Side note: the black pepper in the pepper shaker.....has no flavor. It's probably been sitting there for ages!

Service was good, but they are so busy! I got these on day 2 of my trip, and finished the last 2 slices on day 4. Still turned out fine.

Overall, would potentially come back here? However, if they can deliver nationwide, I would probably try Pequod's next time.

Around 11AM on a Saturday we stopped in for lunch and the restaurant was still relatively empty which was nice. We ordered a small Malnati Chicago Classic small pizza which took about 30-40 minutes to cook. It's a quick wait when you drink a couple glasses of their sangria.... man those are good! Not too sweet, and packs a nice little punch. When the pizza arrived, it was still bubbling and gooey. A small is perfect for two people because it is just so filling. The buttery crust makes it the best deep dish pizza I think I've ever had.

pics.caption: The small Malnati Chicago Classic Pizza is perfect for two people! Sangrias are pretty dang good too.

review.des:
After a lengthy plane ride and finally making it into downtown Chicago after what seemed to be the longest stop-and-go city traffic, my sisters and I finally made our way to authentic a Chicago deep dish pizzeria. Be prepared to wait at least 1.5 hours especially during peak dinner time. We put our name down at the front desk, then went to the right hand side to order our pizza, so by the time we got a table it would only take 20-30 minutes more to wait for the pizza.

We knew we wanted salad and pizza. We ordered the Malnati's salad, which was pleasantly surprising with the sweet vinaigrette and salami bits drizzled over big leafy greens and romaine lettuce. Not sure if we were just ravenous but it was an amazing salad we would be happy to order again. If you're not as hungry, I suggest ordering the smaller size that can serve 2-3 people. If you're very hungry, go for the family size that serves between 4-6 people. Then the Malnati Chicago classic deep dish pizza came! With my first bite, I was greeted by a thick doughy and cheesy goodness. As I was halfway through the slice, I noticed the dough got doughier, the cheese thicker and the meat meatier, which was heavy for my taste. I really wanted more tomato sauce than meat and cheese, but the tomato sauce seemed sparse. I think this was a great introduction to authentic Chicago deep dish, and I'd likely come back! Hopefully next time I'll try the one with more tomato sauce.

Overall I had a good experience here, and got to watch parts of the 2018 NBA draft!

I'm a Chicago girl who grew up on Chicago pizza (only for special occasions as a youngster). I used to make my own, lived and ate pizza in NY, and in Napoli, the home of pizza... Lou Malnati's is one of my favorite places because the servers are great, pizza (the deep dish) is worth the wait, and it's a cool look.

Met the owner of Lou Malnati's when he opened the Oak Park restaurant and he was such a great guy!

The verdict is in.  Had the butter thin crust red meat with mushrooms.  I would say it was delicious.  I had 3 slices and all three tastes differently.  The longer the pizza sat the better it tasted.  I would recommend that when your pizza comes let it sit for another 15 minutes and then eat.  I would eat here again.  For me Diorganos is better

My fave Chicago style.  Love the tangy sauce and the crust that doesn't get in the way of the flavor of the toppings. Unfortunately, we live in a delivery deadzone only a 15 minute drive from the Lincolnwood location.  Please close the deadzone.  Pretty please?

Lou's is pretty tasty and I've already left reviews at two other locations in Chicago so let me just focus on this store in particular:

We came on a Sunday for lunch and to our surprise we were seated right away. Since this location is nestled at the edge of River North, the Gold Coast and South Loop locations tend to be much more crowded. Not having to wait for our seat meant that we can order our food right away. Mind you, the pizza still takes 35-40 min to cook because that's just the way deep dish is - you have to go in with the expectation to wait.

Our server was friendly but not pushy, checked in around 3-4 times throughout our 1 hour-ish meal. The Lou's salad is delicious as usual, and the pizza came right at 40 min after we ordered it so no complaints there.

The restaurant is a lot bigger than it looks on the outside - I believe there are multiple floors and it stretches pretty far back so plenty of seating. There's also plenty of sunlight from the large windows which I appreciate because I prefer to be able to see what I'm eating. Restaurant is clean and the tables aren't packed tightly together. This will be our go-to Lou's in Chicago moving forward!

Was here for a conference and had been hyped up for Chicago style deep dish. Being my first time, I had a lot of hope for this malnatis location.

You expect to wait a long time at a deep dish pizza spot, but I'm not sure that this was worth it. The price was good, but the pizza we got was pretty disappointing. Crust was almost break your teeth hard, and the layers weren't really there. In one bite, you would have just sausage and crust, another cheese and sauce, and every other permutation. I'm not sure if they were in a rush or just lazy, but seeing all of the videos of malnatis preparing it looked like a perfect layering of the pizza. This was clearly not that.

I'll be back, but probably to a different location. I can see all of the ways this could be correct, but sadly, it wasn't.

Lou Malnati's deep dish = damn good. I've never had deep dish za before and am so glad that I got to try it at Lou Malnati's during a trip to Chicago.

We got into town pretty late but that ended up working out in our favor. I hear that there is usually at least an hour wait, but at 10 PM we had no trouble snagging a table.

The menu has a ton of pizza options, but because it was our first visit I knew that we'd have to go with the Lou Malnati classic. Sausage pizza with a butter crust... I mean, c'mon. We also ordered a house salad to go along with the pizza. The salad was the perfect precursor to the heavy pizza - light and refreshing with a ton of delicious toppings. But of course, the real star of the show was the pizza. A small pie is the perfect share for two and comes with four hearty slices. The pizza is incredible - the sauce is fresh and taste homemade, the mozzarella cheese is ooey and gooey, the crust is buttery and flakey. I'm still dreaming about this pizza.

As expected, deep dish pizza is pretty heavy. So expect to be in a bit of a food coma afterwards. But it's also totally worth it. Highly reccomend!

pics.caption: Classic Lou malnati - sausage and butter crust

review.des:
This place is INCREDIBLE. Visiting from NYC, my friend and I wanted to try traditional deep dish pizza and this absolutely exceeded or expectations! We made the silly mistake of not calling ahead of making a reservation, so make sure you do, and there was a long wait. Instead of waiting we sat at the bar.

The bartender was incredible and knew we were from out of town and immediately told us the most popular items on the order. He sold them so well that we just let him take over our order, & boy did he deliver.

We had the Malnati Salad, which was unlike any salad we have ever had. Incredible flavors and combination of items inside. After we had the The Malnati Chicago Classic which also was out of this world.

HIGHLY recommend this place for a good deep dish experience.

Lou Malnati's, in my opinion, is the best deep dish pizza in Chicago. You must try to the Chicago Classic. The sausage is layered in the pizza so you get an even bite of sausage at every bite. The tomato sauce is sweet and savory. The cheese just brings everything together. You won't regret it. When out-of-town friends and family ask where to get deep dish, there is only one answer - Lou's!

So this was recommended by several people for my first try of a Chicago style pizza and boy did it not disappoint! I had a personal Malnati Chicago Classic (with mushrooms added). The sausage on it was some of the best I've ever had and the garlic butter crust was divine. Everything was super fresh. As a pizza lover, I'm sad to not be able to come here more often. We also had the sangria which was pretty good and packed a punch. They make the pizza fresh so be prepared to wait or order and appetizer/salad if you go super hungry. If I'm ever back in Chicago I will definitely be back!

pics.caption: A personal size Malnati Chicago Classic (with mushrooms added)
A personal size Malnati Chicago Classic (with mushrooms added)

review.des: So we had just come into town and we were so tired so we went to our hotel and ordered a pizza. We had it delivered. It took about an hour for us to get it so we showered while waiting. When we were done our pizza and stuffed bread with spinach was arriving. The food was very hot and delicious!!!!! I think that was the best pizza I've had to date!!!!! I'd definitely order from this place again!!!! Thank you for making our night amazing!!!

pics.caption: Absolutely amazing!!!!!! The taste is so fresh and the flavor is just on point!!!! The sauce and the pepperoni is just mouth watering.

review.des:
IM SO DISAPPOINTED ):  I came to Chicago wanting REALLY BOMB deep dish pizza and I didn't get any... Lou Malnati's was highly recommended by so many people except I had a group of friends who thought this place was a let down but I still wanted to try for myself.  With a solid 4 stars and over 4k reviews and many other locations.. I had such high expectations.. maybe too high.

Anyways, we came on a Sunday night and was quoted 45-60 min wait.  Doable.  We put down our names and preordered our pizza.  We ordered the Lou and added italian sausage.  The wait wasn't too bad, we managed to find seats inside.  Fast forward, we were seated and ordered a salad and couple drinks.  I was so shocked at how long it took the salad to come out... and even shocked at how long the PIZZA took to come out.  What was the point of preordering?!  It felt like it still took a good hour for it come out...

Finally the pizza came out and it was HUGE.  I excitedly took the first bite and it was just EH.  Nothing special.. as I continued to eat more, I started to come across SUPER salty parts of the pizza.  It was as if they dumped a pile of salt onto the pizza.  At first I thought it was just me but my girlfriend experienced the same saltiness! I also didn't like how they just throw on huge slabs of sausage onto the pizza... like cut it up into pieces or something?!  Literally blocks of sausage on top of our pizza lol.  Meh... such a disappointed.  It wasn't bad, but I definitely don't think the pizza was worth the wait or the hype.

I don't usually like deep dish pizza but I guess I just hadn't had a good one until trying Lou Malnati's! We ordered the Malnati Classic and the Lou and both were SO GOOD!! The Lou is vegetarian, and the mix of flavors was amazing!! Seriously, the garlic, cheese, fresh tomatoes, pizza sauce, basil...all of it just melts together into one perfect slice of heavenly, cheesy, goodness. We came here twice in one weekend, that is how good it was! And the crust to topping ratio is perfect, the butter crust is crispy and not too thick. The center is perfectly cooked and the pizza toppings stay on the pizza...they dont fall off in a gooey mess. It really is the perfect slice of deep dish pizza!

I went when it was somewhat busy, but it was a good vibe. The staff was friendly and attentive, and I found seating at the bar. I ordered an individual pepperoni and it was great! Very good quality pizza! I would recommend.

This is the first time I've been in Chicago and had real deep dish. I've had Zachary's in Berkeley, but nothing from Chicago (Zachary's actually is very authentic now that I've had the real stuff).

I've been here twice so far, both times during the week. Both times there was a 30-40 minute wait so be prepared. Don't leave because of the wait though because they allow you to order your deep dish when you check in. It takes 45-60 minutes to cook, so the wait is almost irrelevant. Would you rather sit down and wait an hour for your pizza or walk around outside and get called in and have a pizza served almost immediately?

Both times we got the Malnati pizza. The first time we got a large, with only 3 people. That was a mistake. It was 8 pieces and we could only do 2 pieces each because of how dense and heavy one piece is. It's like eating a stuffed cheesy pie with sausage goodness. The crust isn't thick at all, it's the perfect thickness with the perfect amount of buttery crispness. I still prefer thin crust, but I know when something is good and I'll give credit when credit is due. If you have 3 people, a medium will be 2 slices each. Go for that.

The buffalo wings are also really good. Surprisingly they're some of the better wings I've had in a while. The actual wings are good quality and well cooked. They're not spicy as normal, but very good if you need a warm up to the pizza.

First off, deep dish pizza was never appealing to me.  Lou Malnati's is know for their Chicago style deep dish pizza.  We ordered a Large size deep dish that feeds about 4-5 people with 8 slices.  I could only eat 1 slice since I am not a fan of deep dish or sausage, which was the main topping.  We also added pepperoni which was and add on.  I felt the pizza was to cheesey and it wasn't like melted cheese it seems a bit hard.  The crunch of the crust was really good.  To be honest I don't even remember how the pizza had tasted.  

The best part was the appetizers we ordered.  We ordered the BuffaLou wings which came with 8 pieces of wings and a side of celery with ranch sauce.  The wings were very tasteful and a bit Spicy.  My group finished the wings and wanted another round of it!

We also ordered the Trio of Dips and Pizza Chips.  The dips were roasted garlic, artichoke and glardinier-topped hummus.  Pizza chips where crips and paired nice with the dips.  The best dip was the artichoke and wasn't to fond of the garlic one.  

Our wait time was approximately 20 min to be seated.  Make sure to sign in with the person standing on the side of the entrance. We missed him and so did many others trying to dine in.

Well I thought I would try a deep dish pizza while in Chicago and was recommended this place by a friend. I am probably not too much of a pizza lover to truly enjoy or appreciate this kind of pizza, it was nice but really nothing to ride home about (again not much of a pizza connaisseur), however I sure didn't enjoy the service.
I sat at the bar with other customers, by themselves like me for the most part, and the girl behind the bar was the least personable considering she is in a customer oriented job. She just did her job of serving the drinks and food with hardly no interactions with customers. I stayed there for one hour and she relentlessly chat up her colleague server or bartender without even bothering.
I would not recommend this place just for that and will not be back here! A complete lack of customer service and charisma. Not even a smily person :(

I had two plans in mind for coming out to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria.  I had heard about the long lines, so:

1) Put our names down, go get hot dogs at Portillo's which was just 0.3 miles away, and eat them while waiting for our names to be called - also to pre-order the pizzas during our wait.

2) Go during an odd time for a meal in the hopes of missing a line entirely - this is also known as the grazing through the day method.

We ended up heading to Lou's after the river boat architectural cruise, and thus unfortunately had hit prime time.  We were quoted over an hour's wait (1 hour 40 min?), but we put our name in because there didn't seem to be much around the area and where would we take a take-out pie?  So we put our pizza order in under the name on the reservation list.

After waiting for a bit, one DC suggested that we put my hot dog idea into play.  I checked in for the current estimated time and off we walked.  Ironically, we ended up finding the largest McDonald's I had previously heard of (the one with museum type exhibits) across from Portillo's.

As we waited for our order number to be called at Portillo's - this after having waited in a rather sizeable line to place our order - we heard numbers being called over and over again, and patrons being reminded to look at the number on their receipts.  But then, we got... the buzz.  Our number was up at Lou's and we had 5 minutes to get to our table!  We gave up on our hot dog and high tailed it back over.  Yes, we became one of those numbers... poor Portillo's.

One friend was stopped by a light, but she told us to keep going.  Two of us both made the next light, but then I realized that was alone, as yet another traffic light had caught my other companion, so it was all on me.

But I made it and was told to check in inside to be seated. Yes!  New arrivals were being told of an hour wait at this point.

We had ordered two small pizza pies - The Malnati Chicago Classic $15.95 (Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust), and The "Lou" $17.95 (Spinach mix, mushrooms and sliced roma tomatoes covered with blend of mozzarella, romano and cheddar cheese on garlic Buttercrust), both well done.

Once we sat, it was 20 minutes to pizza, as they cooked it half way after we ordered it, and then the rest of the way once we were seated.  They looked rather wet, which disappointed us since we had ordered our pies well done.  But we started off on the classic and found a disk of sausage beneath the tomato and cheese layer - yes, that would keep the moisture from dissipating.  But we asked if the other pie could be run through the oven to dry it out some.

It disappeared for longer than expected - I became worried that it would come back burnt.  But it was fine - just a tiny bit charred.  And that did dry it out some.  I preferred the spinach pizza over the sausage, but then I tend to prefer veggies on my pizza.

Hot and fresh - they're really good!  But once cooled, they're not so good.

Service was iffy.  One friend asked for water and received a full replacement glass.  The server left too fast for me to ask for water as well.  When I did manage to ask for water, it was nearly the end of the meal before water was poured for me.

This was my first time to Chicago. I loved it and I want to go back!. We got to this place around 6:30 - just in time before it got crowded. The waitress busted her but to make our dining experience prefect. I got the Chicago Classic. My co-workers got the sausage crust pizza, which they loved. The wait for the pizza takes a bit, but worth it. The wine was good, just understand that you are paying city prices. Work was paying so I wasn't sweating it : ) - this place rocks!

Solid deep dish pizza joint! Came here around 4:45pm on a Thursday and luckily there was no wait to be seated. My co-worker and I ordered a few drinks and started off dinner with the stuffed spinach bread. This was definitely the best part of the meal. It was around $8 and a kind of small. The bread was crispy and flaky with cheese, garlic, and spinach pouring out of it.

For dinner, we ordered a cheese deep dish with the butter crust. This took the full 45 mins like the waitress had informed us. The pizza was good! It wasn't amazing though like I was expecting. I thought it was lacking sauce and almost felt like it was a large cheese bread. I would also follow the recommendations of the serving size on the menu. We ordered the medium and was no where close to finishing it and even the server suggested the small.

Overall, solid pizza joint but would be open to trying others in the area to see how they compare.

pics.caption: Cheese deep dish with the butter crust

review.des:
Who doesn't like pizza? I'm a big fan of pizza but only eat it once in awhile. So when I do it better be amazing.

Being married to a Chicagoan I am use to deep dish pizza and only eat at the best. Lou Malnati's is the best! They have several locations around Chicago from the city to the Suburbs. Every time we are in Chicago we always make a stop at one of their places.

We came for a early dinner before going to the airport. The hostess seated us downstairs and was very friendly. Our waiter was quick to take our order since the pizza takes 45 minutes to make. We started with a house salad which was plenty to share. We ordered their signature pizza deep dish cheese and sausage in a small. One piece was plenty for me.

The service was great and prices are fair. See you soon Lou on our next trip back to Chicago.

The best Chicago deep dish pizza. Yes it takes a while to get the food since it is deep dish. We decided to order the bruschetta while we waited. OMG best bruschetta I have ever had it was yummy. The beer was really good too a change from what I'm used to but so good. Wish they had that in cali. Which they had this pizza and bruschetta in Cali. Everything was amazing. The service was great. They even brought be desert since it was my birthday. Can't wait to go back this place is beautiful on the inside really has an older restaurant vibe.

It was just ok. Maybe we needed more toppings or were just exhausted. But it was just ok. It felt like a tourist chain place. It was good and glad we went, but nothing crazy special. The wait staff was awesome and they were unbelievably managed. But the food was lacking.

Maybe it's the New Yorker in me .. but I just don't get the deep dish pizza. Pizza is something you can dine on-the-go and a very hands-on experience. Deep dish requires too much preparation .. Anyhow, seeing that this establishment was so highly reviewed, I was excited to come here but, man, the service here is SLOW to borderline despicable. We came in on a Sunday afternoon and was seated without reservation in maybe 10 minute. They encourage you to order the pizza before you get seated because the pie takes about 30 mins to make. So we went to the 2nd floor dining area, and it took the waitress at least 15 minutes before she introduced herself and another 5-10 minutes before we got our water. For a chain restaurant (they have multiple locations; reminds me of a localized Olive Garden), that's unacceptable. I overheard nearby patrons complaining about the same thing - "The waitress looked swamped" or "She's never around" .. but it seemed like she was manning 6 tables/parties max. I don't know if they're understaffed or just poorly trained. I know, as a waitress in NYC, the service we received would never fly.

Anyhow, we ordered a calamari and two personal pies - the original and the meat. The calamari was standard; nothing terribly interesting beyond that they served it with a shrimp cocktail sauce which was strange and took some adjustment due to the unexpected tartness. I really enjoyed the meat but it reminded me of a casserole; the meat provided an unexpected umami flavor that was lacking in the original, which was composed of tomatoes, spinach, etc. Surprisingly, the crust was crispy but also borderline hard .. a great contrast to the moist meat/vegetables which were meh at best. Warning: portion sizes are huge; two personal pies were sufficient between two people. My partner wasn't impressed by the pies - he mentioned he has had better in Chicago.

Nevertheless, what I truly dislike about my experience here was that we got the first beer way BEFORE the pizza arrived and we got our second beer way AFTER finishing the pizza. Essentially we consumed the pizza with water, which is whatever. Meanwhile, waitress kept checking in with other patrons and coming by our table saying "Oh we will get the beer soon!"

So, do I recommend? Maybe if you're very very VERY interested in deep dish pizza but I probably wouldn't want this to be my first deep dish experience as it wasn't too convincing. Would I return? Unlikely. Food was mediocre despite some interesting notes, but service was notoriously abhorrent and unorganized. I am sure there are better deep dish pizza out there.

pics.caption: The meat/sausage pie. Prob the better of the two choices available.
Calamari with shrimp cocktail sauce - took some getting use to.

review.des: Very delicious pizza place. My husband and I often come here to try different kinds of pizzas. We never get disappointed. Friendly service whenever we come here

I figured I should try Lou Malnati's because it's a Chicago staple.  I was glad to see that they offer small sizes: a six inch deep dish or nine inch thin crust.  I tried both the Chicago Classic deep dish and the pepperoni thin.  Both were unique.  I hadn't  eaten anything like either of them before.  However, neither was so special that I'd go out of my way to return.

They have several craft beers on tap.

There is lots of Chicago sports memorabilia on the walls, but when we visited it was too crowded to see any of it--visited on a Tuesday night and waited thirty minutes for a table.

Service was really good considering how busy the place was.

Easy access from the L train, brown line, Merchandise Mart Station--just across the street.

There's a line out the door, but it's worth the wait.  The deep dish pizza here may be the single best pizza I have ever eaten.  I'm normally more a fan of thin crust pizza, because it's all about the toppings, but the butter crust here melds perfectly with the sausage and mushrooms and the whole thing just melts in your mouth.  Perfection.

While you're waiting for the pizza, try the calamari.  It's excellent.

This tourist attraction is mostly for tourist most Chicagoans pass on a slice of pizza that's so filling they don't need to eat for a full day. Trust me, if people in Chicago regularly ate Lou Malnatis Chicago style pizza there wouldn't be anyone here. Jam packed with carbs, fat, sugar that you can't taste and calories this delicious treat is not designed for regular consumption.

They have other things on their menu but anyway you go this place is a gut buster.
Thin crust here with the spinach medley is pretty great. Though not the best deep dish in town

Best local chain.
Giordano's is most consistent but we like Malnati's crust and sausage.

Love the fact that this restaurant have you pre order the pizzas before you get a table as the pizza takes 30 minuets to cook. Waited about 15 minuets before getting seated but very good service and smoothly run. The thin crust cheese pizza was amazing as well as the calamari and bbq wings.

I'm not quite sure what I was expecting upon coming to Lou Malnatis.  I did quite a bit of research of which deep dish I wanted to try in Chicago and had chosen this place.   It was solidified by the fact we have some friends in Chicago who suggested we meet there for dinner.

We get there and it's packed.   I mean PACKED!  The wait is 45 min to an hour but they text you and keep you updated as to your spot in line so you don't have to be close.  

We didn't order before hand which was a mistake because our server, while very nice, was overwhelmed.   She couldn't seem to remember what we asked for and wasn't around our table very often.  And she seemed super annoyed by us by then end of our meal (like she wanted us to leave) and we actually never saw her again (I think she left for the night without telling us.)

The pizza itself wasn't that good.   It wasn't that hot when we got it and the "buttercrust" tasted like a dry undercooked cracker with no flavor at all.  I felt like I might actually need to add salt to my meal which I never do.  

If I had to describe this place in one word: underwhelming.

pics.caption: spinach pizza - lacked any flavor at all
Meatball sandwich (meatball was actually pretty good)

review.des:
Bomb pizza! The staff was great, my wife is pregnant and only seating they had was outside but the host came and got us a table on the inside which we appreciated! This place is a must if you want to get that Chicago feel and get that authentic deep dish taste. I will be back.

Also know that you can pre order your food! The pizza's take about 40mins to make. Which is a good time to socialize if you like and enjoy your company or date night.

It's all about the dang buttercrust here.  It's flavorful, flaky, and really satisfying.  I prefer the original sausage deep dish (dish deep sausage heh..) vs The Lou, but both were pretty good.  In my opinion, the cheese, sausage patty, and tomato sauce are a step up from Pizzeria Uno.  If I ever come back to Chicago, Lou's would definitely be a place I would revisit.

4 stars.

Deep dish pizza is a must while in Chicago!

Was quoted 45min wait, but after 30mins I found seating at the bar. After the 30min wait, was told it would be another 45mins for the pizza to arrive! Ordered an appetizer of buffalo wings because I was getting hangry and wow... the wings were AMAZING. I was recommending everyone else at the bar to order some! Extra crispy and the buffalo sauce had the perfect amount of tangy-ness. I had no expectations of how I would like the pizza because I love thin crust, but I was caught off guard at how good it was. A small size was perfect to share between my boyfriend and I. We actually killed the whole pizza. I love that the sausage was like a huge patty so that you could have sausage with every bite. The crust was crispy and cheese was gooey... I'm salivating as I'm writing this review!

All in all, worth the wait and Lou's lives up to the hype.

Now, before everyone starts coming for me because of the 3/5 rating, please note that this is my first time trying "Chicago Deep Dish" in Chicago. I've had "deep-dish" "Chicago-inspired" pizza before and it was amazing.

First and foremost, Lou's was not terrible. I was expecting more dynamic and rich flavors, but instead I got something that was a tad mediocre. A girlfriend and I were in town for work, so we took a short walk to Lou's. The line was out the door! We walked in and reserved our names with an expected 1 hour wait. We were able to pre-order our pizza so that it would be ready by the time we sat down. Great, great idea; however, poorly executed.

As soon as we were seated, the kind waitress confirmed our pizza. It took another hour for the pizza to arrive. What was the point in me ordering earlier only to have to wait another hour for our meal to come out? We ordered the "The Malnati Chicago Classic" and it was... okay. It was layered of crust, sauce, sausage patty, cheese, and tomatoes. We asked for garlic as an additional add-on. I think if I had not asked for garlic, the experience would not have been "A-OK" per Yelp standards.

For a large, we paid about $30.00 which is a phenomenal price for how much food you were getting. I can eat a ton, but I was able to maybe eat about 2-3 slices at most. (2 being comfortable, 3 being uncomfortably full)

Overall, it's /okay/. I think if you have the opportunity to explore more of Chicago, I would try to find the hidden mom-and-pop shop gems of the city instead of Lou's.

I heard from my friends that this was the MUST-TRY Chicago deep dish pizza joint, and it didn't disappoint! Lou Malnati's is a 10-20 min walk from the Bean and Willis Tower (the Skydeck), and I definitely recommend walking or coming here through a rideshare service because Chicago traffic can get crazy.

I came here with my family (a party of 20+) on my birthday, and HUGE props to our waitress for being super patient with us. We started off with the Malnati salad, which was so delicious. I particularly enjoyed the combination of the mushrooms, salami, Gorgonzola cheese, and the sweet vinaigrette dressing. Other appetizers we got were the combination platter (mozzarella sticks, breaded mushrooms, zucchini), three-cheese bread, and the stuffed spinach bread. All of these were cheesy and filling, but looking back it at, I wish we didn't go so overboard because we underestimated our main course.

Now onto the most important part... the pizza. Since we came in a large party, we decided to get both the Lou (vegetarian option), and the Malnati Chicago Classic (contains meat). I definitely preferred the the Lou pizza more, but both were out of this world. When you cut into the pizza, it felt like cutting into a fluffy cloud. 1 slice was pretty filling, but luckily we had some leftovers to enjoy for later (which I happily kept eating).

Since I came on my birthday, my sister told the waitress and they brought me out a deep dish cookie with vanilla ice cream, whipped cream, and a candle. That was the best cookie I had in my life, and I was grateful that I got it as a complimentary birthday dessert.

Overall, I really enjoyed eating authentic Chicago deep dish pizza here, and I highly recommend checking it out if you're visiting the area!
Best pizza ever! We got the thin crust and it was perfect. Not too thick, not too thin. The crust and sauce is homemade and delicious!!!

We came here on a weekday for lunch around 11:45 am.  There were only a few tables taken so we got a seat easily.  We ordered the The Malnati Chicago Classic and the server informed us it would take about 40 minutes to make the pizza.  Around 12:30 nearly every table in the restaurant was taken so I would definitely recommend coming by 12:15 pm if you are coming for lunch on a weekday.

The deep dish was really good.  I loved the tomatoes and sausage that comes on the pizza.  I'm not usually a crust person but this buttery crispy crust was outstanding.  There was a thick layer of cheese and for me it was just a little too much.  This was definitely a delicious pizza and I see why it's one of the most popular deep dish places in Chicago.

pics.caption: Malnati Chicago Classic with green peppers added on

review.des: We eat here every time we are in the Windy City! It's our favorite spot for buttery deep dish and their "crustless" pizza which is made of sausage instead of gluten! Yum...My hubby gets the deep dish with sausage and pepperoni, butter crust. I get the personal pan crustless pizza with spinach and mushrooms. So goood!!!

Let me preface this by saying the food is very good. If this is what I am to expect deep dish to taste like, I think I am off to a good start. My experience with the service was appalling however. Management, you really shouldn't allow your staff to diminish an experience that should be outstanding.

To be fair I was one of a party of 13 arriving for a 9pm dinner reservation. I stress reservation, to point out that the purpose of scheduling one is to be prepared for guests. I digress. The restaurant was not ready. We hovered around the door for a few minutes, then escorted upstairs to two tables that would only accommodate a portion of our party. It wasn't until another table of two left that we were able to add our other three members to the group. Fine. No big deal.

Enter our server, Tonya, or was it Terry? Right off the bat she looked stressed. Was she overwhelmed with such a large group to tend to? Who knows. She made it clear that she was in a hurry and not in any position to be polite. My colleague is Vegan so we asked if they had Vegan options on the menu. No, the pizza is not vegan. We then asked about the bruschetta. Her reply, and I quote, "are you always this annoying, or is it just today?" My head exploded! Because I was with work colleagues I didn't snap. I wasn't the only one who kept mum. Tonya/Terry really didn't want to ask about the bread. In a tone that was forthright, yet polite, I requested that she ask the kitchen about the Bruschetta, just to be sure. She did. Anyway, the bruschetta wasn't vegan. I forget what my colleague ordered.

The rest of the team went H.A.M on the deep dish. The classic, the mushroom and the cheese were all ordered and devoured with pleasure. But, we are getting ahead of ourselves. When it came time to serve said pizzas I couldn't tell if I was being yelled at for ordering my food or being yelled at because there was so much. In a loud voice "okay, I've got two Classic, where are they going," "well hand me plates and I'll hand you the pizza!"

At this point everyone was bewildered at her tone, her body language and her hastiness. When we discovered we were missing two additional pizzas the team opted not to push with ordering them. Since it would take 45 minutes for them to come out. We were quite ready to finish our food and leave as quickly as possible.

Miraculously (perhaps she overheard our whispering) our server tried to redeem herself. "May I serve you another slice," looks like the pizza order was fixed, your pizzas are on their way." They came, we took them so go.

What a missed opportunity by Lou's, all because of one lousy server. The floors weren't clean either! Our Chicago based team will be sad to hear about our experience I am sure.

Came back after almost a year. Still impressed. Still delicious as heck!

I played host to a few guests from Asia. We flew into Chicago for a meeting. And the very first meal I treated them to was deep dish pizzas at Lou Malnati's. Everyone was dazzled. Everyone was blown away. And we all left stuffed and happy.

Our eight man table ordered two pies - the Lou and the Chicago; two orders of the crispy calamari; and one Lou's special salad. We loved every morsel.

What i love most about this pizza joint is the buttery crust. You just can't find that tongue tantalizing taste anywhere else in Chicago's forrest of pizza shops. It's my opinion that Lou's has the best deep dish in the entire city.

Will I return. Oh heck yeah!

Best Chicago deep dish? I mean this is the only one I've tried, but I'd say it's pretty good. We went around 4PM on a Sunday, so there was no line yet. We got seated right away, but we were told that the pizza itself would take about 30 minutes to an hour.

My friend and I split a small Malnati Chicago Classic. It had just basic cheese and sausage, but it was good. The crust was crunchy and their was a good proportion of everything. I'll admit eating half a small was definitely heavy though.

I was told people from Chicago don't actually eat deep dish, but I'd come here to eat it again. Only downside was the pizza took awhile.

First time trying Chicago style deep dish and I must say, this place offers some great Chicago style deep dish pizza
Had the classic and the "Lou" Pizza. Both delicious.

Only downfall was the wait time. We waited 30 minutes for a table and another 30+ minutes for the pizza after we ordered it.

Our experience did not start so well unfortunately. We were in town just for 2 day to visit the city and try something new. The service was very slow, we ordered a medium deep dish with a few toppings. It took them 1 hour 35 minutes.. The manager then came over to apologize and told us they lost our receipt in the kitchen. Then said she would take care of the pizza off our bill. Which was very nice of her but people around were starting to get upset with the service.

Came here for lunch after my red eye from PDX.  Sat at the bar and ordered a beer and personal pizza.  The guy communicated well and let me know it'd take about 30 mins which was fine with me.

The pizza came and I scarfed it down like I hadn't eaten in days (more like 14 hours).  After I was done a shift change had happened and a different server brought out a cookie dessert and wished me a happy birthday. What a sweet surprise!  When the first guy took my beer order, he carded me and noted it had been my bday the day before.  I'm sorry I didn't get to thank him.  What a great way to start my visit to Chicago!

After seeing Hamilton my husband and I worked our way up here for dinner. I was expecting a huge crowd but was amazed by the fact that the place was half empty when we arrived. We got seated immediately.

Service however was very slow and took a while to get waited on. Although they have both deep dish and their Malnati's specials we decided to go with thin crust since we were pretty much worn out. Our waiter said it would take 45 minutes to prepare but since we ordered thin crust he said he would check on it and we would probably have it sooner.

The main dining area is decorated with jerseys of famous people.  They have near the entrance a sign that says text message area. I guess they must use texting if there is a line. I noticed the place was a bit old and when I went to use the ladies room I had to wait since there was only one stall and it was in a small area.

We did however get our pizza in 15 minutes. We ordered a small mushroom and green pepper.Toppings are extra on cheese pizzas and they do note that even if you order half topping then you pay the full price of the topping.

I did see many people ordering for take out or doggie bags since you get so much. Place can get very loud at times.

There were 6 generous cuts to the pizza. They were good but not anything that I would find spectacular. Maybe if I had the deep dish one that would have made a difference.

There are other items on the menu besides pizza. Even for desserts my husband spotted a chocolate pizza but we were pretty full to go beyond the pizza we shared. You can eat either indoors or out. You can even sit on a high top or at a booth. The choice is yours. I

No trip would be complete without trying one of Chicago's famous pizza places and we were glad to have the opportunity to enjoy one.

I can't even begin how to express our disappointment!
We used to live in Chicago and bring some friends from California to visit family over the weekend. We were so excited to show them what Chicago deep dish taste like. We got there at 12 pm, waited for table for 2 hours, got our food at 3 pm after several complained. Food came out cold and hard. Wow! The worst customer service and horrible food. We refused to pay for the food and we left hungry. Such a wasted of time!
Hands down best pizza in Chicago!!! The Lou's Classic is delicious and I'm OBSESSED with their House Salad!!!

Buuutttteeerrrr Crust!!!! We had the CLASSIC with mushrooms. This is Chicago deep dish. Great friendly staff and comfortable place. Terrific sports memorabilia much better Theisman's in Alexandria VA. Come enjoy and be happy.

Came here on a Friday afternoon for what I was hoping was a quick bite. I sat at the bar, where a snippy bartender took my order. He ran off before I could finish the order, so I had to call him back and finish adding toppings. After 45 minutes I asked about my pizza, and the bartender brought up that I should've gotten his attention. Not like I spent 15 minutes trying or anything!!

They didn't clean the seats, so unfortunately I also sat in some pizza sauce. Asked the bartender for some napkins, which he threw at me.

Lastly, I asked for the check. The guy was standing right in front of me and completely ignored me.

Service is abysmal. They charge extra per topping and I thought the pizza was just okay. Not worth the wait and not worth the hype.

First deep dish pizza experience in Chicago didn't disappoint. We order a personal pepperoni and a personal sausage along with a salad. They delivered to our hotel- however it took a while. Once it arrived it was hot and tasted great. Their house dressing for their salad was one of the best tasting  vinaigrettes I've ever had.
Pizza is delicious! One of our favorite restaurants in Chicago! Sometimes we do carry out and it's still as yummy at home! Would recommend trying at least once during your visit to the city.
Amazing deep dish pizza!  I crave this pizza!  Salad was good and huge! Such a great stop in Chicago!

Absolutely GARBAGE!!! Can't believe people wait for this frozen pizza crap. You're better off eating at dominos pizza hahaha.

I guess some people here in Chicago can't taste quality.

Went here for deep dish pizza. Be prepared for a 45 minute wait when it is not even busy.  This was listed as a great place but I didn't think it was that good. The sauce needed more flavor, was very plain tomato - needed some garlic and or oregano- and the tomatoes needed to be chopped more. One of the kids pulled off a chunk of tomato the size of a ping pong ball. We liked Giordanos better.

I've been to Chicago dozens of times, and I've eaten deep dish pizza, but I'd never had deep dish in Chicago. A crime, I know. On a winter visit to Chicago my boyfriend and I decided to right this wrong and check out Lou Malnati's for a late lunch. We sadly had just missed their wonderful-sounding lunch special and thus opted to split a medium Malnati Chicago Classic - sausage, extra cheese, and tomato sauce on their signature butter crust.

The menu has serving suggestions for the different sizes, and though there were two of us we picked the medium (serves three) because my boyfriend wanted leftovers. I am here to tell you that you do not need to size up to leave with extra pizza. Despite being ravenous when we walked in, I was only able to take down a slice and a half and my boyfriend two and a half. Even a small would have left us with extra slices.

The pizza itself was delicious and decadent. I generally hate sausage, but Italian sausage done right is a treat and I'm glad I trusted my instincts to give it a try here. The amount of cheese would make any Wisconsinite feel at home, and the sauce was a tasty topper. The butter crust was, as advertised, buttery. You will definitely feel like a 'Da Bears Chris Farley after enjoying a meal here.

I went into our lunch fully intending to order their Chocolate Chip Pizza after a previous stay in River North that taunted me the entire time with the smell of fresh-baked cookies. However, after my gut-busting failed attempt to eat a second slice of our deep dish I had to abandon all hope. Meal or dessert - never the twain shall meet in my belly during a LM visit.

Service was good. When you arrive you can put in your order while you wait for a table due to the long cooking times. We were seated just as we made up our minds and were about to place our order. Due to the long wait between ordering and our pizza's arrival we could have used another check-in to refill drinks, but that was my only complaint. Once we got our pizza our server was great about checking in to make sure we were happy with our meal and that we had everything we needed.

Deep dish pizza isn't something that I can do regularly, but I could definitely see working this in once a year or so on one of our Chicago visits.

I've been to Chicago once before and had Giordanos and absolutely loved their pizza. I was going to go visit them again because I knew I'd enjoy myself and it would be a no fail dining experience.  Of course I had to reference my fellow Yelpers and see what they had to say since I haven't been here for about 7 years. I'm glad I went off my plan and took the "risk" of trying Lous.

I definitely can see what all the hype is about, their deep dish pizza is definitely a Chicagoan staple.  I was staying far from this particular location but had to check it out because the ones close to my hotel were take out only. Arrived at this location and saw a lot of people waiting to be seated. It was good and bad, obviously because I know people want to eat here and the pizza must be good and bad because I was bracing myself for probably a minimum of an hour wait. Was sunrise when I gave my name and they gave me an estimated time of 30-35 minutes. They let you pre order Pizza before seated as it takes about 45 minutes to make.  Sweet!

So I thought to myself I've got plenty of time to check out another Chicago place to eat, Stans donuts. Looked it up, saw it was .7 miles away and called the uber. As soon as I arrived at stans, I got a text saying my table was ready and they'll hold it for 5 minutes. CRAP!!! Texted them back and said I was in the bathroom, whoops.  My table was ready within 15 minutes.

Okay, now for the nitty gritty. Was planning on only getting the pizza but someone suggested the wings. Being the fatty I am I of course ordered it, wasn't sure if I should get the bbq or the buffalo style so the waiter suggested both sauces on the side and ranch. Hell yes. They arrived and they were mighty delicious. How the heck do I eat this and not be full, or pace it as slow as I can and wait for the pizza? I was hoping they weren't that good, but they were. So hard to do when you're hungry and have been saving your appetite all day for this meal.

Alas, my pizza arrived..half pepperoni half sausage. Omg, so good. The crust was nice and crispy and my first bite and a burst of flavor. Pizza was expertly made as it left me to wonder how the toppings don't fall off.  You can taste all the ingredients in every bite, pepperoni, cheese, sauce, crystal working in perfect harmony.  So glad I made the decision to go here.  Now I need to go back to giordanos and have myself a little contest.

But wait, there's more. As I had to unbutton my pants and had no shame gluttonizing my way through the pizza and wings, I had to finish it off with their dessert. And yet again, it was bomb. It's a pizookie  basically, a chocolate chip cookie with a bunch of vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. Idk what's different in this one vs bjs but it was amazingly good. Cookie was good, ice cream and whip cream. Geez, I can go back just for that or any of the three things I had separately.

First deep dish experience of this trip. Got seats at the bar and ordered the Lou (pictured). Really really good. Started with the salad to set a good base of greens before the glutinous regret. But there was none. The pizza was perfect in every damn way.

I came here by myself and got seated at the bar right away, by the time I was done eating the place was packed and lots of people were waiting outside. If I had to guess the wait time was probably close to 45 min.

I ordered the personal size of the Malnati's Classic. Since this was my first time in Chicago, I have to get deep dish pizza. Oh man, the crust is out of this world. Its crispy on the outside and soft and flaky on the inside. I was certainly not disappointed, it exceeded my expectations. Perks of sitting at a bar: you get to meet other travelers. So great lunch place for solo travelers.

Definitely worth the wait!! Almost was thrown off about the wait but once we sat down and ate it was all worth it it. The crust was the main show for me it was buttery and just amazing. The pie filling was amazing can't wait to go back and enjoy this wonderful pie

Lou's was PACKED when we arrived at 7. We threw our name in the queue and we're seated within about 20 minutes. We ordered the Lou Pizza and a Malnati salad. The salad was awesome! Fresh bruschetta, delicious cheese bacon and olives with a great house dressing, we polished off this salad pretty quickly! The pizza looked amazing but unfortunately tasted pretty bland. The crust was delicious though. Maybe we just picked the wrong toppings because the tables around us were raving about their orders. The dining room was really tight, getting in and out was nearly impossible. Overall it was a pretty blah meal.

I was expecting sooooo much deliciousness... I ate at another deep dish pizza restaurant the other day that was rated 3.5 and loved it... I thought, wow, if this is 3.5 star pizza I can't wait to try this 4 star pizza...sadly, this place didn't live up to the hype I've been reading about. We got the sausage deep dish and a thin cheese crust for the kids. The sausage deep dish had a layer of sauce, sausage, cheese and more sauce. I'm used to pieces of sausage in my pizza and didn't really like the sausage layer that covered the whole pizza. Crust was crispy which I thought I would love, but just didn't do it for me. All in all good pizza, but wasn't great for me.

It's okay. Lou Malnati's is a common choice when you ask natives where to get your one tourist deep dish from, and it's okay at best. There's a ton of little places around that make better pizza than the Chicago institutions. Two that are probably in delivery range are Fat Chris's and ORD. They have some great pizza.

Lou's is still great if you need a stack of pizzas for a party or work function, and it's a great choice if you're ordering for kids, but that's all I use them for.

Lou, lou, lou... sigh... it's over. We are done. I know you could care less about me when it's warm & the place is swarmed by tourists... but winter is coming & you will miss me then. & no doubt the rest of the neighborhood you treat like !@#$ during the summer.

This last time did it. We were told our order would be ready around 5:45. So we wait, & wait & wait some more. Everybody else is getting their order no problem. We finally got it around 6:40pm. Not hot at all because it probably was sitting in a warmer for close to an hour.

Gino's is around the corner. Bar Cargo is 2 blocks north. & dum, dum, dum West Loop's Parlor Pizza is comin' soon on Kinzie.

Ugh. I knew going in that I prefer NYC style pizzas (also true Italian pizzas!). However, I've heard SO MUCH about Lou Malnati's deep dish pizza that I decided I would keep an open mind. What a terrible experience!

I came here alone, and I was told that they don't seat singles. So I decided to order take-out, which apparently takes THIRTY minutes. So I decided to walk around downtown and come back half an hour later, and lo and behold they went to the kitchen to "check on it." My thoughts? They want to remain exclusive so they tell me thirty minutes and make it in the ten minutes when I came back to ask about it. Not only that, the classic Lou's was... not good. It was like eating a very disappointing pie. There was a soggy bottom, and the cheese in a quarter of the pizza was quite enough for the ENTIRE pizza. Phew! What a waste of my time. I would recommend that you come here if you like deep dish pizza, but if you're from NYC or Italy just STAY AWAY!

When you go to Chicago, you have to try their Deep Dish Pizzas!  & not just one, you have to try a few in order to find out which one is the king of all pizzas.

This was one of the best reviewed & most talked about pizza joints by all of our Uber drivers.  The deep dish takes about 45 minutes to make so they recommend you order appetizers while you wait but  I say wait it out because once the deep dish comes, you will get so full & it will be that more satisfying.

The "Lou":  A vegetable based pizza on top of a delicious garlic Buttercrust.  So much ooey, gooey cheese.  Yum, yum, yum!  We ordered a small & that was plenty for us.

Also, you can get this pizza shipped to you nationwide!

I'm not sure what they think they gave me but it wasn't deep dish, unless I have an unfortunate misconception of what deep dish truly is. I was expecting layers upon layers of toppings - think lasagna in a pizza. I mean like T-H-I-C-C. Instead I got a single layer of cheese, sausage, and sauce like any other ordinary, non-deep dish pizza. Maybe it was my fault for ordering the personal size ("Classic Chicago"). We did also order a small Lou's and that one was more like what I was expecting. That one was pretty good, hence the 3 stars. I probably would not come again during prime dining time when the wait was 1+ hour (e.g., Sunday at 5:30pm).

pics.caption: "Deep dish" pizza (Classic Chicago in personal size) = just a single layer of toppings??

review.des: Classic deep dish pizza. The Lou was a great vegetarian option. Really hit the spot on a cold night. We also got the Chicago classic which was good. It was about a 45 minute wait to get in, then about 20 minutes till we got our food on a Sunday night. Nice wait staff and host.
You can't come to Chicago and not experience deep dish.  Our server recommended sticking with the classic fare, which we did and were so pleased .Classic delicious deep dish.

I want to preface this review by saying, just like barbecue, I know how subjective pizza is. When at home, I never eat pizza out because I cook them on my Kamado with home made crust and sauce. They are very good.

That being said, I was with a group in town for a conference and we wanted deep dish. We ordered a medium Malnati's Special plus we created our own combo pizza and we ordered their own house salad.

Let me start with the salad. My co-worker and I never qualify anything as the best. If it's up there it is always the second best! (Back story below) Well this salad was the second best salad I've had. It was very good and would recommend it.

Now the pizzas. First off, they were great! The butter crust was also second best crust ever. The sauce and sausage were sausage were great.

The combo was our own creation and wasn't quite as good but again, our own creation.

We went for lunch, sat our group of 6 quickly, and actually the pizzas were quick for deep dish. They do take at least 30 to cook so make sure you have time to wait.

Two mediums served 6 petite challenges dudes with a slice left over.

The staff and service was great.

I highly recommend this place.

2nd best back story:
I travel all the time for work. I had met my coworker at a location to do some audits, etc. Anyway, we were listening to some 90's grunge and he said, dude this is the second best song ever. To which I responded, so you have a 1st and a 3rd best song. He responded with a list. I said, there's no way I could narrow any music down to a top ten list, especially 80's music. No you know my age range. Yup, "gen z."  So I have teased him ever since naming coffee shops, songs, restaurants, or fishing spots at the second best when they are top of any lists of favorites.

Took a trip to Lou Malnati's for my first deep dish experience in Chicago. My friend and I were seated right away, even though it was busy and the waiter was super attentive. We ordered the house salad to start and the classic Chicago deep dish pizza to share. The salad came out quickly and was pretty good. Nothing special, a very typical Italian restaurant salad. We got the creamy lemon garlic dressing over top though, and that was super delicious.

The pizza came out a little bit after, (the deep dish takes 30 minutes to cook, which they tell you when you order it). The waiter cuts and serves the pizza for you at the table which is fun added touch to the whole experience.

As for the pizza itself, I was a big lover of the marina sauce. It had just the right amount of sweetness and acidity, with larger chunks of tomato that cut through the fat of the cheese. I was not a huge fan of the sausage, there was simply too much of it on the pizza and it became overwhelming. The crust also was nothing special. Overall it was yummy pizza, but nothing life changing.

Super nice restaurant in a really cute part of town, I would go back. I'm giving it three stars, however, for a few reasons. It was a little over meaty and cheesy, and overall I just believe pizza should not be eaten with a knife and fork. Goes against everything I love about eating pizza. Good experience though!

Since I was in Chicago, I had to try the deep dish pizza. Believe it or not, some girl gave us a free pizza at the music festival going on! It was absolutely delicious and the tomato sauce and cheese had great flavor. The crust wasn't too overpowering, but had the perfect crunch. If you're looking for a good deep dish, here's the place to go!

This place is a solid 4.5. Service is a bit slow despite pre-ordering your pizza. The clam chowder was DELICIOUS; creamy and lots of clams. The calamari was good too, crunch batter, perfectly salted. We ordered the Lou's deep dish. My husband and I shared the small and it was more than enough. We had left overs. My daughter ordered the cheese thin crust, it was good. Do yourself a favor: order the ranch dressing. It's homemade and AMAZING!!! Our hotel gave us a free dessert appetizer so we got the cookie; so good!!!
Worst "sauce"! You cant call canned tomatoes pizza sauce and get away with it. Sorry but ive tried Lou's over and over many times but the sauce is what kills it for me every time.

I ordered the Lou's Style Pizza which was amazingly delicious..the only problem is that whoever added the tomatoes put a couple of butt pieces of the tomato in which the core on the top was evident..and it was several pieces like this...pricey pizza should have quality tomatoes??????!!!!!

Also the crust was burned around some of the pizza......bummer!

The salad and salad dressing were delicious....

We arrived here expecting authentic deep dish pizza.  We got pizza in a deep dish, but it was not what one would expect for "Chicago-style" deep dish.  Thinner than the others and taste just didn't make our bellies happy!  Sorry Lou.

I've had many a Chicago pizza in my lifetime and I do declare that this one it the best I've ever had.
It's all about that sausage patty at the bottom baby! It's really delicious, not too overpowering, it's just in every bite and it is truly delicious.
Everything here just blends in perfectly man. No ingredient is greater than another, it's like a math equation of perfection, just the right amount of everything....perfect ratio if you will.

TOURISTS - If you could only pick one pizza joint, select this one, you will be pleased. The prices, by the way, are very good for the quality of the product, which is excellent.

Service - Excellent and beyond.
Atmosphere - same
Food - Beyond!

Tips - The place gets busy, but they do a damn good job of seating you fast. They do a pre-order, which is a really smart concept. You order the food as you wait for a table to open. Boom - you're eating 10 minutes or less when you sit down. Love it, Love it!

Tip 2 - Order a larger size pie. Servings are great, but the pizza is soooooooooo good, you'll want some more to eat and than leftovers. A++

I was recommended to go here from a friend. He said it was his favorite pizza in Chicago. They do pizza very differently. The cheese almost felt like a cheese stick in terms of consistency. It made for a very unique experience. The pizza was great and the service was fantastic. They really have a great system to get people in and ordered.

Would definitely recommend for pizza in Chicago.

pics.caption: The cheese is done so differently. Definitely knife and fork pizza

review.des:
I felt disappointed to say that prior to coming here, I believed that I've had authentic deep dish before.

AMAZING.

Just try it. It's definitely a must visit if you're in Chicago.

Lou Malnati's is definitely the place to go if you're looking for A Chicago deep dish pizza . We tried their most popular pizza, the classic (sausage pizza) & the Lou (a veggie pizza).
The sausage pizza was pretty gross after the first bite. It has a thick layer of sausage on the pizza and has way too much meat for any normal human to consume with out gagging. I really could not handle it.

The Lou was delicious. Mushroom, spinach, and tomato pizza. The tomatoes did make the pizza a bit soggy but still delicious.

Overall, I'm a thin crust type of gal but Lou Malnati's definitely serves decent deep dish pizzas. *Line can get pretty crazy so try the bar*

Came here on Sunday lunch time got seated right away. They usually have long wait 45mins-1hr.
Of course got the famous Chicago pizza deep dish. Got two pizza: The "Lou" and The Malnati Chicago classic, it's ridiculously good. The crust is amazing! *mouth watering*
Calamari are huge and great!
Sad part they sold out goose beer. But it's all good in the hood, there's always next time!
Overall experience is great food and service!

The OG! Sausage, pickled veggies, lots of cheese, and traditional marinara, all in (not on) their signature "buttercrust." Way less bread than I'd ever imagined, which is a good thing in my opinion. So good!

Sports-themed bar atmosphere (although I didn't explore the entire restaurant). David B. at the bar and the rest of the staff were very friendly and attentive.
This is hands down the best deep dish pizza in all of Chicago!!! We have tried all of the usual recommendations and this place delivers the best food every time we go there.

If you are in chicago and wana have best deep dish pizza, this is famous but not really worth of hype, waiting an hour is fine but understandable, we ordered the classic well done but turned out very hard bread crust, too much of marinana sauce and tomatoes which overpowered the rest of the veggies or meat ( too tangy ), cheese was ordinary, chicken turkey sausage was good... but the soul of pizza which was the pizza sauce , it was let down.. hence scoring it 2 of 5..

First try of Chicago Style pizza .. since moving here.  We are afraid trying something new.    We had the bruschetta ..  its amazing .  The pizza was even better!   The preparation took 45 min.  The wait was worth it!   The crust is buttery yet crispy.  The service was amazing , the wait staff and waiter was there when needed but not too much..   Plan for wait if you get there too late in the day.

If you're a pizza fan, like me; THIS IS THE PLACE FOR YOU!

A true Chicago staple. Ordered something simple; the pepperoni deep dish. It did not disappoint. The wait to be seated can be a drag, but that goes hand in hand with the business popularity. Recommended and will return!

Ah-mazing pizza! I had never had Chicago style deep dish pizza before and now I only want to eat it. It's so delicious and good. This location is insanely busy. We arrived after 8pm and were told it would be a 90 minute wait. It turned out to only be a 60 minute wait and they do get you to preorder your pizza so it arrives at your table shortly after you are seated, but it would be good to be able to order some starters to eat while you wait.

Despite the crazy wait I can't wait to be able to eat here again next time I'm in Chicago!

Tourist trap. Good service, terrible pizza. Confused about the hype. Ingredients did not taste fresh.
Just such an underwhelming experience.

so yeah im a tourist, and i needed to go to the touristy places to get what chicago is known for. the deep dish. and since this place had thousands of reviews, it was the place i picked. typical, i know haha. but yeah it was good. duh

we started with a lunch special of chicken alfredo. it was okay, good enough for kids. and just a sample of that taste if you need to get rid of that craving like i did.

me and my friend ordered a small. came with 4 slices, we added jalapenos and it was really good! we have a gino's in texas and we ordered one and im sure its frozen thats why it takes so long. but still. it wasnt as good as lou's, idk if its frozen but it was really good very different from what i had at gino's. i wanted to eat it with my hands. i could wait for the cutting hahaha. thats how good it was. we were only able to finish the 2 slices, and the pasta, so we were left with 2 slices, that we took home to texas and ate right when we got home. it was still good! i put it in the oven for about 40 min and it wasnt as hot as it was when served, so i can def see why it takes 45min for a pizza to come out. its a really big pie.

our server was really nice and helpful, he was tending the bar and to us and other tables bigger than us. we never felt forgotten. id def come here again for a slice.

I'm more of a New York style pizza girl but this deep dish pizza was incredibly tasty and my husband still dreams about it! We loved the Italian sausage and the staff was super friendly. It was a long wait so don't go starving but we put our name on the waitlist and put our order in ahead so the pizza was ready a few minutes after our table was ready. Otherwise it's about 45 minutes of a wait from when you order the pizza. The ambience was lively and we enjoyed a beer as we waited for the table.

Lou Malnati's... it's a Chicago Staple. It's an original. It's BUSY. But is it worth it? The answer's not so simple. I came here during my first time in Chicago (during which I tried just about every deep dish spot I could get to). I never planned on going to Lou Malnati's, particularly because of its mainstream vibe and long lines-- still, I was forced into it by a friend. Here's my experience:

You walk into Lou's knowing it's going to be busy-- add to that the standard 45 minute wait for a deep dish and you've got quite the wait. Use that wait to order appetizers! The atmosphere here is great; there's always a crowd and while it gets VERY packed, it keeps things entertaining. The service is great as well and servers manage to be extremely attentive and friendly (a recurring theme in Chicago). The food here is good-- you won't be disappointed. But the deep dish left me wanting for more. This was my first authentic deep dish in Chicago and I couldn't help but feel that the spot was way overhyped. So I went to Pequod's (see my review on their page) and my expectations were blown out of the water. Still, Lou Malnati's has decent pizza and food/drinks-- you won't be let down that easily.

I liked:
Mozzarella Sticks - A classic appetizer, Lou Malnati's did not mess these up.

I disliked:
Deep Dish - It wasn't bad by any means, but the overall taste and quality of the ingredients simply didn't match up with smaller, lesser-known competitors.

My Uber driver recommended this place for deep dish pizza. We ordered the small deep dish pepperoni pizza which is good for 2 people. It was delicious and I was full! If you are in Chicago this is a must try place. You will need to pre-order the pizza as it takes up to an hour.

Both times I've been to Chicago I've stopped at Lou Malnati's.. Both times I was glad I did. This time, me and 5 friends shared an order of bruschetta and 2 medium deep dish pizzas..The Chicago Classic and the Lou. The bruschetta was so good and perfect for holding us over for 30ish minutes while we waited for our pizza. The pizza... OMG. So hearty. So cheesy. So amazing. I would recommend Lou's to anyone looking for some good deep dish!!

pics.caption: A slice of the Malnati Chicago Classic.. So good!!

review.des:
I heard mixed reviews about Lou Malnati's but decided to give it a shot anyways. One of the must-eats for a first timer's trip to Chicago is deep dish pizza. I don't regret choosing Lou Malnati's for that at all.

Yeah, there will probably be a wait. It's the famous Lou Malnati's. But that's okay because each pizza takes 40 minutes to cook, anyways. While you wait, you can preorder your pizza and they will text you when your table is ready.

What makes their pizzas good is the crust. BUTTERY. GOODNESS. You MUST get the Malnati Chicago Classic for the buttery crust - you can get it with sausage or pepperoni. The crust is a game changer. The tomato sauce was a bit on the tart side for my taste but it didn't bug me too much. Perfect amount of cheese. Decent amount of sausage. Also the Malnati salad was a good appetizer to get while waiting for your pizza to finish baking. It's light and refreshing and the sweet vinaigrette is the icing on top.

By no means did Lou Malnati's convert me into a deep dish lover. I am still a thin-crust lover through and through. But overall this was one of my top meals in Chicago.

pics.caption: 2 pieces left - the small is enough to feed 2!

review.des: It was a bit of a wait which I'm used to, BUT WELL WORTH IT! After much discussion in our group about which deep dish to try, Lou's or Giordano's, we settled on Lou's. So so so happy we did. This is a must have! And dont skip a salad with the sweet vinaigrette!
I was extremely underwhelmed. I didn't think the pizza was all that great. Plus it took them about 2 hours to make 3 pizzas. I understand that they were busy, but that's just ridiculous.

We flew in late and my gf's sister had bought this to go for us to have as a late night snack when we got there.  It was reheated and was still delicious!  Crust wast buttery crispy, cheese was melted, and sausage was warm.  This was like an upside down type. Of pizza where the sauce was on top.  Flavor combination was prefect for the crust. I'd come back to try other pies.

Traditional Chicago style deep dish pizza is a must stop in the wi day city.  

The best pizza crust I ever had and the classic pie there Has chunky plum tomatoes and a generous helping of cheese and crumbled sausage.

The personal pizza looks small at first glance but it is plenty for sure.

Don't expect east coast thin crust pizza here. Eat the local style and appreciate the differences.  

Each pizza if made from scratch so it's a 30 minute wait from when you order. Longer if it's busy.

Great pizza.

Great service! Even though two medium pizzas were ordered for just two people dining in, our server didn't miss a beat and understood that we wanted to try a little of both and take home the rest. We chose the classic and lou, the latter being vegetarian. Both were good, but I, the carnivore, preferred the flavor profile of the lou more.

On top of that, these pizzas do take time to make so you might want to consider an appetizer to hold you over. We saw people supplement with salads to balance out the heaviness of the pizza.

One note, the pizza does travel pretty well and I think that's credit to our server. She took the time to box things up table side and gave us plates, utensils and packets of crushed red pepper and cheese.
The Lou will always be my fav pizza in Chicago but the service continues to be erratic. If you're not in a hurry and don't mind waiting for a drink refill it's still a good place for pizza

I had hear good things about Lou Malnati's and even though I had DDP the night before, I didn't think I could leave Chicago without trying it here.  

Perhaps my high expectations didn't help, but I was a little underwhelmed.  I had the personal Malnati classic (with lean sausage), and while the crust was as good as other reviews said, the pizza itself was just OK.  From the presentation, to taste (the sausage was a little bland and there was hardly any cheese or sauce), I was just expecting more.  I truly do believe that if I had gone with a group and ordered a larger pizza (baked and served in the skillet), I may have added a star.  On the bright side, their house salad with the creamy garlic dressing was very tasty, and service was good.

I liked the pizza here, esp w/ the buttery crust. The particular location is very neat to explore and is much bigger than you would expect from outside. The wait wasn't too long and is well organized. Staff was great. Im sure you can find better pizza elsewhere but it would never end with a  search. If you have a better place hey send me a message and let me know! Everyone comes here for the deep dish, and personally, I think it doesn't disappoint. I think its a good place to try and I would definitely come back for another round. Just a little turned off by the price which drops a star but otherwise a great pizza joint IMO.

So everyone says this is the best place for deep dish and it was. Omg i am dying to go back! It really was fresh and tasted amazing. Also tried the minestrone soup and that was delicious as well, only thing that keeps the five Star was a our waitress wasn't so pleasant.

Lou Malnati's Pizzeria did not disappoint! This pizza was amazing! I got "The Lou" personal pan pizza. The pricing was decent ($10.25 + $1.10 for the pepperoni I added). The flavors were poppin and this is the crust you WANT to eat! You can even add additional seasonings to the crust ($.75 extra). Be prepared to wait about 30-40 minutes for your freshly made pizza. Don't worry about the time because you will want to try out the soup, salad, or other appetizers. The salads are shareable and worth a try. I loved the pizza so much that I decided to try the dessert cookie pizza! No complaints! Get the bigger portion ($7.25)...you won't regret it! The cookie is cooked to gooey perfection and topped with vanilla bean ice cream. This was the perfect way to start off my Chicago adventure!

The 40 minute wait (felt like less honestly) for this deep dish "The Lou" pizza was SO WORTH IT! Incredibly delicious, well-cooked, fresh ingredients. We also had calamari for an appetizer and it was also spectacular. I have to come back next time I am in town. Beautiful inside, too.

I had my first deep dish pizza here and I can say I was not at all disappointed. It was the beginning of my new love for deep dish pizza. It was quite the magical moment but I'll spare you the details of how it went down. The personal size pizza is perfect, I was skeptical of the size but it was just right. I am a huge crust fan so, I loved the pizza just that much more because of their thick and buttery crust. Great pizza and if I actually lived in Chicago I would find myself coming back often. Maybe it's better for my health that I live a couple thousand miles away.

I was super excited about Lou's since a lot of friends told me it was the place go to. Probably the location that I went to really just had an off day, but it was nothing of what I was expecting. There just wasn't enough tomato sauce on this pizza to call it a deep dish. Could the fault be mine because we ordered two pizzas that serves one and not a big pie?

Went just before the restaurant opened at 11 am on a Sunday, managed to snag a seat outside. Felt some neglect because we were outside. Had to run inside to get the attention of a waitress for an order, maybe it was just too early to expect a full operating restaurant. Not too many big groups filled it during the course of our dine in.
My favorite pizza. Buttery crispy crust. Great cheese and flavor. Always nice decor and friendly service!

I had many different Chicago style pizza before this one. And this is the second time having Lou Malnati. From my food tour I've learned that the executive of this pizzeria hand picks their tomatoes every year from Europe. Pretty impressive on how much thought goes into make a perfect pizza. The crust was very crunchy for my taste, but they do season them with butter and other ingredients. We had cheese pizza, which it still had a lot of flavor. When you visit, I would recommend ordering the food over the phone and come eat at the restaurant. it will take 40-45 mins to have the pizza made. There are two floors on this location and they do have an elevator.

The BEST deep dish pizza in Chicago!
When you go, no matter what day, there may be quite a wait. It. Is. Worth it. The staff is friendly and the founders are exceptional!
The leadership in this company really shines through every level, from the founders to the servers. The cheesy spinach bread is always a go to appetizer for me. No matter what you'll probably have leftovers, so go big!

We arrived at 4:45 and got in the que. We then pre ordered large classic pizza. We were seated at 6:15 and were told it would be another 20min. Our pizza arrived at 6:45! So be prepared to wait and wait and wait. I think their preorder is a scam. But what do I know. Still sitting here waiting on our dessert that we ordered when we sat down. I believe without their pre order scam no one would put up with these kinds of wait times. Pizza was good but I have a better at home. Oh and btw we were just told they forgot our pizza and we would have to wait another 15mins if we wanted one. So much for my husband birthday "cake"! They did give us a discount on our check because of the cookie problem but come on we ordered it when we first sat down at our table.

***THIS IS THE SPOT FOR CHICAGO STYLE PIZZZAA!!!!***

Coming to Chicago, you think, "well damn, I sure would love to try an authentic deep dish right?"

This is theeeee spot to go my Yelp friends! Yes, Yes, Yessss! It gets mighty crowded, so do be wary of a lil wait time. But it is worth it, I promise you!
