I still think pizza is pizza, but Lou Malnati's will probably be the best you've ever had :)

We had lunch today at Lou Malnati pizzeria . I don't understand how the restaurant has such a good reputation . The three different pizzas we ordered had the same taste . Where is the culinary touch ? They were so heavy, all we can taste is butter. We had to wait 40 minutes to get the order . So deceived :( Never again .

When I pictured a Chicago deep dish pizza, this place delivered. A bustling hole in the wall with a long wait. An awesome feature of this restaurant is that you order your pizza before you sit down. This way, they have more tables available and you don't have to wait very long to finally taste some deep dish.
The staff was really friendly and made sure our drinks were full and we had what we needed on the table.
Now to the important stuff: the pizza. It came out hot and the person sliced and played it at the table. The crust was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. But the real winner was the sauce. The tomatoes were sweet and so flavorful. It is not something I will forget. There was plenty of cheese but not so much that you couldn't take a bit without an extendo arm.
Try and go for lunch to miss the dinner rush!

As a Chicago deep dish virgin, this was my first taste of an authentic pie.  It was one of the highlights of our trip! This place was amazing, the charm of the inside sets the mood, and the pizza just brings it home. It was SO amazing. I was pumped when I saw that we can actually ordered them online to be shipped home. It has taken my online shopping problem to a whole new level, haha.

Yum yum yum yum yum!!! I have to preface this by saying I'm not a fan of lots and lots of toppings on a pizza and I've never really had deep dish before - true deep dish but when in Chicago, you HAVE to try it and I was glad I did. Wow!  The pizza came out on a pie pan and they cut and serve you the first slice and I thought, the bottom of this crust must be so soggy cause look at all that liquid and grease but boy was I wrong.  Chicago deep dish is something else, especially here at Lou Malnati's.  The crust was crispy - we tried both the normal and the butter crust and couldn't really tell a difference.  The toppings were fantastic, especially when hot before the cheese congeals.  I love love loved the Malnati Chicago Classic - just the flavors of the cheese and meat was fantastic.  We also had to try the "Lou" while were were here and it was a little more soggy cause of the mushrooms and tomatoes and peppers but still good.  This was the vegetarian option and as good as it was, it couldn't beat the Malnati classic.  We ordered two smalls so we could try them both and it was more than enough for the 2 of us.  These babies are filling - so if they look small, it is very very deceiving.

I like that they pre-take your order and then seat you as seating becomes available and take your drinks and appetizer order then.  The pizza does take awhile to make so this shortens the wait a bit.  The line could be long but it was worth the wait - come on off times, around 3pm between lunch and dinner for a little shorter wait or during the week for no wait at all.  The restaurant was very classic Italian decor and style.  I'm drooling just writing this review and want to fly back to Chicago just for Lou Malnati's!!!

Food was tasty, but unsure what the hype is about. We waited about 1hr 15 min when we put our name in at 7:15. Tip would be to get there a wee early and put your name down and then you can go walk around Chicago and check on the website to see where you are in line.

So for the deep dish pizza I was expecting bounds of flavor and melted cheese oozing as you take a bite into it. Instead -  it did have good flavor but the cheese seemed to had already congealed quickly since when we took a bite, it was like taking  a bite out of a solid piece of cheese. I also like sauce .. and this wasn't very saucy. Now I realize it's so thick due to the thickness of the dough/bread and the slab of cheese.

Perhaps I just had a different expectation of a deep dish.

We were told to come here for the quintessential Chicago Deep Dish Pizza experience. And as guy who's pretty picky about pizza, I can tell you they delivered beyond my expectations.

Let's begin with the wait staff. Our waitress was friendly and professional. She was on our drinks with  gusto. Her recommendations were spot on. Definitely an exceptional experience.

We ordered both the mozzarella cheese sticks and a bowl of the minestrone soup. The sticks were pretty standard. Nothing to complain about. But the minestrone soup was out of this world. Easily the best I've ever had by miles. It says on the menu it takes two days to prepare. I can see why. Order this. You won't regret it.

Onward to the main course: the deep dish pizza. We ordered the Malnati Chicago Classic with their trademark Butter Crust. It comes with sausage and extra cheese by default. We added mushrooms and pepperoni.

First thing you need to know: the wait is a little long. Thirty to forty five minutes is standard. This is because they're making your pizza fresh, and that takes time. The wait staff is up front about this. It's no surprise. But if you're in a hurry, it's something you need to know.

That said, it's worth the wait. The pizza is dense with its ingredients. Everything is fresh and delicious. The sauce is savory with a hint of sweetness. The butter crust maintains its flavor and crunch. It's everything you'll ever want in a deep dish pizza.

They also make solid Bloody Marys. A little spicy by default, which I like. It's light on the garnishes, but classic Bloody Mary's usually are.

Lastly, price. It's pretty fair. With two Bloody Mary's, the soup, the cheese sticks, and the pizza, the price came to $40.00 before tip.

If you haven't been here, do yourself a favor and go. If you have, I shouldn't have to tell you to go back. I'm sure you already have.

Me and my friend decided to come here since we heard of great things about the deep dish pizza!

When we first got there , there was a line to put your name down ,which went by pretty fast. We got seated in 10 minutes.

We decided to get a regular ceaser salad to share and and small (serving 2) Lou deep dish pizza to share as well. It was delicious

Expect to have time to eat here. It took us about 30 minutes to be seated also an additional 30 minutes for our deep dish to come out. My friend and I did preorder our dish.

Let me tell you, I'm not a fan of pizza. The deep dish is absolutely delicious, well worth the wait. Their house salad is amazing too, loved the dressing!

Our waiter staff Marko is so amazing! Loved him! He's so friendly! That goes along way!

Save room for their chocolate dessert! It's so delicious!

Awesome Chicago style pizza!!! I had the pequod and Lou back to back within the two days on my Chicago trip and comparing the two pizzeria, Lou is lighter in taste, not as greasy. I wouldn't necessarily say one is better than the other, more so that they are cater to two different customer group. If you want a crunchier crust and not as heavy in taste, you would like Lou's pizza. Make sure tho to get their buttercrust, that's what they are famous for.

I started eating their pizza in 2006 at their downtown Naperville location. I love it! It tops Ginos East hands down which use to be my favorite. The south Loop location is ALWAYS crowded, so I use the App and order to go sometimes.

We were fortunate enough to stay a hotel within walking distance from Lou Malnati's.  So we checked in and put our luggage and ran over to get our first meal in Chicago (which had to be a Chicago deep dish).  We went at an off hour, so it just a short wait for a table.  While waiting, we pre-ordered our pizza to save time.  
This was our preferred touristy pizza place (compared to the other touristy pizza place that rhymes with "too much cheesedanos").  The crust was buttery, there was the right amount of cheese on top, and the sauce tasted really fresh.  We ate in the late afternoon, so we were looking for a stopgap between landing in Chicago and dinner, but it's as a great fill for us, and we wish we had more time to eat another meal here.

Lou Malnati's is now my favorite deep dish pizza place. I used to think it was Gino's East, but I was so wrong. We came to Lou's on a Friday afternoon and sat outside on their patio. My husband and I both had drinks and ended up splitting one of Lou's pepperoni deep dish pizzas and a ceasar salad. The combo was perfect and it was just the right amount of food portions for each of us.

#1 reason why I love Lou's versus Gino's? The crust. Lou's crust is cooked perfectly, unlike Gino's that takes away the flavor of the pizza with their cornbread style crust. The pizza is also extremely flavorful and the service there is great. Plus, they have more than one location in Chicago, which I love.

If you want real, authentic, delicious deep dish pizza, go to Lou Malnati's!

Solid pizza. Did carry-out and the food was ready when promised and hot. Quality was solid, but wasn't blown away. May just be my bias towards thin crust pizza though. Good value at ~$15 for a pie for 2.

I had to put salt on my pizza.

The service was impressive-- they CHURN people in and out of here. I found the food to be extremely bland and disappointing.

As an out of towner, this was my favorite deep dish in Chicago. I visited Chicago from Boston with practically the soul purpose of eating deep dish pizza. I was in pizza heaven at Lou Malnati's. I ordered the vegetable pizza. The crust was incredible & the stood out because they added cheddar cheese. This is definitely a place worth visiting.

Went expecting greatness but got mediocre. Malnati's salad was great, but the deep dish did nothing special for me. I've had better in Iowa City believe it or not. Not busy when we went, but it took the server about 12 minutes to greet us, then another 12 for beer. Only six or so tables sat at the time. Seemed like they are living on reputation and not trying that hard.

Sooo. Apparently I'm a NYC pizza girl. I did not care for the thick crust - was mushy. The flavor was bland.  We ordered the personal Chicago style and a small thin. Both went virtually uneaten- even after waiting about 2 hours.

The bar tender was rude. Hostess was friendly but they are very busy and she had to keep things moving.

I know pizza style is a preference- so if you like deep dish you may love this place.

Not going to lie I was pretty excited to try this famed pizza spot, however I left really disappointed. Honestly it tasted like pizza hut..the one inside the Target stores that are microwaved. No wonder why the crime is so high in this city. Truly overrated, I would skip and go to pequods (which is way better in most ppls opinions)

We ordered the lous original pie and the  buttercrust was decent but the rest of the crust was dry and the toppings were nothing special. I really wanted to like this place, but it's just another tourist trap along with giordanos and unos.
WOW is all I can say about the pizza.  I actually came here twice during my trip to Chicago.  Be sure you get there early or plan on waiting. Make sure that you get the butter crust pizza!

Chicago is synonymous with good pizza. Lou Malnatti's is easily in the top 5 of anyone who's in the know's deep dish pizza spots. Regardless of the crust you pick (Buttercrust is a must for first-timers), you can't lose with their fresh ingredients and seasoning mixes. Gluten-free? No worries... grab a "crustless" and enjoy.

Lou Malnatti's is a must for visitors and new residents, and a standard-setter and sure bet go-to for native Chicagoans. One of the best!

Delicious but be ready to wait! They say explicitly on their menu that pizzas take 30-45 minutes and it's true. It was delicious and loved that thick crust. We went half and half on a small (lous and half vegetarian) and it was plenty for two people. Service is fast and friendly. I would come back to get this again - can't speak to what the rest of the menu is like though.

When my friends found out I was going to Chicago for my annual trip for a convention they told me I had to try this place. Everyone talks about deep dish pizza and although I do have acid reflex and deep dish pizza is acid reflex on a plate, I decided to give it a try.

I honestly feel like the pizza is overly hyped and I was way too excited to try it and I was slightly disappointed. I blame the hype. Although the pizza was delicious, it wasn't as amazing as I would've hoped.

I loved the vibe which is why I gave place four stars! It was snowing outside and it had a very "Friends TV show"type of feel if catch my drift.

The staff is very friendly and you are allowed to take frozen pizzas to go. It is limited to only cheese and pepperoni from what I was told and I oddly had some friends who wanted me to bring frozen pizzas to LA. Since I'm such an amazing friend I did put it in my luggage the same day. I wonder how it tasted, LOL!

Overall, food is 3/5 and the environment is a 5/5!

I highly recommend just going for the hype honestly!

pics.caption: If you have acid reflex I highly recommend taking acid blockers before eating here

review.des: We decided to try a lesser known place(for out of towners)for deep dish.  The place has an amazing feel to it. You could tell it was a favorite for the neighborhood folks.   I understand it is a pizza/Italian place, but the appetizer menu didn't offer much outside of bread-based dishes.  Tried the calamari. It was a pretty heavy breading, but cooked perfectly.  The bloody was a little sweet, so make sure to spice it up with something.  The pizza was average.  The crust was a little thin and a little dry.  I'd still come back to this place for drinks and to watch a game. It was peaceful even during the lunch rush.

pics.caption: Shared a small Sausage Deep Dish Pizza. It wasn't as deep as I expected, but decent flavor. Crust was a little dry.
Don't let the menu fool you. The Calamari Fritti was fried perfectly, but not lightly breaded as the menu description.
Bloody Mary was a little sugary, but it made for a decent palate cleanser after the Calamari Fritti.

review.des:
The guide on a boat tour said this place was his favorite. My companions wanted to try Chicago pizza. So, we headed over. We were given a 25 minute wait, which was to be expected. They tell you to order your pizza ahead of time. My co-diners ordered. I didn't want pizza and was told to order when we sat down.

My pasta and a salad we ordered at the table came out about ten minutes before the pizza showed up. We should have known something was up when a later seated table got their pizza before ours did.

When the pizza showed up, it was cold. My companions ate it, thinking that's the normal temperature. But, then they noticed everyone else's was hot.  

After bringing it to the waiter's attention, they didn't charge us for it. But, it's a mystery why our lone table got cold pizza.

4 stars because it didn't taste exactly like what I expected :( but I'll try others first before I can judge this one.

Pros:
- one of the most famous deep dish
- order when you are in line = short wait time after you get seated
- good drink menu
- big big portion - i.e. Salad
- after you put your name down, you can walk around till they text you

Cons:
- didn't meet my expectation (and it could be my fault for imagining how good it is before I get to try others and compare their pizza). From all the pictures on yelp, pizza looks super gooey, cheesy, and warm. However, mine was not gooey (cheese were just solid) and not warm. I'm not sure, but when I looked at others...theirs don't look that gooey either. So is it not supposed to be gooey or today was too busy due to Chicago marathon?

Tips:
DO NOR forget to order when you are in line (once you made your decision)

I had the pleasure of dining here awhile back and am so glad I did!! My first trip to Chicago wasn't complete without a visit here.  It is definitely better than I'd heard! Our waiter was phenomenal!
From the bread,  the pizza and the atmosphere,  simply great!
That crust is like Crack,  you just can't get enough! We had just the basic pepperoni which was delicious.  I cannot wait to go back!

I have been to several places in Chicago for deep dish pizza, including the original Unos long before it became a franchise/chain.

Sadly, these guys disappointed me. It was billed as "the best deep dish in Chicago" by some local friends and while it was OK, it was far from great

For starters, about the only thing deep about was the pan it was baked in. It was roughly half an inch thick. Second, it lacked depth of flavor. No hint of garlic, the sauce was generic and the cheese was uninspiring.

Gino's may be consider another chain that also sells frozen pizza, but I personally think it is ten times better.

Pizza was great again but the time to get served is ridiculous! We even put our order in when we had a 45 min wait and we put in our order while we waited and we sat down expecting our meal to be ready since we waited 45 min and the pizza took 40 min to make. Only to find out that they only Do a half bake until you are seated and then they put back into finish. Only to find out that it took another 40 minutes to get the pizza. Needless to say if you decide to eat here plan on spending all night.

We ordered a small deep dish, added the buttery crust option, and cooked it the extra 5 minutes. The toppings were pepperoni, spinach, and sausage. They didn't disappoint, the crust was crunchy, the toppings and flavor were on point!

We also got an order of the buffalo wings, they were cooked perfectly as well, good flavor on the buffalo sauce.

We ordered the appetizer which includes; fried zucchini, fried Mac n cheese balls, fried mushrooms, and fried mozzarella sticks. Wow, all of these were nothing short of amazing, their sauce tastes home made and is a great compliment to the four.

We ordered those in to our hotel. They recommend that you order it uncut so it keeps all the flavor, we ordered it uncut cause we didn't have a way to cut it at our hotel room. Be sure when ordering, you let them know what condiments you want, silverware, and how many plates. They included more than what we needed which was appreciated.

Two thumbs up for this place!

Great deep dish. Both the Malnati and Caesar salads were fantastic! We had the Lou and Classic pizzas - both were very good but the classic was my favorite. The staff was very friendly and the decor is pretty cool. I'll be back!

The pizza was okay...
Got a large deep dish with onions basil, roma tomatoes and green peppers. The pizza to me lacked seasoning but the crust was really good. The customer service was great. B- for you.

This is a perfect location.  My friends and me had the chance to have pizza here, and it is consistent and great, just like your other locations!
I can mention that it's a place that has loyal clients which are satisfied of quality and professionalism.

Lou Malnati's is my favorite touristy deep dish pizza in Chicago. If I have friends coming into town, this is usually the location that I take them to.
I usually order the Malnati's Chicago classic, which has a variety of meats, and I find to be the most satisfying.
I think I'm just not the biggest deep dish fan. It tastes good, and Lou's is known for its butter crust, which I like. However, I definitely think there is better pizza in the world. One thing I also dislike is that the temperature of the pizza is not hot enough when it comes out. I think the cheese should be very stringy, but wen you actually cut into it, it's not that stringy, and not as satisfying.
As for serving size, the suggested serving size, it definitely assumes you are a hungry person and are not eating anything else. So order with caution. I usually have leftovers.
If you want to come here during the summer at a normal dinner time, good luck having to wait less than an hour. You put your name in their system and then they text you when your table is ready. While you're waiting, you can order your pizza beforehand, because they take a while to make, and have it come quicker to your table. So usually when you get to your table, you don't have to wait too long to eat, but then it makes it feel like a factory, you sit, you eat, you get out. It's definitely not my favorite restaurant environment.
You can always order carry out, if you don't want to wait in the store.
One last thing that I find annoying is that Lou Malnati's has locations outside of Chicago, namely where I'm from in Phoenix, AZ, which kind of diminishes the specialness of eating at Lou's in Chicago, especially when almost all of my visiting friends are from Chicago.

If you're here from out of town, sure go here, but be prepared for a wait. Definitely don't go to other large deep dish chains; they are subpar. I only take friends from out of town here, and never come here when I'm not with them.

pics.caption: A slice of a medium Lou's classec

review.des: Lou Malnati's pizza is much cheesier, and ingredients meld together, more so than Giordano's. I got the Lou personal  and I definitely enjoyed the flavors on this. Good pizza, but not amazingly great or mindblowing, as I thought I would get with a traditional Chicago deep dish

So the crust is amazing but can we talk about the crust less pizza?!!?!?? Yes!! Yes!! Yes!!! Crust less pizza!!!! Sausage replaces the dough. It's quite possibly the best thing ever created.
It's so amazing and delicious. No crust a great low carb option and my favorite go to!! It's one of those things that you eat and it literally ruins all other pizza for you! Because it is that damn good!!!
Enjoy!!!!

The wait here is ridiculous. At 9:30, we waited an hour and a half. We even pre-ordered our pizzas when we checked in, because we were told it would be cooking and ready soon after we got our table. When we finally got a table, it took forever for a server to take our drink order. Then came back 40 minutes later with our pizza. We got a small deep dish and small thin crust pepperoni. It was our first time eating deep dish, and it was honestly disgusting. Nothing is cohesive. Water runs out when you cut into it. The cheese almost chokes you it's so thick. Not a fan. But the thin crust was the saving grace. It was very good! It was a little thicker than a thin crust you might get at a chain like Pizza Hut or Domino's. And honestly, it may have only been "so good" because the deep dish was so gross. Don't think we'd ever come back.

Well, we hit up Lou Malnati's as our last meal in Chicago before heading home to Las Vegas. Of course, we wanted to partake of some of that famous Chicago-style deep-dish pizza. So, we hit up Lou's based on the heavy recommendation of our river tour guide. Not gonna lie, we were kind of disappointed, and we are not picky eaters. We had to wait about 40 minutes for our pizza to bake--totally normal for deep dish pizza, which is fine-- but it just wasn't the amazing pizza we were hoping for. It was just kind of, bleh. The salad we had as an appetizer was very much the same. So, we left kind of bummed. A Giordano's just opened up here in Vegas, so I'm looking forward to giving that a try. There are tons of other options for deep dish pizza in Chicago, so I'd probably try one of those before giving Lou Malnati's a shot.
Disgusting. Overhyped. Sorry Chicago. Never ever again. New York Pizza is way way way better !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

If there's a better deep dish in Chicago I'd be impressed. I'm a New York style pizza type, and was kind of reluctant to try Chicago style pizza. I've been so wrong!!!! I still prefer thin crust, but this place is excellent, surprisingly affordable  (15 for a pizza that feeds two) and it's delicious!!!

The wait for a table was about 20 minutes and our order took almost an hour! The place was packed. I would highly recommend to pre-order while you're waiting.

Top notch food! This place stands out from all the other pizza places in Chiago, it's one of my favorites! I love the deep dish, baked pizza a lot. Whenever I'm semi-close to the area, it's an always go to on my list. The wait can be a bit excessive at times, but again this is quality stuff so I think the wait is justified in my opinion. The people who work here are always smiling, cheerful. Good environment and great food!

Listen. This is the best pizza in Chicago. Nothing else even matters. Stop looking.
We always get the classic, add mushrooms and onions. Also the bruschetta for an appetizer. You won't regret it. We are moving away from Chicago in a few weeks, and Lou's is in our top 3 things we will miss about the city.

We arrived in Chicago later in the evening.  Our receptionist at the hotel recommended Lou Malnati's, and after reading the reviews on Yelp, and seeing that it was ranked #1, it was not a chore to walk 3 blocks to experience this "top ranked" pizzeria.  

The place was packed, and were told that it would be a 45 minute wait.  We were also told that we could pre-order our pizza and by the time our table was ready, our pizza would be also.   45 minutes later we get a table.  And wait.  And wait.  Another 30 minutes for our pizza.  The ambiance was crowded and loud.  We literally could not hear across the table.  So we thought, "ok, its gonna be worth it when the pizza gets here".  Wrong.

We ordered both a deep dish pepperoni and a deep dish veggie pizza.  

This might possibly be the worst pizza I've ever had.  Ranking right up there with a cheap, overcooked Totino's pizza i made in college.  

The crust of the pizza was thick and under-cooked.  Under-cooked?  They were making it for an hour and 15 minutes, right?  On the top were huge chunks of tomatoes that had no taste.  There was a little bit of cheese and some pepperonis.   I've had pizza all over the country.  And this is hands down the worst pizza I've had in a restaurant!   $57 dollars for 2 pizzas and 3 sodas.  Wow.  

My whole faith in Chicago pizza was ruined!  

The rest of the story................The last night in Chicago we thought we'd give "The City" another chance to redeem herself.  So we ate at Pizanos.  YES!  We found the pot at the end of the pizza rainbow!  Thick crust, thin crust, toasted ravioli!  The waitstaff was great too!  

How do I get Lou's out of the #1 spot?
A great pie every time!! Prepare to wait, though.... Order in advance before you get there.
Great deep dish pizza. Visited Chicago for the first time in years and had to find some pizza. Walking distance from the hotel. Good service appetizers and drinks.

We were visiting Chicago and had to try a deep dish pizza at least once!  it was between Lou Malnati's and Giordano's - by luck we went here.

They had verrrrrry long wait-times, but I did like that you could pre-order your pizzas while on the wait-list so that it would be prepared by the time you sat down.  I can understand a small eating space, but we ended up sitting right in the front area, right near where people were standing and waiting, and it was a bit off-putting that they would be leaning right near us with their elbows hanging over our table.

We ordered personal pizzas so we could try two varieties - The Classic, and The Lou.  To be honest, I've only known NY pizza, and I was not sure what we'd be getting into.  I was expecting something very heavy and stuffed with cheese.  I also normally don't like red pizzas (I love a good white, veggie) because I find them overwhelmingly tomato-y, but these were lovely - very light, you could taste the fresh tomato (but it wasn't too much), and the portions were just right.  For the Classic - I'm not usually a fan of sausage either since usually it's an overpowering flavor, but this was very subtle and worked nicely.

I was hoping to try their cookie pizza dessert, but we were just bordering on full, so we opted not to.  We stuck with the pizzas and the pink lemonade (super refreshing and free refills!)

The food was good, but the service is what made this less of an experience for me.  I didn't feel it was worth the insane wait - especially with nowhere to sit or go to while you waited, and it was such a hot and humid night...  They were understandably busy so flagging down our waitress was difficult, even to just pay and leave.  Perhaps if we had gone at an off-peak time I would have liked it more, but it wasn't a meal I'll remember of my Chicago trip.

A Chicago classic -- deep dish pizza with a buttery crust. I love the veggie deep dish pizza, "The Lou" which comes with white sauce instead of red, spinach, mushrooms, tomatoes, and mozzarella cheese.

2nd Stop while on my Chicago trip. I had high hopes for this style of deep dish pizza.
I ate a Small Malnati Chicago Classic ($15.45) and I could only put down 2 of the four slices. Overall it was a good pie, however, it was a bit overpowering with garlic. My favorite thing about the pizza was the sausage with every bite. I like the way the sausage was spread over the entire pizza, that part of the experience was amazing.
I have nothing to compare this to except for the east coast, thin crust pizza we eat on a normal basis. That said, I would probably only eat this style of deep dish pizza 1 time a month.
At least now I know what the rave is about even if i do not agree :)

If you didn't try deep dish pizza, did you really even go to Chicago?

It was hard narrowing down a single pizzeria to visit during our trip, but a lot of Yelp lists and locals seem to like Lou Malnati's. We came on a Thursday night, and there was no wait for a party of two. I loved the atmosphere -- very Chicagoan and classic. Our server was friendly and made some great recommendations. And just a warning - deep dish pizzas take about 30 minutes to make, at least here, so this is definitely not the place for a quick bite.

Stuffed Spinach Bread: 5/5. Knowing we'd be waiting a while for our food, our server recommended ordering an appetizer to nibble on in the meantime. The Stuffed Spinach Bread was small, but so flaky and delicious. I could've eaten five of them. It wasn't so much "bread" as it was a crust - it was like a Hot Pocket, if he went off to college and became a successful businessman.

Malnati Chicago Classic Deep Dish Pizza: 4/5. This was our first time having deep dish pizza ever, but our hopes were high because we're pretentious. Unfortunately my lactose intolerance meant I could only have a few bites, but I got the gist...very delicious crust (their signature "Buttercrust" I believe), lots of tasty meat and gooey cheese center. Really good! It fell slightly short of our expectations because it wasn't as deep as we'd hoped, and the cheese was almost rubbery, which is strange because it shouldn't have been sitting out for long before arriving to our table.

Malnati Salad: 5,000/5. AMAZING. BEST SALAD EVER. This salad is huge and definitely for sharing, but I did some damage because it was so dang good. There must be some banned substance in the dressing or something because I couldn't stop eating. I feel bad for my future salads. They'll never come close.

pics.caption: Malnati Chicago Classic deep dish, personal size ($9.55)

review.des:
Weekend in Chicago called for Chicago style deep dish pizza, and Lou Malnati's was where Yelp took us.  
Excellent pizza, great staff.  Minestrone soup is homemade and delicious, but came out only lukewarm.  Waiter fixed it with another full bowl!
Salad was awesome with excellent dressing.
Definitely wanna go back before we leave Chicago!

Not good. With a wait time that long, you would think the food was good...not true. Locals don't come here. It's a touristy food spot that somehow caught traction and got its shot to fame. I don't know why the reviews are good, maybe ppl don't know what a good deep dish pizza should taste like. Maybe tourists visiting Chicago have a low standard of what good food should taste like.

Shame on you tv food shows for promoting pizza chains like this on your tv shows. Shame on you concierge for directing us to this touristy food spot. SHAME

My place to come for pizza every time I travel to Chicago, I'm obsessed with their house salads it is unbelievable and if you are from LA and think you can eat a medium pizza all to yourself think again one, max two slides of these will send you in a food coma.  Simply delicious, filling and cheesy

Delicious pies and great service. I was visiting for a day and needed my fix of Chicago famous deep dish, I do not regret having this be my only destination. The Malnati salad was also very tasty, highly recommend if you want something salty and savory. Great for groups and come with a huge appetite.

Lou Malmatti was my first deep dish pizza experience back in 2015 during my first trip to Chicago. I was back again for another round of my deep dish pizza fix on 10/13/17 around 7 pm with my partner. It was a busy Friday night and as expected long line was awaiting before us.
The greeter asks for a name and a phone number. We were told that it would be about 50 minutes and there is about 5 minutes of grace period where you have to answer to the text message to confirm the table. We took a quick walk to the river walk and walked back.  We were a little worried because we had text the confirmation text about 7 minutes later after receiving, but the greeter still let us in.

We ordered 1 small The Malnati Chicago Classic with butter crust and the regular Malani salad, all to share. Salad came out first. It is a good size salad. We were glad that we didn't order the family size. It was tasty. My partner is a carnivore and he didn't mind the Malani salad.

After about 10 minutes, our pizza arrived. It was my partner's first time trying deep dish pizza. He's a NY pizza fan for sure and he didn't sway. Even though, the Malnati Classic was delicious, I think I favor pepperoni better, of course with butter crust. My partner couldn't handle all the cheese and had to go for another serving of salad, which I am very happy about.

I love Lou Malnat. In every location I have been to, staffs are delightful and so helpful and the food is even better. I do favor this location more than the other ones I've been to just because of its authenticity and the location. Surely will be back when I return to chi town.

Their website says that they are open until 1 am. Naturally my boyfriend and I headed there at 11:50. Upon arrival, one  of the bus boys opened the door for us. We stood there for a few minutes before I decide to walk to the front desk. There was someone behind the counter but there was also someone in front of the counter (looked like a manager) she asked if we planned on dining in. I told her yes and she said "well we're close". I followed up by informing her the website said it doesn't close until 1. She said "yeah I'm sorry it should be updated."  

Safe to say the next time I want pizza I will NOT be heading to any Lou Malnati's locations.

Great pizza with a butter crust, and great buffalo wings! Service was good and if you want to try some native deep dish pizza, stop by. Not really much else to say. It's fairly priced and the pizzas fill you up!

Very good deep dish, although not as good as my still-reigning-favorite, Pequod's. We got a large pie, half Classic (which comes with sausage) / half Lou (which has spinach, mushrooms, tomatoes, and a three-cheese blend), both of which were good. I do think I may have liked the cheese or pepperoni more, but hard to say. Regardless, overall I thought this was very good, but not close to Pequod's.
This place is great, we ordered a small and it was enough for two. We also ordered calamari and it was really good and fresh.

As a tourist from California, I came to Chicago to venture out deep dish pizza joints. After further research, I have concluded four original deep dish pizza from Chicago; Lou Manati, Uno, Pequods and Giordanos. See my other reviews of the other three and their respective ranking of the four godfathers of "Chicago Deep Dish Pizza". I will not grade on the service due to the fact that they were take outs + eaten within 20 minutes.

Here is my take on Lou Manati,
They had plenty of their popular pizza for sale in a frozen freezer for dirt cheap. It was definitely the cheapest pizza out of the four, with their medium deep dish being mere $21.

Pizza: Malnati Chicago Classic
The crust: tasted very dry and not very fresh.
Sauce: May have came out of a can.
Meat: aged, not very fresh
Cheese: definitely packaged cheese that had been melted, very plastic-like taste.
Atmosphere: casual, nothing spectacular
Parking: very good

Overall: I would have to rank Lou Manati fourth out of the four godfathers of "Chicago Deep Dish Pizza" places.

Pros: parking, price of pizza
Cons: not authentic and thinnest deep dish of the four godfather places. Also seems like they took their frozen pizza out of the freezer and baked it.

Grade: D+

pics.caption: Chicago style, D+ grade. Tasted like frozen pizza

review.des: Upon planning my trip to Chicago this was theeee place my boyfriend and I wanted get our hands into - deep dish pizza. I don't know what else to say but it is by far the best pizza I've ever had in comparison to the other places we've tried during our stay. The garlic-butter crust was everything. The perfect ratio of cheese and toppings. Service was great! There wasn't much of a wait around the time we had dinner which was about an hour before closing time. Our server was nice and very accommodating and welcoming. We ended up ordering frozen pizza's to bring home which was so worth the wait and getting checked and searched with TSA at the airport.

pics.caption: Too hungry to take a decent before picture.

review.des: This is a fresh review, I still have the left overs with me lol.  Is it the best pizza in Chicago? No, I mean it is nice but for me, nothing to rave about there are other smaller pizza places that I have tried, that have blown my mind. I just went because every one goes on about it and I guess it's mainly because of the tourists. It is a very touristy restaurant. I still prefer Pizano's over Lou Malnati's and Giordano's. The service is great and the waiter was very attentive, so no worries. It was good that I went and got it out of the way, now I have the experience lol, on to the next. It is safe to say that I won't be going back

We were warned it would be 45 minutes after you order to get your pizza.  I would expect it to be perfect, but it wasn't. Deep dish was not piping hot and neither was the thin crust. Flavors were good, but just was not that hot. Server was great, and place is cool. I see the charm just wasn't thrilled.

Great atmosphere and great pizza. The bruschetta appetizer was one of the best I've had.
Pizza is made to order and was outstanding.
It's very popular so a bit crowded, but we did not have a wait for a table. Server was attentive.

+gluten free review
gluten free thin crust pizza (excellent)

Ok being in Chicago for the first time we were like let's eat pizza one of the nights, so we used Yelp to google gluten free pizza and Lou Malnati's popped up and said 0.4 miles let's go! Now we didn't realize we were embarking on one of the best pizza journeys of a life time. We arrived and there were about 50 people standing outside, I said darn, let's go somewhere else. The lady however asked a lady why she was sitting down she said you go inside and place your order and then you wait outside for a text a message when your tables ready.

I would have left not knowing you can order your pizza with no line and wait for a text to be seated. They def need to make this more well known!!! However we went and walked around and came back after about 20 minutes and got seated. Then was additional 20-30 minutes for our pizza to arrive, service was excellent and the pizza.... best gluten free pizza I've ever had. SO GOOD. Can't wait to fly back to Chicago just for Lou Malnati's.

Great job.

pics.caption: waiting for the text "your table is ready"

review.des: While in town on business, I stopped in here with my nephew and some of his coworkers on 3-20-2018.  I knew I wanted to try some pizza this trip and this is what my nephew picked out.  This was a party of 8.  We were seated quickly, upstairs....without an elevator.  My knees!!  Our server was Kristen T.  For the table we ordered a Family Malnati salad.  For my own meal, I ordered a thin crust pepperoni and sausage pizza.  I coordinated with my nephew so that I could have a slice of deep dish pizza too.  The salad was amazingly good.  Lots of flavor, very fresh and BIG!!  The one slice of deep dish pizza was GREAT.  Good flavor.  Good temperature.  My pizza, the thin crust, came out COLD which was surprising.  So, I told a server and then the manager came over and offered to (1) reheat the pizza or (2) make me a new one.  I accepted a new one (which was complimentary).  This time the pizza came out piping hot.  Good flavor.  Plenty of topping.  Big enough for two people too.  I had iced tea and water to drink.  Next trip to Chicago I can see myself coming back again, but this time sitting on the first floor.  Keep serving up the pizza, piping hot too!!

pics.caption: This is some thick pizza!!  You can't eat a small by yourself.  :)

review.des:
As a tourist from Cali, this was one of my bookmarks since it's highly popular. After Lollapalooza, we were craving a nice deep dish but we were exhausted from the event. Thankfully they were able to deliver to our hotel!

I highly recommend their Chicago deep dish. You can tell the sausage is homemade because of the flavor. I really love how crispy the crust was but at the same time, everything in the middle was soft. Just taking one bite from the pizza will take you to Pizza heaven and back-- especially how Ooey-gooey the cheese will string from your mouth. Phenomenal!

The chicken fettuccine was also very delicious! The pasta tasted like it was made from scratch with its perfectly creamy Alfredo sauce and bits of chicken. Delish!

I was once skeptical about deep dish pizza. It's just a lot of sauce, and a big slice of pizza that will fill you up. How good can it be? Boy was I wrong.

After polling from locals, Uber drivers, my friends who visited Chicago before, I have decided to try Lou Malnati's pizza over the other chains that are around town. Since we had a tight schedule, we didn't want to wait in line and wait for the pizza to cook when we order, so we decided to call in and ask for to-go.

Their medium deep dish pizza has 6 slices (serves 3-4), and their large deep dish pizza has 8 slices (serves 5-6). My group weren't too hungry, and the 6 of us shared the medium deep dish pizza (so we each had one slice).

When I opened up the pizza box after picking it up at the restaurant, I was really nervous that the pizza would go stale or not be as fresh since it was sitting inside a pizza box for roughly half an hour. As soon as I bit into my pizza, all those worries went away. The cheese were so stringy, and the butter crust was amazing.

I seriously don't know how else to describe the slice of heaven I had, other than asking you try it yourself!!

Welp I expected more from this place, I don't know if it's cause we're from Cali and we have really good pizza but to be honest I've have better Round Table and Mountain Mike's than this, def not worth the 1 1/2 hr wait it took. Pizza was salty and dry, more sauce would have been nice. Our salad was better than the darn pizza lol. P.s not too many topping options either

I read my review from the last time here and now my experience is the exact opposite.

This time I did carry-out so I didn't have to wait in the long lines.  A Malnati salad and a deep-dish pepperoni.  It was ready when I arrived.

I didn't like the Malnati salad this time.  The dressing was way too sweet, like a Pennsylvania Dutch sweet-and-sour dressing.  I don't remember that from last time.

Where it was at was with the pizza. Sure, I couldn't taste the pepperoni (note to self - just get it plain), but the sauce was pure, acidic, crushed San Marzano tomatoes.  Oh how I love those things.

Next time I'm craving Chicago-style deep-dish, it's Malnati's plain cheese pizza for me.
The food definitely lived up to the hype. Was afraid that my expectations were to high but yummy.  Must try

Chicago, chicago! I've always wondered what a deep dish pizza tasted like, and Lou did not disappoint. As a first time visitor from Atlanta, I found a ton of different options for deep dish pizza while researching food places for the trip, and I decided on Lou Malnatis mostly due to its location in the heart of tourist central (sorry in advance to all the delicious hole-in-the-wall pizza restaurants that I'm most definitely missing out on) and closeness to the subway line we were looking to take after dinner.

Upon arrival, I put my name down for our party of 7 and was told the estimated wait time was an hour and a half (pretty accurate). We were able to pre-order our pizza, so when we were seated it came out pretty quickly. During our wait, we kept track of our place in line via a website that was sent to my phone, which let us wander while waiting. For the 7 of us, we ordered two medium pizzas (one Classic and one Lou).

From the cheese pulls to the thick sausage and the rich sauce, the Classic was definitely my favorite of the two. Our server, Jessie, was jess-t amazing, and made sure we had everything we needed. I'm pretty easy to please with food, but that was 5/5 for sure - some of, if not the best, pizza I've ever had!

This was the first place I had deep dish at when I moved to Chicago a few years ago. Expect to wait about 45 minutes to receive the pizza after ordering (this is pretty standard at all deep dish places). The pizza itself is pretty heavy, more so than most of the other deep dish places I've eaten at in Chicago. The crust doesn't particularly have much flavor despite ordering the buttercrust, the sauce is a big on the sour side, and the sausage tends to be pretty bland.

One nice thing you can do at this restaurant is to pre-order while you're waiting so you can sit down to a hot pizza. Another is that this place is pretty cheap, and a small pizza goes a long way.
Here's pizza is always amazing. Restaurant is quite spacious, and the workers are nice. Also they deliver to neighborhood. Classic deep dish pizza is awesome.

This place is overly rated with tourist reviews. Prior to coming to Chicago, we researched for the best pizza and this place was rated for the best deep dish Chicago pizza. They have different types of pizza and you can customize as well.

This place has a long wait line and be prepared to wait for 45 minutes additional for pizza.

we ordered the pizza with sausage and apparently the pizza was so salty, chewy that we were unable to eat. No one would believe the pizza was that bad until they would have tasted our pizza.

The bruschetta were awesome and I highly recommend you to try here.

Spiritually this place reaches a level of intoxication via food in me that I cannot fully describe. Yeah it will take a lil bit to get to you if you ask for it delivered but oh my goodness is this the clutch meal when seasonal depression kicks in. Bless yourself and order some dew dish from ya boy Lou. The cheese will fill the void in your empty heart.

This was my first time here. I ordered mozzarella sticks and a deep dish pizza. It was a Wednesday night I gave my number and only waited 15 mins for a table. They let me put the pizza order in early, so it would be ready by the time the table was. When I asked the person at the door if they had beef sausage he said yes. When I got to the cashier they told me it was mixed with pork. Also when we were seated no one informed the waitress that the pizza was pre ordered. Personally I like Giordano's better but their pizza was still good. I think the staff should communicate better though. Overall the service was good and everyone was nice.

True Chicago style pizza. Deep dish pizza. Get the one with the butter crust, onions, spinach and mushrooms. Great baseball memorabilia. Busy at lunch time. They have indoor and outdoor seating. The pizza is so filling! We had the small enough for two people! And we were both full. Had the coffee, which is good too. I like the exposed brick and wood floors. A NYC loft type feeling. Go early!!

pics.caption: Front of the building! Can't miss it! Look for the red outdoor umbrellas:)
Buffalo wings are so good! Crispy and great sauce!

review.des: I'm not used to Chicago style pizza so I'm not sure if it falls into the pizza category for me. It's absolutely incredible though. Definitely worth checking out when coming into town

Recommended by a TON of folks, and they DID NOT DISAPPOINT! The pizza was freaking the BOMB!!! Explosion scene just happened, sorry y'all can't see it! Took roughly 33 min to get it, but it was fresh! We went with the Malnati and added pepperoni. We got a large, but for the 4 of us, a medium would've sufficed. Our pre-game consisted of bruschetta and mozzarella sticks, both held their own! For the grand finale, we got the baked cookie! (Free if you ride the big bus) - it was very good.

I was told it's a great deep dish pizza place during my first time staying in Chicago . I guess I'm not a fan of any pizza at all. (Yelp and google for this pizza restaurant have so many reviews!!!). Service wasn't great, but I guess because restaurant is busy, understaffed so it's understandable.

JUST LOVED THE DEEP DISH PIZZA OVER HERE !!

We ordered the salad and the Malnati classic pizza which is made with sausage.This was just awesome.

The servers are great, service is great, PIZZAS are awesome ! In my last 5 years of eating pizza, this certainly is one of the best !

A must have in Chicago !

O.M.G. Do yourself a favor and go eat here! We had to wait an hour and fifteen minutes but it was well worth the wait. This is the best pizza I've ever had!

The crust is amazing, it's crunchy throughout and not doughy, the cheese is out of this world, the sauce has small delicious pieces of garlic, and you get sausage with every freakin bite!

The worst part of it all was that I wanted to go purge in the bathroom so I could keep eating more!

Really cool pizzeria to come and hang out.  The line can get long so be prepared; there is also a 40 minute wait for your pie so I recommend having some appetizers.  Had the Lou personal Pizza with added pepperoni and sausage and it was great.  Also had the sample platter for appetizers; all the samples were really good.

When you're in town for only 24 hours and you have to eat Chicago, you get deep-dish pie.

However, being gluten-free (not by choice, trust me, i wish I could smash my way through a Chi-town hot dog/pizza/sammich fest), I figured I'd be relegated to crying sorghum tears over another one-size, flat, cardboardish, probably-bought-from-Udi's-and-marketed-as-"'made daily in house" pizza.  

Damn, I was SO wrong.  

So Lou Malnati's gluten-free deep dish isn't really a bread crust; it's made out of sausage.  Hold up. Wait.  Rewind.  A sausage crust available in multiple sizes, you say?  And I don't have to pay $5 extra for it?  Whoooooo

Yep. And after careful deliberation, myself and a friend opted for the smaller size (and a two-slice serving was pretty filling).

The pie took a bit of time to make, prob 20-30 min, but I'm used to waiting a bit longer for my grub so I was ok with it, besides, I needed to let my three lunches settle anyway.  

Once it arrived, the smell of the freshly cooked sausage topped with fresh mozzarella just wafted its way up to my face,  slapped me and said "Welcome to Lou's!"

Delightful spice, fresh tomatoes, amazing sauce, I was sad I couldn't eat more, and am even sadder I left the extra slice in the hotel fridge.

pics.caption: Side profile of the Gluten free, sausage-crust deep dish pie. Look at that "crust":cheese:sauce ratio.  Mmmmmm
Rear view of the sausage crust on the GF deep dish.
Birds eye view of Lou's gluten free / sausage crust pizza.

review.des: There is usually no wait to be seated but you need to be willing to wait for food. It takes time to order the pizza and then 30-60 min to get it depending on how busy they are. But meanwhile, why not get their appetizers? Pretty cheesy and delicious- perfect way to wait out the time it takes to make the pizza.
If you're not getting buttered crust you're doing it wrong! Amazing deep dish pizza. I always get deep dish pizza with sausage and green peppers. My absolute favorite place for deep dish  pizza.

Another good visit to Lou's! The lunch special is a great deal. 6 inch personal pizza, salad and drink for under $10. Lunch was super busy. We got seated at a table that was basically in the waiting room. Not very private. The server was new too. But once again the food was wonderful! My pizza came out before the salads because we pre-ordered so that is a warning.

We had to get deep dish pizza before we left Chicago! We came to chi town for MLK weekend and hours before we had to be at the airport going home, we stopped by Lou's. We ordered "The Lou" and it was phenomenal. It was the perfect temperature, cheesy but not too much, and I loved that the vegetables still tasted like vegetables.

They warn you that it can take 30 min or so before the food comes out and I greatly appreciated that. We weren't too hungry when we arrived so the wait was fine.
Never like deep dish...loved it here! Love the varieties. Super nice staff. Quaint setting. Yum yum yum!!!

We may be biased as we are from NY, but Chicago, if you have to wait over an hour for this kind of pizza, you're doing it wrong...

We tried the Lou salad - eh - and buffalo wings - they were fine. Then a deep dish and a thin crust. We felt like we were eating at Costco.
Great deep dish pizza! Fun live music and a cool environment as well. Would recommend for a fun Friday night hangout!

I sat at the bar. The bartenders were fantastic. Since I was starving, I ordered a deep dish half and half of the small (serves 2); the Lou (add jalapeño) and the classic (one with sausage). The bartender warned me it would be one slice too much, but I finished it (without eating the crust on the last two slices). Generous pours on the drinks!
Bartenders stayed involved in the conversation and were easy to talk to.
Very very  tasty, flavor explodes from the tomatoes, the cheese is very good, I still can't buy into the deep dish crust... it's ah!!!

Where do I begin...?

I had pretty high hopes as a tourist that this place would be a must on my to-do list but I was so disappointed.

Disclaimer: we ordered the thin crust pizza and a personal size deep dish so I can't speak for the taste of the bigger sized deep dishes that come in an actual cast iron skillet.

We waited for about 40 min for a table. We did the preordering thing, thinking our pizza would come around the time we got seated. Nope. We waited a total of an hour and 15 minutes from the time we stepped foot into that restaurant to eat our pizza. Fine. I get it. It's packed.

But when my pizza comes, I at least expect it to taste good. Nope.

The cheese has hardened. I mean, we just got it. Not like it hardened over the course of our eating it. It came like that. And then the waitress, as friendly as she tries to be, didn't even think to let us know when our pizza would come out.

AND tell me how the tables that got seated after us got their pizza first.

Save your money and go elsewhere. Waste of time.

I love Lou malnatis. It is our go to Sunday night pizza. However it is not even 50% of the time I place an order that I get what I really ordered. When you pay $40 all in, delivery tip etc, for a medium pizza. It would be nice to get what you paid for.

Yesterday I was shorted two toppings that I ordered. I went over my order on the phone at least 3-4 times. But I didn't receive my onions or green pepper. The ingredients that I did receive were barely on there. I could count on two hands the amount of sausage crumbles I received.

I also asked for crushed red and parm cheese. Asked 2-3 times to make sure they bring it, as they never do.

Lastly, my pizza was like soup. Very undercooked.

I know these sound like small things, but add them all up and pay $40.00 for 6 slices of pizza and.... it is not a very satisfying experience. Sunday night hbo and Lou's is something I look forward to all week. But man, what a disappointment it is to get a product like this.

Lou's does have the best deep dish in Chicago, just beware of the details when placing your order.

#veryunsatisfied #moreoftenthannot

It's good Chicago pizza...but unless you love tomato sauce in huge quantities....and I am not keen..
Very generous amounts of toppings...sausage was great, the service is fine ( they are rushed, lots of customers exhaust some of their energy) they earn their tips.
Almost always a line...order to go a few times...saves waiting around.

$10 lunch: soup or salad + personal deep dish pizza

Soup: minestrone, a bit salty, full of veggies, generous portion

Salad: I asked for no onion or cabbage, so they gave me fresh romaine, tomatoes, and cucumbers, with balsamic vinaigrette, generous portion

Personal pizza: crispy dough, perfectly salted, generous layer of sausage (and pepperoni in the 2nd pie).

Service: courteous

Cleanliness: drink and dessert menus had tomato sauce smeared on them, plates had black peppers sprinkled on them

Definitely a place that deep dish fans should try.

Don't let the crowd scare you away. Went on a Friday night and the crowd outside almost scared me away. Hostess said the wait was 45 min and we probably only waited for 20. I do think the crowds can cause some confusion with the ordering process. You have to place your pizza order after putting your name in because the pizza takes so long to cook. After getting seated, it took awhile for our waitress to get drinks. The waiting was sooo worth it. We got The Malnati's classic and added pepperoni, garlic and basil. You have to add garlic and basil to any pie you get! Even our waitress commented on how good the smell was. Definitely will be back!

We were in search for a great deep dish pizza and Lou Malnati's pizza did not disappoint! The pizza tasted soon good!! The crust was also really good!. We loved it so much that we returned the following day for more Lou Malnati's pizza!

My boyfriend and I came here on Saturday a little after 5PM and were seated immediately at a booth. Lou's is a casual, cozy pizza restaurant. We ordered the calamari and a medium deep dish (half The Malnati Chicago Classic and half The Lou - yes you can do half and half!). The appetizer took 25 minutes and the pizza 45 minutes to be served.

Can I please say how the calamari appetizer is literally one of the best calamari I have ever had? When it was served on the table, I was not expecting much already because it looked too crispy and fried. But wow, the combination of the calamari with the house dipping sauce is AMAZING. The dipping sauce is not your typical tomato sauce. It's refreshing and it reminded me a little bit of a mignonette sauce used for raw oysters.

The deep dish itself was tasty too. I liked The Lou more than The Malnati Chicago Classic simply because I'm not a very meaty person. I also don't love to eat cheese... so the triple cheese on The Lou was a little much for me. The tomato sauce that Lou Malnati uses is homemade and so so delicious. If you read the description on their menu, their vine tomatoes are handpicked from California (or something like that). Note that they have suggested portion sizes and I advise you to listen to that. For two, a medium was WAY too big (my boyfriend claimed he could finish it). A small would have been perfect for us and maybe even a little bit leftover still.

The service was also phenomenal, even during the Saturday evening rush at the restaurant. Basically, the homemade tomato sauce and dipping sauce made the experience a great one for me.

As we were leaving, there were about 40 people waiting around in the lobby, on the stairs and outside for a table. Good thing we just missed the wait!

pics.caption: Half The Lou's and half The Malnati Classic!
Half The Lou's and half The Malnati Classic! Featured slice: The Lou
AMAZING CALAMARI + DIPPING SAUCE! Get it!

review.des:
Not sure how impressed I am with Chicago deep dish pizza.

There was about a ten minute wait when I came on Thursday night around 8:30 pm. Checked in and gave them my number- they text you when your table is ready. You can then go in and preorder your pizza.

Got a personal size pepperoni pizza with Buttercrust and additional mushroom topping. It was tiny! And the pizza wasn't super hot when it came- the cheese was kinda thickened and not melty. Sad. The crust didn't blow me away- was pretty unimpressive, really (not light and fluffy as they described it). More squished and crunchy. Left me wondering what the normal crust looked like and whether I should have just gotten that instead of paying extra for Buttercrust.

My personal pizza was $11. Coke was $2.60. Total bill came out to $15.17 before tip.

Overall, not impressed. Not to be blasphemous or anything, but Zachary's deep dish pizza in Berkeley is way better!

I am not a deep dish fan. I prefer thin and crispy. When my group decided they wanted to eat here, I was hesitant as I didn't think I would end up liking anything on the menu. Boy was I wrong.

I got a thin crust personal pizza and it was FANTASTIC. I ate the whole thing. It was cooked well, the toppings were fresh, and the sauce ratio was perfect. I really don't like over-sauced pizza.

Everyone else got one of the deep dish pizzas. I wasn't optimistic when I was told I MUST try a bite because it's "soooo gooood!" - but again I was wrong! It was soooo goooood! Definitely changed my opinion of deep-dish pizza. I guess I just hadn't ever had a good one prior!

Our server was great! He was noticeably busy that evening, juggling several tables, yet the service was never lacking. He was friendly, chatty, never pushy or rushing.

I am a fan!

I really think Lou's is the best deep dish in Chicago! The crust is crisp and flavorful (which I find lacking in most other deep dish places), the sauce is good, and the toppings are great. I usually get their spinach and mushroom pizza - and I'm never disappointed! The salads are also really good, so make room!

Beautifully cooked to my very specific taste every time. They have a manager check my order for accuracy and I have to say that their consistent delivery of exactly what I ordered is refreshing from other places where accuracy is less important. I love the butter crust, the beautiful thin sauce that I prefer in place of the chunky sauce on my deep dish pizza, and a well done pie with extra pepperoni and no parmesan.
I'm a picky eater and I sure appreciate the effort Lou Malnati's has shown in gaining my customer loyalty. I'm a very loyal customer, too.

Lou's is a fan favorite and for a reason, they know Chicago-style pizza and deliver an exceptional pie every time.

Don't forget to order the 'butter crust'

The Lou will blow you away!!

I was told by someone I know that used to live here and said that I have to go try this place.  When I went it was a Saturday evening, I was 49th on the waiting list and it took over an hour to get a table.  I was told that I could order the pizza while I waited for my table.  I took about another 20 min to get my pizza after I sat down.  

The pizza was amazing and filled me up.  I ordered the Lou Malnati signature pizza and it was amazing.  I ordered the small and still had ¼ left over after I was full.  ANYONE who comes to Chicago NEEDS to come try this place but plan on a long wait if it is a weekend.

Visiting Chicago I was told to go to Lou Malnati's pizzeria to experience my very first official Chicago deep dish. And I have to say they did not disappoint. The crust was buttery and crispy. Sausage and garlic spinach topping was absolutely delightful , it went along very well with the very flavorful tomato sauce that goes on top. Their tomato sauce has so much flavor in it and it's not like drowned in the garlic flavor which I really don't mind. It's very savory yet not acidic but also not sweet sauce.. Hard to explain.. add to my big surprise, it was also good the following day just microwaved. Very shocked. I also rate pizza this way cuz I feel that there's always left over when getting a pie.. and I hate it when u get a good pie when it's hot but nasty once it cools off.. I never waste food.. lol..

Finally had this pizza and .....  not all it's cracked up to be. Don't get me wrong it was good for sure but I'm more of a thin crust kinda guy. The restaurant is awesome though. Covered with great sports decorations from wall to wall you can find some cool things to look at. The pizza is heart and rich with flavor and pairs well with a nice cold brew. That buttery crust is pretty damn good and great for dipping. This is just a classic joint that you have to try once!

I only come here when I have friends and family visiting from out of town. There's a reason why this place is always packed and always has at least an hour wait.

We have never had a bad experience. Our friends and family have always left happy and very full. Servers and staff have always been nothing but polite.
Very good deep dish. Rivals others that are more widely known. A bit expensive and service a little slow but food was very good
Lou's is hands down the best pizza around. I've never had a bad experience and I always look forward to my meal!

Gahhhh. This pizza came recommended. I really need to reassess the judgment of my friends. Got takeout and the pizza is completely raw on the bottom. Literally doughy. I've included a picture as it is inedible. Desperately needs salt/garlic/SOMETHING as the pizza is flavorless on top of the raw and gooey crust. No plastic ware, plates or napkins were packed with the to go. Beyond amateurish. Seriously, go anywhere else.

Ever feel like there's just not enough sausage on your sausage pizza??? Look no further than Lou's who has not crumbs of sausage on their pizzas but SHEETS of sausage. Yum. The deep dish is heaven; they even make their gluten free pizza tasty.

First time in Chicago, I asked a few locals where I could find the bear deep dish pizza and they recommended Lou's. We went right around 5:30-6pm so it was busy and it had just rained so it was packed inside while we waited for our table (45 minutes). After we placed ourselves on the wait list we were able to pre order our pizza to cut down on the wait time once we reached the table. We ordered our version of the classic pizza except with chicken sausage. Once we got to the table it was about another 15-20 minutes before the pizza would come so we ordered the calamari as an appetizer. Unfortunately it took quite a while to come out and when it did it was cold so we sent it back for a reorder. By that time we we elbows deep in deep dish pizza and the manager, who was absolutely amazing (Matt), had already come to our table to square things away.

In the end we walked away with a belly full of some of Chicago's best deep dish pizza and an amazing first experience at Lou's.
Best Chicago pizza!  It is my go to every trip.  Get a good workout before you go because one slice comes in at 750 Cals but totally worth it.

Hour long wait and although it was pretty good i have to agree I think there's better deep dish pizza in Chicago. While the pizza had lots of toppings, I thought both would be deeper dish (we ordered a large so maybe that's hard to make deep?). But mainly I was disappointed in the lack of flavor. It seems like neither their sauce nor sausage has any italian spices in it.

Spinach salad - good.
The Malnati (sausage) pizza - a layer of crust, cheese, sausage, and then sauce. This was ok except it really lacked flavor besides grease. Even the sausage didn't really have flavor.
The Lou (veggie) pizza - this was the best. Yay flavor!
Tiramisu - meh, I've had better

This Chicagoland Pizzeria NEVER disappoints!
No trip to the "Windy City" is complete without a pie at Lou's!

This was good and a fun experience. I don't know if it will make the frequent list for us to dine at. We ordered the Chicago style pizza and it was good, not great. The bruschetta however, was wonderful! I would give the staff a B- on attentiveness.

Everyone knows that the wait here can be exhausting, even on a weekday night, but they seem to have the process down to a science, even when, with so many people filling every nook a cranny while they wait, it makes it really difficult for the servers to get through. So, wait in line to give your order, then wait some more until your table is called, and THEN, tuck into a sweetly satisfying, deep dish pizza. Coming from pizza-centric New York, my husband did not appreciate the sweet, butter-"frosted" crust, nor the somewhat sweet, diced tomato-ey sauce (all of which I loved) for which Malnati's is known. Come give it a try, but prepared to wait and people watch.

pics.caption: $22.75 and more than enough for three people.

review.des:
I order from Lou Malnati's every other month for large meetings and they are great! The delivery driver is always on time , and the pizza is always nice and warm!

They have a great customer service , and always exceed expectations!

I don't know, guys. I am a transplant to Chicago, and I just don't get it. That makes sense right? Every time I have this pizza...it hurts my insides. Don't get me wrong...I keep trying, but even I am not foolish enough to injure myself over and over again. I recognize that this is a Chicago establishment, and I don't prefer deep dish (I prefer Dimo's, really). This particular location has good service and a nice staff. It does take a long time if you order deep dish (like most places).

I would consider this, food wise, mediocre, but also, a Chicago establishment. You have to go at least once. I can't promise you it will come out okay on the other end. They do offer other options if deep dish isn't your thing. The wings are pretty good here as well.

The pizza was so good and very reasonably priced. My boyfriend and I went on a Sunday night and the place was packed which was totally ok! We had a 45 minute wait to be seated but put our order in so (apparently) we wouldn't have to wait long to eat after being seated. I'm giving this restaurant 4 stars instead of 5 because after being seated we had to wait an additional 1.5 hours for the pizza. Loved the pizza it was amazing, the waiting after we got seated though was a little disappointing.

So - caveat . . . I am not a fan of Chicago style pizza.  I just do not do the deep.  That being said, I was pretty happy with the pizza we got here.  We opted for the butter crust to add some calories and make it crisper.  What I liked about this was that the crust wasn't crazy doughy like some other deep dish places and the toppings didn't make some wet spongy mess.  

We also grab an order of mozzarella sticks.  These had a nice thick crisp coating with stretchy oozing goodness inside.  Couple that with a little garlicky marinara and we were happy.

Of course you have to try the Chicago deep dish when you are in Chicago!

I ordered the famous Malnati Chicago classic deep dish and a side salad.

YUM. The deep dish was delicious and flavorful! My first time trying deep dish and the crust along with the meat, sauce and cheese melted in my mouth.

The Lou malnati's salad dressing is BOMB Also!! Would definitely come again and recommend :)

There was a lot of hype about this place and unfortunately, the restaurant didn't live up to it. The hostess said the wait for a table would be 45 minutes so we ordered take out instead. A table cleared up 15 minutes later and sat open for an hour while we waited for our takeout pizzas. AN HOUR. The crust on the pizza was greasy. The sauce had no flavor and the sausage was bland. We were disappointed but I'd be willing to give the place a second chance to see if we showed up on a bad day.

This was a tough review for me to figure out! First of all, I have a huge and unwavering love for NY thin crust pizza, but I promised myself to have an open mind for this. We got there around 9:30 on a Sunday night, and MAN, was it packed. We were told it'd be a 45-minute wait, so we tried to do carry out instead. We were told it'd be 50 minutes to wait for that, so we stuck to that plan. Well, after about 15 minutes, everyone had been seated and we regretted that choice! The staff was not very helpful and that whole process was kind of frustrating. We finally got our pizza, and it was really good! It was delicious and fresh. I just wish it was easier to get!

Why 4 stars? Because I enjoyed it, but I've had better.

  ---   ---   ---

I've been a huge fan of deep dish/Chicago-style pizza for a while now, but had only tried Lou Malnati's frozen version in the mail, so I knew that my visit to Chicago was definitely going to consist of a visit here for the real deal.

There was quite a lengthy wait, and unfortunately, it was cold/rainy outside, so we crammed into the bar area and stood around to wait for our table. After 30-45 minutes, we were seated and were ready to devour some 'za!

While I did enjoy the pizza, I've actually had better in the Tampa Bay area, at Paul's Chicago Pizza. The crust at Lou Malnati's was a bit different than what I expected - it was actually a little bit hardened. I didn't think it was a bad thing, but just not what I imagined it would be. But the primary reason I prefer Paul's in Clearwater is because it's just absolutely swamped with cheese, where Lou Malnati's had plenty of cheese, but it just wasn't quite the level of Paul's.

I recommend trying extra cheese, if that's available on the deep dish!

This place was hyped up before we even got there. It was a 30 minute wait but it went quick and we put our order in as we were waiting so the pizza arrived just 10 mins after sitting down. Lou's lived up to the hype. We got a small pizza and a bruschetta to share and we left feeling like beached whales. That's a lot of food for a couple.

Our waiter was awesome and the food was Devine. To top it off we sat near the bar so we watched the Cubs beat the Reds so it was a win all around. Do not miss this iconic take on Chicago deep dish.

I'm a lifelong Chicagoan, so I take deep dish pizza very seriously.  In my mind, the two best places are the original Uno's and Due's, and Lou Malnati's.  Lou Malnati's has a little bit of a sweeter crust--especially if you ask for butter crust, which makes it richer and crispier.  I would ask for extra sauce on their pizzas--I think the standard way they do it doesn't give the perfect ratio of sauce to cheese.  They also do a decent Caesar salad to snack on while you wait.  Full bar and good beers on tap.  Service is always friendly.  Prepare for a long wait if you go at a popular time.
Sampled some of this at taste of Chicago. Daaaamnnnn was it good! No wonder this is an institution for chicago pizza! Now on my top recommendations to peeps looking to score the best chicago pizza!

So Chicago is known for deep dish pizza. And Chicago has many pizzerias that serve their own twist of deep dish pizza. So... how do you choose the best deep dish pizza spot knowing that there's many others. If you're like me, you probably think "whats the best spot" , "where's the best bang for the buck?" , "I don't want to waste my time" , "I don't want to be disappointed" .... well I'll make it easy for you...

Go to Lou F'N Malnati's!!!!

As recommended by a few Chicago natives and locals, we went to see for ourselves if it was everything it was hyped out to be. On our first visit, we ordered the "Chicago Classic" - which basically is sausage, extra extra cheese, and their signature tomato sauce. And when i say sausage, I don't mean sausage as in carry out pizza sausage... you know, little turd pieces of sausage scattered across the whole pizza?.. well, no no no no no.. none of that here at Lou's. Here at Lou's, I mean sausage as in a whole freaking slab of sausage (lean sausage may I add) covering every square inch, every square centimeter on the pizza!! The "Chicago Classic was so good, so meaty, so cheesy, and oooohhh the crust, Oh so buttery!! We also ordered "The Lou" which has some veggies on it such as spinach, tomatoes, and shrooms. That was good also but, hey I'm a meat kinda guy so I prefer the Classic Chicago!

Aside from the pizza, they also have real good appetizers. Some appetizers that we tried that is worth mentioning are: the calamari, chicken wings and mozzarella sticks.

On our last night in Chicago, we decided to do delivery out to our hotel, not knowing when we will get close or even get our hands on this authentic deep dish pizza again.  Being that I am a meat lover, ordered a custom combo, sausage and pepperoni. It was meaty delicious.

Recently, I found out that besides Chicago/ Illinois, there is only one other city/ state that has the pleasure of having a Lou Malnati's in the U.S. ... and that is Phoenix, AZ. Living in Las Vegas, I was ecstatic! It is about a 4-5 hour drive or I have the option on taking that hour flight. Will try to make it a point to visit at least every other month LoL Yes, all for this. Best pizza I've ever had! That's because I've yet been to NYC or Boston. But who knows if they can slug out Lou's and Chicago in general to take the crown as best pizza? We shall see.. it's a personal preference anyway.

Enclosing in 4 words: The Hype is Real!
The pasta is so filling it can be split between 3 people !! They have a crustless pizza which is totally worth checking out

I've never had deep dish pizza-and I've been told Lou Malnati's was the place I had to try in Chicago. And it for sure didn't disappoint. I'd recommend getting the buttercrust for the pizza-it adds a better taste. Also, if you sign up for emails through their free wifi, you can get a free appetizer with a purchase of $20!

pics.caption: Personal pepperoni with the lunch special and the small pizza!
Small Cheese Deep Dish. Feeds 2, or a hungry 1 ;)

review.des:
Dropped in around 4:30 on a Friday afternoon while in town.  I have been to this location several times.  Grabbed a seat for one right away --- 30 minutes later and it's likely a decent wait.

One mission this trip --- some deep dish on a super cold day before flying home.  Debated a personal or small classic --- sausage, melty cheese and the butter crust.  Lauren S., my very efficient and just attentive enough server explained the options, and i settled for the small. I skipped lunch after all for this.  She said it would be 40 minutes, but it was out in 30... they neatly serve up the first slice and off you go.  As advertised and expected --- nice thick, almost chunky tomato sauce, plenty of cheese and generous sausage.  They really promote ordering it "your way" which is a nice touch --- less sausage, more cheese, etc.

Lauren kept my drink full and boxed up my last slice for a snack preflight. Give Lou's a try... I have had 'em all, and Lou's deep dish and even their thin crust is a good pie.

pics.caption: Lou's classic.  Deep dish sausage and cheese on their buttery crust. Can't go wrong!

review.des: Amazing pizza. You will like this pie. You want this pie. Recommend to anyone. Sauce, cheese, and butter crust all make the magic happen. Get the Lou it's a signature for a reason.
