We came here for a birthday dinner and not disappointed. Thank you for the service and food. Salad is amazing. I bought a bottle of the dressing to make at home.
It's Lou's. I moved out of Chicago. I may never eat pizza again. Because whats the point? I had Lou's. The rest is cheese bread.

My husband and I order here quite often. The deep dish pizza  is amazing! Always amazing . This particular Lou Malnati's ( on Wrightwood) is very consistent and always delivers high quality pizza. They have us for life!!

YUM. Ok, I have to admit I was a little hesitant to try the deep dish style pizza being from New York and living off of thin crust, but I was pleasantly surprised - it was better than I thought. Four of us popped in around 6:30 on a Thursday and there was a 25 minute wait (it actually was 25 and not like, one hour). We were told to order the pizza specifically at the front before we sat down. We opted for the Chicago classic and the Lou (there were four of us and we ordered two mediums - perfect amount). We also started with the calamari which was shockingly good. The pizza was awesome. Our friends who live in Chicago said that this was a "thinner" deep dish which I liked. Of the two pies, I preferred the Chicago classic. The sausage was a nice touch and the pie itself was full of flavor. Overall, I was really impressed. As for the service, our waiter was great, and he called me out for not already having a beer in front of me when we got to the table, which I can appreciate.

I am normally patient with restaurant during busy hours but if you are short staffed or whatever reason it may be .  The restaurant needs to let the customers know better approx of when they can expect their food.  If the food will take 2 hours let me know it will take 2 hours and not 1 hour 20 mins.  The staff was not apologetic that the food was delayed after asking them for updates 5 times for foods and being told the food would be ready in 20 mins. No matter how good the food is there needs to be better management.

Okay 3,2, and 1 star Yelpers...we get it, you like New York style pizza.
Okay self (and life-long New Yorker), you like Chicago style pizza, and it doesn't matter what your family and friends say, you're going to go to bat for it.

My partner and I's first stop on our trip to Chicago was Lou Malnati's. It came recommended as the best of the bunch to try deep dish and a location was conveniently located near our hotel. First, I had no idea that these deep dish Chicago pizzerias were more like chains (atmosphere reminded me of New York's UNO locations), which already creates this allure that there's nothing particular special or authentic about it. And while I must agree that message carried on through our meal, I still really loved the Chicago classic with sausage, veggies, ripened tomato, and crispy butter crust. There was just something comforting about it, rich but not overly so, solid cheese, tasty lean sausage, served nice and steamy. For the price the portion seems enormous, and although there's a bit of a cook-time wait, it's well worth the extra minutes.

I think we need to bury this age old battle of which pizza champions the other - they're different and satisfying in their own right. Now New Yorker's let's focus on educating the people like-minded to those who sat behind us, that you don't eat "three-cheese bread sticks with dipping sauce," before you eat a damn pizza.
Hhmmmmmm comfort food done well... very well. Tomatoes were very juicy, sausage amazing, crust crunchy. Just drool-worthy.
This place is great. Be prepared for a long wait but it's worth it. Definitely get the deep dish and order when you check in so the pie is ready when you are otherwise it take an hour to bake.

The line outside the building for dinner should tell you everything you need to know. Just Go! And bring your appetite! Huge pizza, huge tasty as hell pizza that explains all the talk about a deep dish pie. The buttery crust makes this one stand above the others. Worth the wait, and the belly ache

First time eating Deep Dish Pizza! A lot of people thought this was Illuminati Pizzeria, but it's Lou Malnati's Pizzeria :) There is indeed a long wait to get in and also to actually get your food.

We arrived on Saturday at 6PM and were told there would be an 1:15 wait, but we ended up getting in after 40 minutes. It generally takes 40 minutes for them to cook the deep dish, but they do try to start 20 minutes before you're actually seated if there's a long line.

We had garlic bread and a pitcher of sangria before eating -- both were decent but wasn't anything special. As for deep dish, we had the Chicago Classic and The Lou which were both amazing! I love how deep dish actually has a good amount of toppings beyond the tomato sauce and cheese instead of something like a few flakes of pepperoni. The Chicago Classic was filled with sausage and The Lou was filled with veggies and mushrooms. Oh god, getting hungry again writing this review...

We had a great experience overall, but were a little surprised that the pitcher of sangria was $30 at the end of the meal... Would still definitely come back again though!

pics.caption: Their garlic bread with cheese -- nothing particularly special but a good appetizer while waiting.
The Chicago Classic in the front and The Lou in the back, both amazing!

review.des:
Come here on Saturday evening around 5 pm and the wait for a group of 4 was only 20 min or so. They tell you to preorder the pizza because the deep dish takes about 30 min to get to the table. So I'd highly recommend doing so as well.

The malnati was great!!! Their sausage was rly yummy. The Lou was a little soggier for our tastes. We also made the mistake of ordering a Large and a Medium for just 4 ppl when the menu says it would normally feed 7 ppl. I was with pretty hungry young adult men so they were able to finish the majority though.

Fair warning, pizza snob here.

I just moved to Chi and am checking out all the pizza spots, Lou's is close to me so I gave it a shot this last Saturday evening.

Long wait for the pizza, expected this, so no problem there.  Got seating at the bar, drink options pretty standard.  The place ooozes a touristy feeling, I suppose this is also to be expected.

Got the classic chicago, it has a layer of cheese, sausage, then sauce on top.  The crust was great, very buttery and crisp.  Though before I even took a bite I was pretty certain the tomatoes were frozen, just from the appearance.  I am pretty sure that I'm right after tasting.

The sausage was also clearly not fresh, or high quality.  It honestly seemed like that cheap stuff they throw on pizza in high school cafeterias.

To me, you have to use quality, fresh ingredients to set your pizza place apart.  I know Lou's is cashing in on the tourist factor and long lasting name.  But as a local (new), I'll be taking my visiting family members to Pequod's in order to show them deep dish in the city.
I am not a big deep dish fan, but this place is the best one I've had. UNOs is good too, but this was a little bit better. The place that starts w/ a G is not good at all.

I usually don't gravitate towards deep dish, but when in Chicago, you gotta.  All of my Chi-town friends said to go to Lou's, and I see why.  It was great!  The crust, in particular, was buttery and crispy, and maintained its crispiness even on the bottom underneath all the sauce.  Speaking of the sauce, it was fresh, tasty, and the right amount.  I was afraid the cheese would be too much, but the balance between it and the sauce was perfect.  The personal size was a good amount, too, and the bf had one slice leftover from the small size.  So, I wouldn't say I'm converted to Team Deep Dish, but when in Chicago, this is a great choice for a tasty deep dish pizza meal.

* Tourist trap. Overrated alert. *

Ordered  : The "Lou"
Taste  : 5/10 - Nothing special.
Service  : 2/10 - Long wait times in every regard.
Ambiance : 8/10
Overall  : 3/10

Would I return? No!

Amazing experience at Lou's. It was a wet and cold day yesterday but we found comfort and delicious food at Lou's. You should trust all the hype about this. The service was excellent - shout out to Anna! We ordered a salad (so we wouldn't feel too badly about ourselves), a small deep dish with sausage and spinach, and a pepperoni with peppers thin crust pizza. Everything was delicious, including the salad. I live in New York and love New York style pizza but after visiting Lou's I'm now questioning my loyalty...

pics.caption: Deep dish with sausage and spinach

review.des: My group of 5 came here after eating lunch and we were all so full. However, we had to come try out the famous Lou Malnati Pizza. We ordered the Malnati Chicago Classic and The Lou. You can just see the melted cheese oozing out. The pizza was good. I liked the classic more than the Lou but they were both very good.

I stopped in last night (5/9). A good 15 minute walk from Michigan Ave. I found an open seat at the bar and was quickly acknowledged with a welcome and a menu. A small deep dish with sausage and cheese caught my eye. A half hour later but worth the wait. A bite into the slice was the crunch. It was delicious. You have two screens at the bar where I watched half of the Rockets vs. Jazz game. I would come again. It was also highly recommended by other visitors in the City. Thank you.

On our trip to Chicago, we just had to try deep dish Chicago pizza. After researching many pizza joints, we decided to try Lou's.

We shared a personal sized pizza and side salad. It may seem like not a lot of food, but it was the perfect amount for us. Being tourists, we didn't want leftovers, as we were continuing our day in the city and didn't want to take food with us.  The pizza was very filling and rich. I'm not a huge fan of deep dish pizza in general. I am more of a thin crust person. However, this was a good deep dish pizza experience. The crust was crispy and buttery, sauce was tasty and not too salty. The cheese was good quality, not too rubbery. I liked the long string of cheeses that come off the pizza when you try to eat it. The server gave us the heads up that the pizza would take 30 minutes, which we were prepared for and fine with. Good quality food takes time.

If looking for the Deep dish Chicago experience, I recommend this place.

pics.caption: Come here for the Chicago deep dish experience.
Crust was buttery and cooked just right.

review.des: Great experience, very good pizza. Caesar salad was unique and very good. Sangria was above average. Sports memorabilia was awesome, especially the Larry Bird jersey. A little expensive.
This is one of those things you kinda have to do when you come to Chicago.  The pizza is good (I wouldn't say amazing).  Keep in mind it is super crowded but they've got a system to manage to crowds.

If I'm getting pizza it's here. Better then imos pizza and I'm serious. If you aren't from Chicago you have to try the deep dish - butter crust always as well. Every time I'm in Chicago I order ! Over and over I probably eat this once a week at least
Very good deep dish pizza. Takes about 45minutes - 1 hour for your pizza but worth the wait once you get it. My husband and I ordered a medium and we had left overs.

14 years ago loved Lou Malnati's, and always recommended friends visiting Chicago to male sure they go to this restaurant.  14 years later, waited over an hour in line, their own app bumped me and everyone else back by a spot when we were close to being seated, and the food was jus not what it used to be.  I ordered same.exact pizza with same exact toppings, the crust could barely be cut, especially on the edges, and later, the whole family felt sick.  Too bad, it used to be such a great place.

Wow! Great pizza, great salad, great tiramisu. Amazing service. We ordered delivery to the Embassy Suites. My Uncle showed up after we placed our order and I called for another pie. Since our original order was almost ready, they didn't want to compromise the quality of the pizza and didn't want me to wait for the other pizzas. So they removed the delivery fee for the second pizza. It's the little things. Totally recommend to ANYONE.

This joint is located in the busy streets of downtown Chicago. They have various sitting arrangements from outdoors to inside dining along with bar section. That day I ordered "The Lou" which is a veggie deep dish pizza and has Spinach mix (enhanced with garlic, basil & onion), mushrooms and sliced Roma tomatoes covered with three cheeses, on a garlic Buttercrust. The pizza took around 45mins to arrive but it was definitely worth the wait. Lots of melted cheese and tomato flavours which was enticing to taste buds.

Food:9/10
Service:7/10
Ambiance:8/10

pics.caption: The Lou - Spinach mix (enhanced with garlic, basil & onion), mushrooms and sliced Roma tomatoes covered with three cheeses.

review.des: I don't love pizza and don't love deep dish...and the pizza was very good! I preferred the the Lou over the Classic, but both were great!

Came here to try deep dish pizza for the first time even though I've been to Chicago a few times. This place was recommended to me by my friend who said it was the best pizza he's had.

So I came in and expected big things...

We ordered the spinach bread and two personal sized pizzas. One was the classic with their lean sausage and the other was the spinach and cheese one.

I actually liked the taste of it but maybe deep dish isn't my thing because I felt it was too much crust. I am more into thin crusts and also Neapolitan style.

The pizzas did come quite slowly but we were warned.
Additionally, the stuffed spinach bread was quite delicious.

Staff was nice and quick to see if we needed anything.

Value 4/5 taste 4/5 service 4/5 ambiance 4/5
I just rec'd 4 pizzas in the mail from Lois for my birthday. And I live in idaho! Thanks lou! Not as good as fresh out of the oven but beats not having any!

pics.caption: Mmm. Crustless pie? Thanks for shipping to idaho!

review.des:
Tourist review.  I am not a pizza fan but this is by far my favorite pizza place in Chicago.

The pizza had a huge layer of huge pepperoni chunks, cheese, and sauce to top it all off. It would have probably tasted better if I didn't have it delivered but I'm still not complaining. The pizza came with a small pool of juice from the tomatoes.

The pizza oozed with melted cheese. Every bite was a nice burst of pepperoni or sausage. The pizza sauce on top added a well balanced of moisture making the whole pizza easy to eat.

Would I go again? Yes!!!! First time around, I bought 2 frozen pizzas to bring back to LA.
It's Lou Malnati's!!!!  A must visit when in Chicago and the obvious reason being their amazing deep dish pizza.

Definitely my favorite deep dish place in Chicago. I'm not a huge fan of deep dish in general, but I'll eat at Lou's any time.

This place is fun as hell. Loud, crowded, and the perfect atmosphere to sit around a couple of pitchers and delicious pies. The butter crust here is delicious, and really makes the pies tasty.

I'm a big fan of the Malnati Chicago Classic, which has sausage and extra cheese. I've had it with added pepperoni and jalapeños too. The "Lou" is also fantastic, despite the fact that it contains no meat. It's really a special pie that tastes amazing, so I recommend you try it even if you are a dyed in the wool carnivore like me.

For an appetizer, I recommend the buffalo wings. They are fried really crispy, tossed in a delicious sauce, and are totally awesome.

Lou's is the real deal, with great food and a really fun venue to boot. Highly recommended.

Sorry for the short review but I've only had this pizza delivered. I have no idea about the actual restaurant and how their service is. I had the deep dish sausage pizza and it was very bland! No flavor at all. I'm not sure why this place has a good rating...it was not good.

This is my first time having deep dish pizza in Chicago. I heard about Loui Malnati's being the place to go, so it was worth a try. When we came, we were told the wait would be about 30 minutes for seating (it was really about 5 which was nice). Pizza takes at least 30 minutes to be made, so it may be a good idea to call in advance or bring something to do/be prepared to entertain yourselves for awhile. We tried a small 1/2 Lou 1/2 Classic Chicago (charge is for the more expensive of the 2), which is good portion size for two people.

The Lou itself had copious amounts of cheese, which was nice intermixed with some spinach, mushrooms, and tomatoes. I do think I like the classic better because of the rich flavor. Note that the sausage seems to be one large flat piece of sausage (rather than smaller pieces). The butter crust, was indeed more buttery than most, but not as amazing as it sounds, unfortunately.

I don't have much to say about this place. It's a rite of passage to try deep dish in Chicago and yes, it was good, but I'm not dying to come back.
Ordered in, really good food! Worth the drive and wait.

I love pizza. All kinds of pizza. And Lou Malnati's Pizza was very unique but I'm not quite sure it lived up to its hype. Of course when you're in Chicago, you are told to must try deep dish pizza. My impression of deep dish was thick dough and little toppings. I was wrong. At Lou's, the dough was actually not super thick and the toppings were layer upon layer! There's a wait though.....a long one. Definitely go there and put your name on the list then go shopping or walk around. Don't go hungry expecting to eat right away. Their system is very efficient though. They'll call you when they're ready and you also pre-order your pizza so it is already cooking by the time you sit down.

The pizza itself was pretty good. They're know for their butter crust which was the most interesting part. We got the Classic and it had sausage, pepperoni, cheese and lots of tomato sauce. Overall, it was crunchy on the edges, fluffy in the middle, piping hot and amazing on the top. The medium doesn't look like a lot when it comes out but after two slices I was stuffed. I also got a bowl of their minestrone soup which was very well made. Full of beans and lots of spices. This place is definitely worth a try if you're in Chicago but I wouldn't go back again just to have their pizza.
You can never go wrong, but PLEASE make a gluten free deep dish already! Drinks inside are dated and not great so I always stick to beer and wine now. Love lous!

I was in Chicago for the first time, so of course I had to check out the famous Lou Malnati's - it did not disappoint! I went on a weekday a little before noon and thought it was odd that there was barely anyone in the restaurant. However, 30 minutes later, the restaurant was completely full and a line had formed. I've never been a huge fan of deep dish pizza, mainly because the crust is always too dense. While the crust on this pizza was indeed thick like traditional deep dish, it was light, buttery, and absolutely delicious. The toppings were also fresh and generously distributed. Lou Malnati's made me realize I actually do like deep dish pizza and I'll definitely be back next time I'm in Chicago.
The service was very sub-par, it was noisy and crowded. However, the pizza is delicious. I highly recommend the Lou with butter crust. Very yummy.

This is the REAL DEAL- Chicago Deep Dish Pizza.  There are others places in Chicago that serve this Chicago style pizza, but this is ONE OF THE BEST- right up there with a few others at the VERY TOP.  

Excellent food and not expensive.  BUT - be aware it takes TIME to cook one of these signature deep-dish pizzas all the way through, immutable laws of physics being what they are...  so either plan on sitting around for a while with your friends after you order, or PHONE AHEAD and they can get your order into the oven before you arrive.

If someone asks me, "Wanna go to Malnati's?" my answer is ALWAYS **HELL YES**!!
Loveeeee their buttery crust! What I dreamt Chicago deep dish pizza would taste like!! We got their Original which had a giant sausage patty the whole size of the pizza!

OMG, one of my favorite pizzeria restaurants in Down town Chicago. Lou Malnatis ranks in my top 3 Chicago Deep Dish pizzas. The best way to order is select your pizza at the counter before you are seated.  This location has two levels so it was extremely busy; even for a Wednesday evening. My family and I waited for about forty minutes to be seated. Since I ordered a large and smaller pizza, it took longer than usual.

The server was polite, however she was at times distracted and forgot about check ins and drink refills. That would be my only negative. The pizza was fantastic.. no survivor slices were spared. If you decide to visit this location, prepare to drive and find a parking garage unfortunately.

No free parking options are available. I found a meter and paid $4.00 for a 2 hour park on the street. There are however many other locations city wide, but most are call in and pick up only (no dine in). The noise level was loud because the dining area is not very big. Again, Great Pizza! Recommend. ..Absolutely :)

Every time I tell somebody I live in Chicago, they ask which club I'm in: Lou's or Giordano's. I can now say I support Lou Malnati's!

I ordered a personal Chicago Classic pie with added Roma tomatoes for delivery, and I was not disappointed.

First off, the butter crust is absolutely delicious. Probably my favorite deep dish crust I've ever had, and I was pretty in love with Patxi's (in California) version. This version is sweet and flaky, almost like half crust and half pastry. Unfortunately though, like pastry, it got a bit soggy. I thought it was the moisture from the tomatoes, but from reading others' similar reviews it sounds like the mozzarella is so moist that it bleeds into the crust and doesn't keep it crispy. I didn't mind it terribly, though; it was still delicious.

The cheese is fresh, well-melted, and perfectly portioned. There was plenty of it, but I never felt like I was getting just a mouthful of goop.

Toppings were SUBLIME. That sausage is one of the best I've had on pizza, and the Roma tomatoes were exquisitely fresh. You can tell that they put a lot of care into their ingredients, and it pays off!

I really didn't notice any sauce underneath my tomatoes, and from what I read in other reviews the sauce layer is pretty thin. But what amount there is, I was happy with it because I felt that the pie had a great amount of depth in flavor and seasoning. Lots of different notes going on.

The delivery was at the tail end of the 15-minute window I asked for when I ordered online, but still on time. I would certainly order from Lou Malnati's again!

So all Chicagoans swear by this place. I think it's awful - but I've only lived here for a year, so I guess it takes multiple horrid winters to make you love this strange sort of cheese soup the locals call pizza. The wait is super long, this place is vastly overhyped. Portions are huge. Maybe it's better delivered?.. not coming back here, even if out of town guests want to try deep dish pizza.

-1 star for the wait. On a Tuesday night, 30 minutes to get seated, 15 minutes for appetizers to come out, 50 minutes for the pizzas to come out.

My friend put our name down, so we got there right when were getting seated. Lou Malnati's was my first deep dish pizza experience and it's equal to or better than regular pizza. I could see myself getting tired of it really quick. But I loved the crust! I NEVER eat crust because its always so bland and not worth the extra calories, but it was so soft and butter here, I couldn't resist.

We ordered the dip as an appetizer, the small Lou deep dish pizza, and the large Malnati Chicago Classic™ for 4 people. We ended up taking home most of the small pizza.

3/4 of us had drinks and the bill came out to be $82. Even with the drinks, it's a little pricey for pizza..

pics.caption: Slice of a Medium pepperoni deep dish

review.des:
I had been to this location before, about four years ago with a friend, and I was in town tonight and wanting some deep dish pizza so I did takeout.

I first stopped at Gino's East nearby but it was an hour+ wait for takeout, so instead I went here. They have personal-sized pies for about $10 (one topping) which was nice, I just wanted a smaller pizza for myself.

Only took a half-hour so I was happy. Tasty pizza too.

pics.caption: Personal sized mushroom deep dish pizza

review.des: Best Deep Dish in Chicago! If you are waiting on a table, tell them your order so you can get your pizza when you sit down. The bartenders were playful and made some great drinks. Our group had the deep dish cheese - can't go wrong and the deep dish sausage and pepperoni- my favorite

First time in Chicago means you must try deep dish. My friend and I waited about 30 minutes after getting their early around 5pm. I like that they have a wait time app to see where you are in line. You place and order at the front if you want to get deep dish and all the other appetizers when you sit down. When we got our table, our deep dish still took a while as if we hadn't placed it earlier. We were waiting for some time. The pizza itself was pretty good. Use your hands and bite into it so you can get the experience of eating deep dish instead of using a knife and fork. I still prefer NY thin crust pizza, but definitely fun to eat and experience.

Lou's is a staple in the landscape of Chicago pizza. If you aren't ordering deep dish- you're doing it wrong.
Always hot, always fresh, always friendly.

The big ole debate isn't necessary, as pizza is pizza and all pizza is good in my book.

HOWEVER, this pizza accomplishes rare form, as it's even better a day later than when first out of the oven - and it's pretty legit fresh. I admire their tomato sauce the most and believe their cheese to be heavenly (when pulling a slice, the strings create an actual gateway into heaven).

A Chicago classic and I don't have any insight into distinguishing features of one deep dish over another . I got the Lou's (the vegetarian one) and it was phenomenal. Cheesy, saucy goodness mixed with a great crunchy crust, I wasn't disappointed. The best part is, deep dish pizza is better next day pizza than normal pizza and the couple slices of Lou's I had left over were a great next day snack. If you are in Chicago, you can't go wrong with a trip to Lou's

I really don't know what's the hype on this place. It's not the best pizza. Maybe the clean dinning and friendly staff. $18 for pizza it's just okay not the best. Other places in Chicago has better pizza and taste is yummy

Long overdue, but wanted to write a review for Lou Malnati's outstanding service. I mistakenly ordered a pizza with pork on it, and only realized it upon getting back to my place. I called them and asked if there was anything they could do about it. Without hesitation, the manager said to just come back and they'd get us the right pizza. No questions asked, right off the bat. The pizza was great as it always is, but the service here is what truly made it exceptional.

This was my first ever deep dish pizza and when I asked someone for a recommendation as to where to eat my first, I got a resounding Lou's from every one of them.

We came here pretty late on a Friday and expected a long wait. Our wait ended up only being a little more than an hour. We were able to easily get to the bar to get drinks while we waited and even ordered our pepperoni deep dish (I had not previously known this was ordinary since the pizza takes so long to cook).

Once we sat down we ordered another round of drinks and a salad. The reason I knocked a star off is because the second drink (Moscow Mule) I received was not very good. I continued to drink it as I really dislike complaining at a restaurant unless absolutely necessary. I think instead of vodka, gin was used.

We ordered the Malnati Salad and it was really good. We all expected to eat a little bit then prepare for our pizza, but I am pretty sure we all went back for at least seconds. The salad was in a giant bowl and was perfect for a table to share.

Finally came the moment we were all waiting for, the ZA! I was mesmerized by it and was very happy when the first slice out landed on my plate. It had the absolute perfect ratio between crust, sauce, cheese, and pepperoni. My eyes were bigger than my stomach and I assumed I would eat 2 slices. I barely made it through the first and was completely full and satisfied.

Their large pizza was the perfect amount for 4 people, we had 3 women and 1 guy.

I will definitely be coming back to Lou's next time I am in Chicago!
It's pretty good!  Not something I'll ever crave, but I suppose one of those things you gotta do when in Chicago

Really busy when we went there. Messed our table up - called us once and we didn't hear it. Took phone number down incorrectly so didn't text us. We preordered our pizza which was cold when it hit our table. All handled well by the manager. Second pizza was very good.

Lou's never disappoints and that's what is so great about the place. I wish you could make that magically delicious pizza come out faster. But it's like my dad used to say, "you can't rush perfection!"

Downside is obviously the wait time to get a table, and the wait time for actual pizza. The server could have been nicer.
By far, the best pizza I've ever had. Buttery thick crust, delicious tomato sauce, top notch ingredients... Try the brucetta too...so delicious

Not a fan of them, and it disappoints me to say the least. Everyone I've talked to has raved and awarded Lou Malnati's with the title of having the best deep dish pizza in Chicago, so I had some pretty high expectations going in. Maybe too high. I came here with my boyfriend for his birthday after our original reservations at a different restaurant had fallen through. Once we arrived, we were told it would be about an hour wait which I totally expect. It's what you have to deal with when you go to a popular restaurant, especially one that doesn't take reservations. We pre-ordered our pizza and decided to go with a medium classic. After about an hour, we got a text that our table was ready and headed upstairs.

At this point, I was expecting our pizza to come out pretty soon - after all, we had ordered in advance. However, this was not the case. After already waiting an hour, we then had to wait another hour to get our pizza. What's the point of pre-ordering then? I feel like they may have messed up our order, because I saw another table get their pizza relatively quickly after they sat down. Our server was very inattentive, and this just made the wait so much more annoying. He would serve the tables next to us and then just ignore us. He never checked up on us or gave us updates about how long the pizza would take.

About the pizza itself, I was not impressed either. I've had Giordano's and Pizano's before, and I enjoyed both of them so I was expecting this one to be even better. But this pizza was just so average in comparison. First, it was lukewarm when it came out. Second, it didn't even look that thick. The flavor was fine, but it was nothing special.

Overall, I will not be returning. Neither the pizza or service wow'ed me, so the search for my favorite deep dish will go on. If I ever do want to try Lou Malnati's again, I'm definitely going to order delivery and wait in the comfort of my own home.

Came to visit Chicago and was told to not leave without having deep dish pizza. Through good reviews, we found this place and I'm so glad we did! It was a Saturday night and pretty busy but the wait was so worth it. Would 100% recommend.

I've been to three of their locations. My favorite for ambiance is the one on Touhy, but for convenience and efficient service, I like the Lincoln Sq. location. The one on Wrightwood is TOO small and didn't serve all the items from the Touhy location, but that was a while back.

I like the lunch options and the quick lunch choices. Times for wait are pretty much accurate, though give 5 minutes on a busy day, such as the first day of spring/summer, or when a concert or sporting event nearby is happening. The seating is comfortable enough, and their menu offers plenty of options.

The pizza is pretty solid. I've had the personal, the thin, and the stuffed, in multiple topping variations. Haven't been disappointed once. It's cooked exactly how I ask and the same goes when I order pick up. I've used the app for pickup and haven't had any mistakes when ordering. I find it better tasting than Edwardo's, Giordano's and definitely steps above Pizza Hut, Dominoe's, Little Caesar's, etc.

Staff is pretty friendly and easy going, though there are times when a host isn't always readily available. If you call ahead and order so your food is ready when you arrive, they can do that for you as well.

Found out that I can order some Lou Malnati's pizza from tastesofchicago.com.

Since I didn't visit the pizzeria personally, I can't comment on service or ambiance. Based on taste alone, we were very happy. Our pizzas arrived all boxed up with dry ice. It was neatly and securely packed. Placed our pizzas in the freezer and when we were ready to enjoy them, we just followed their simple directions. Tried the Pepperoni, Sausage, Spinach, and Cheese. They were all delicious and made with quality ingredients. The crust was thin, buttery and crisp. The sauce was smooth, light, and flavorful. Quality ingredients are used and you can taste the difference. We are incredibly satisfied with our order.

I'm sure nothing beats actually being at Lou Malnati's Pizzeria, but for now this will do :D Yum!

Ate early dinner this past Sunday night, which was the Marathon day. They said it would be an hour 15 wait, but they called me in 45 minutes. This was the last positive thing that happened in the meal. I ordered wine and bruschetta for an appetizer. It came very quickly, which seemed good, except the bread was cold, and super crunchy. As well, I was done with the appetizer before the wine showed up. The pizza took a long time which was not really a problem, and it was expected. But the second glass of wine took even longer to show up. The deep dish pizza was good, but lots of places have good deep dish pizza. To me, this was not nearly as good as Uno's, or Due's, and even a step down from Giordano's. So, while the pizza was good enough, the service and the wait make Lou Malnati's low on the cost/benefit scale. Definitely not worth a repeat.
Pizza was great!  Small goof up with my sons order. But they fixed it quickly and gave him a complimentary dessert.

Second pizza spot while on my Chicago Pizza Tour. I had Giordano's two days ago. GIORDANDO's is wayyyyy better.

Something wasn't mashing with my tastebuds. I ordered the Malnati's Classic (not pictured). Bread crust was soggy and the tomato/marinara sauce was bland. I did like the extra mozzarella cheese embedded in the pizza. I'm glad I ordered a personal size because I would have hated to trash the whole thing.

Lastly,
I ordered the key lime pie hoping a dessert would redeem my experience but I was wrong. The cinnamon crust was a nice touch but overpowering.

The service was decent and we didn't have to wait long (Less than 20 minutes).

Overall, it's a must try for pizza lovers visiting Chicago. (Might have been a off day)

SN: My coworker enjoyed the Lou pizza but she did agree the bread crust was soggy. (Pictured)
I think the cheese to tomato sauce ratio is not as good as some of the others. The pasta was great but the deep dish wasn't good as far as we thought but to each their own.

A must stop when visiting Chicago! I can't help to notice the efficiency improvement they have adopted to enhance customer experience and shorten the lead then from the moment you check-in until pizza in your mouth.

Delish Chicago style deep dish pizza. Had The Lou and it was yummy!. The Cesar salad was a nice start to the meal along with the bruschetta. It could stand a drizzle of basalmic vinegar, however was still yummy.

I ordered the gluten free pizza with sausage and onion. I must say the sausage was great! The gluten-free crust was mediocre, which most gluten-free people are used to. My waitress would go MIA for 30 mins at a time, I would get no refill. I would have to stop other servers to get my more napkins, drink, etc. It wasn't until I saw my waitress walking back from McDonald's was when I was furious. I had to wait over 45 mins after eating to get a check. Let me you remind you that this place was not busy at all. It was during an off time in between dinner and lunch. Then the waitress came by and said that she would be in a meeting while we were receiving our pizza. Why would a restaurant schedule a staff meeting during operation hours?? I'm not sure how efficient this restaurant would be when busy if it wasn't efficient when it was empty.

I was told Lou's was the place to go for pizza when visiting Chicago  and wow! It was delicious! Service was great, place was clean and the spinach bread appetizer was so yummy. I will definitely be back.

Chicago staple.

I used to fight it and tell folks that Giordanos had better cheese to sauce ratio...

Hands down the most consistent deep dish pie in the city. Fabulous crust, gooey cheesy, and sausage that doesn't remind you that you ate it every 20 minutes thereafter. Lean, and easy eating (well for pizza at least)...

Just do it...

My wife and I tried 3 different Deep Dish pizzas in 3 days in order to be able to have a good opinion and to taste the difference between the competition.
By far and away Lou's was the best! The buttercrust and sauce make all the difference. The sauce was something from heaven. And a nice amount of cheese that didn't take control of the pizza.
Service was not notch!!

I would totally recommend.

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down. Because they are the best there is always a long wait. What Lou Malnati's does that's wonderful is they will take your order if you call ahead and put your pizza in the oven so that it is ready or almost ready when you do get a table and sit. So call ahead they are helpful!

You can't go wrong on what pizza you want. The Classic is always a great go to option if you have never been there before. If you create your own pizza always ask for the butter crust! They also are able to do gluten free crust for any food sensitivities someone in your family might have.

Stick to their recommendations I have found a large is just the perfect amount for four people and their is usually a piece left over. Eating two deep crust pieces is like eating four regular pizza slices anywhere else if you ask me. If you are dining in they will cut and serve the first slice for the family. So if you are in the area this is a must try!!

Lou is LEGENDARY. While Giordanos is also solid, Lou has just the right consistency for Deep Dish Pizza. The sauces and light amount of cheese in comparison to Giordanos makes it my choice for Deep Dish in Chicago.

To be honest I'm a New York pizza kinda of gal but Lou's may have changed my mind! I just moved to the city and I thought to myself the best way to get to know Chicago is through their food!! First stop : DEEP DISH! I went to Lou's with my family around lunch time, it was pretty packed but I love their system where they check you in and you can see your place in line. There was about a 27 min wait so we just headed over to the Starbucks down the block and I just kept checking their site to see how close I was in line. What a great idea.. a must for so many restaurants! We started off with a house salad, I tried the house sweet vinaigrette, it was so freaking yummy! What's even better is you can buy a bottle for 6.99 downstairs!! Ok so let's get to the real deal, the pizza... omgggg. SOOOOO YUMMY CHEESY AHHHHH. We got the Lou which is a deep dish with Roma tomatoes, spinach and mushrooms. It took a while to come out, even though we ordered ahead but it was so damn worth it! Everything worked so well together, the dough was just perfect crispy on the outside but soft and doughy on the inside. My mom, who hates pizza (weird, I know!) even said this pizza tasted really good! I shared it with my dad and it was the perfect amount for two. My mom had a chicken sandwich, it was nothing special but it came with fruits and cottage cheese which was nice. The service here was excellent, our waiters name was haired, not sure if I spelled it right but she was adorable and soo friendly. With how busy they are, I was really happy to see that they don't sacrifice service. I've had Gino's before and Lou's wins the deep dish battle for sure!

pics.caption: The Lou, terrible picture but still had to share!

review.des: This was my first deep dish experience and I was not disappointed at all. The pizza was excellent from the crust to the filling, paired well with an ice cold coke. Even though the wait time was quite long, it was amazing of them to have a system where you could put in your pizza order so when you sat down you barely waited. That was super clutch. I would recommend this place to tourists for sure.

SOLID Chicago pizza place...wow. I'm impressed!!!

This is the real deal. Yes, it's a chain, no, I don't usually go for that, but....YOU GOTTA TASTE THIS PIE.

Seriously. These are fresh, amazing, delicious pizza pies. We got the butter crust (c'mon, you gotta go all the way when you're visiting Chicago and only have one night to try pizza)! I think our pizza was the equivalent of the "kitchen sink" in some other shops, and I'd get it all over again even though I'm usually a one-topping gal.

With a pint of beer and a salad to start, I couldn't have been more pleased. The wait? Painful. The payoff? Amazingness.

Would wait in the cold all over again for Lou's pie. Anytime.

The worst service I've ever had. It took me over 20 minutes just for someone to approach my table. Some of the things I ordered didn't even come out. The dry pasta and pizza were mediocre. All my friends were excited try out this restaurant and it wasn't really all worth it.

2 advices - 1. Don't come here on an empty stomach like I did! You will starve to death waiting and stalking the poor waiters! Ordering ahead doesn't really help unless you are in for a very long wait for seating. 2. Don't order the individual size that serves 1. You won't get much of the toppings and the crust will hurt your mouth.

Other than the long wait, service was fine, something you'd expect from a pizza joint. Pizza was ok, I've had better even in Atlanta.. but definitely not worth the really long wait..

pics.caption: Individual the "Lou", not that interesting..I think the larger sizes are better

review.des: First time having Chicago deep dish and it did not disappoint. Never understood eating pizza with a fork and knife until digging into the beautiful pie we ordered. We went with the classic 'Lou' and devoured it. Our waiter Martin was from Uruguay and was incredibly friendly. Also had my very first dirty martini which i didn't regret.
I tried a piece of this pizza at Taste fest in Chicago. Yum. I have a couple Malnati's pizzas coming in this week from Goldbelly. That crust and sauce are great!

My go-to stop for chicago deep dish pizza.  Everyone has their favorite and Lou is what I crave.  The lunch special is a great deal and if you are happy with cheese or pepperoni, you can get a pizza pretty quickly.  I prefer the sauce used at Lou's but I am not a fan of the butter crust and go with the regular crust.  I say you need to come in and try and try the others.  I think you will stick with Lou's.

I had to try authentic deep dish pizza while in Chicago, so I came to Lou Malnati's. This place seems to be crazy busy, as I went twice and both times there were 45 minute waits to get a seat on a week night. I ended up ordering a pizza online for carryout, which worked well for me. I ordered a personal-sized deep dish pizza with sausage, green peppers, and fresh tomatoes. The pizza was amazing, so I'm glad I chose to try my first deep dish pizza here.

pics.caption: Personal deep dish pizza with sausage, green peppers, and tomatoes

review.des:
If you ask for a recommendation for a deep dish pizza in Chicago you will get a different answer each and every time. I personally chose Lou Malnati's for my first Chicago deep dish experience and it did NOT disappoint!

Walked in and the wait was 30 minutes, luckily I spotted 2 seats at the bar so we opted to sit there. Started off with a Goose Island Green Line while Boyfriend went with a Goose Island IPA. We split an individual salad with red wine vinaigrette and ranch on the side. I personally enjoyed drizzling both dressings on my portion of the salad and thought that it was enough for two. For pizza we ordered The Malnati Chicago Classic, a size small. It comes with sausage so we added green peppers and onions. The pizza was FRICKING AWESOME!! I fell in LOVE with the buttercrust, it was so crispy which is just the way I like it.

David offered awesome recommendations and took excellent care of us too!

The only downside is that it gets SLAMMED. Since we were sitting at the bar people kept coming up to order drinks and were standing around so it was tough for me to get out to use the restroom and when leaving. I would recommend ordering your pizza and picking it up.

I did not try any of the other deep dish pizza joints but I would HIGHLY recommend Lou Malnati's.
This pizza is a Chicago classic. Took away one star because we pre-ordered and it took over an hour and we were missing half of the order. Other than that it was very good and flavorful pizza.

Lou's deep dish is the best around. My cousins recently came to visit from Italy and couldn't get enough.

This pizza is the definition of Chicago deep dish. I have grown up ordering via delivery and in restaurant in the suburbs and am never disappointed. This location is no different.

When you order make sure to order uncut to keep the pizza warm and keep the cheese from sliding!

Was dying to try a Chicago Deep Dish! Our flight got us in around 7:30 pm so some of our dinner choices had already closed for the day. We decided on this joint, why not start off our Chicago trip with a deep dish. Delicious! Exceeded expectations and definitely will return!

We got the malnati salad and classic deep dish pizza. More than enough food for two people.

The pizza had a good mix of cheese, tomatoes,  and sausage.  Great buttery crust. Not as dense as other deep dishes we've had,  but that was kind of nice.  

Only downside to our experience were the distracted servers.  More concerned with layout of tables than trending to customers.

I'll start off by saying that I'm a NYC pizza kinda gal. I like pizza so of course I have to try the deep dish. When in Rome right?

So the wait wasn't too bad although we got there early-ish. We waited about 15 minutes but soon after, the wait time was around an hour plus. Then when we sat down, the waitress told us that the pizza would take half an hour to make after we ordered. It took 45 minutes for the pizza to come out and it wasn't hot! Tisk tisk tisk!! I would expect it piping hot if it's made to order... out of the oven and served immediately. That was a bit of a disappointment bc the cheese held together and wasn't melting as expected.

The pizza was good.. just good. Never ate pizza with a fork and knife but it's a must with a deep dish.

This was my first time trying deep-dish in Chicago, although I've had a few run-ins with deep dish in San Francisco (Little Star, Patxi's). From word of mouth, I heard the best way to order is to-go, then pick it up because pizzas usually take 45 minutes to come out. Good suggestion because it's the perfect walking distance from Navy pier, Millennium Park, and other sightseeing touristy spots. When I arrived at the original Lou Manalti's, there was a crowd of people and probably a 30-40 minute wait on a Wednesday night, which attests to its popularity.

I got the Chicago Classic - lean sausage, tomato sauce, cheese on buttercrust - and it was good, but nothing life-changing. The sausage overpowers the other ingredients, so I didnt pick up the sauce flavor that much and the cheese was kind of just there. Again, pizza was good, but I guess my expectations were a little higher.

Hands down the best pizza I've ever had!  I saw the yelp reviews online and had to try it on my first night in Chicago.   We sat down and our server immediately let us know that the pizza takes at least 35 minutes to cook.  We ordered the malnati salad while we waited for our malnati chicago pizza.  

I expected the pizza to be good but I was surprised by how amazing the salad was too!  I'm not sure what kind of dressing it was, but it was the perfect balance of tangy and sweet.  The salami bits added a perfect crunch to it as well.  When the pizza came out I was blown away, the cornmeal crust is seriously a home run.  I'm officially in love with deep dish pizza.

Our meal was so great that we went back to a different Lou Malnati's location on our last night and ordered the same thing.  Service at both locations was friendly and attentive.  You have to try the pizza here if you haven't yet!

Located near a corner with outdoor seating (too cold and windy for us to eat outside on a Saturday when we visited), my husband and I came here for a late lunch a little before 2:30 pm. There was a wait even this later in the day. We waited 22 minutes for a table, which wasn't too bad. While we waited, an employee told us that we could actually put in an order for our pizza so that it will be ready by the time we are seated (you can only put in your order for pizza only, which is great because it does take some time for it to be made).

So 22 minutes later, we were seated with menus in hand and ended up ordering:

Spinach Salad, $9.25 prior to tax- I asked for the dressing (balsamic dressing) to be on the side, which is how it came. This salad was a good size for 2 people to share and came with thinly sliced pears (added a nice sweet taste), some crumbled goat cheese and sliced red onions. I thought this salad was good, but would have preferred grilled onions.

The Malnati Chicago Classic, Small Size, $14.95 prior to tax- If you come to Lou Malnati's, you have to get the Chicago classic. This deep dish masterpiece is topped with sausage, roma tomato marinara and extra cheese. Toppings are simple, but so perfect together(but you can add extra toppings at an additional cost if you want more). The small size gives you 4 large pieces (our server cut and served the pizza for us) and honestly could probably feed 3 people (you only need to eat one slice because it is really filling). The cheese is so oozey and wished I had more it. This is a must order!

Chocolate Chip Pizza, Individual Serving, $3.35 prior to tax- Not that I had much room for dessert, but I still wanted something sweet to end this meal. So my husband and I opted to share an individual serving. This serving really is perfect for 1 person (or 2 full people). The cookie and ice cream was a good match and would love to order the larger serving ($6.65 prior to tax, serves 2-3 people). By the way, if you want to order this dessert, let your server know ahead of time because it does take some time to make.
---------------------------
(Total= $29.75 after tax, prior to tip)

Wow this meal was delicious!

Even though a local Chicagoan (whom I met on the plane on my way back to Southern California) told me that Lou Malnati's is just "decent", I still think this place is pretty good. I would definitely come back here again the next time I am in Chicago.

By the way, the women's restroom on the 1st floor has 1 stall (was clean on this visit) but the women's restroom on the 2nd floor has 3 stalls (and was clean on this visit)

pics.caption: Spinach Salad, Salad Dressing On The Side (as requested), $9.25 prior to tax

review.des: Great Chicago Pizza, this place was recommended by a few friends, it is really good deep dish Pizza

The wait is pretty ridiculous. And the ladies at the front need to get their sense of time more accurate. 5 minutes was more like 30 minutes..
I was expecting rainbows & unicorns explosion in my mouth based in how popular this place was.. Well, it was good but I won't wait 2 hours for  deep dish pizza.. the stuffed spinach & cheese bread was pretty good though. But again not something I would wait that long for..
It was actually really spacious inside with an upstairs too. The waiter was friendly enough and kind of efficient. I can imagine it being stressful working there being so busy.
Overall it was OK.. Nothing special despite the hype. Definitely filling and good to eat when you're hungry  (maybe that was the strategy) but sadly not worth the wait.

Despite my love for Chicago and living here, I've never warmed up to deep dish pizza (I still consider it a doughier lasagna). However, if I had to deep dish, I would definitely go with Lou's. It's not too heavy, and it has a nice pan crust that gives it edge a wonderful crispiness.

While in Chicago we were told to try this place for some amazing deep dish pizza. We came in on a Saturday night and seen people all around waiting. We were told the wait was a two hour wait so we grabbed some beers and waited.

When you walk up to the location it looks like a small restaurant but they have an upstairs and some setting in the back. We looked over the menu and placed our pizza order ahead of time so by the time we got seated it wasn't a long wait.

The Malnati Chicago Classic - Made with Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust. It was awesome! Great taste, sausage was very good and ingredients tasted very fresh. Very cheesy and crust was great.

Buffalo wings - very tasty and just the right amount of spice. Had a side of blue cheese and ranch with some celery. They were also very good.

The wait might have been long but it was very worth it. The later you get there the shorter the line gets. If around the area stop by and enjoy some deep dish.

pics.caption: A slice of a great pie.
The Malnati Chicago Classic Made with Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust.

review.des:
Honestly, I don't know what luck I had coming here when I did because my partner and I got seated right away, no wait, around 5 pm on a Saturday! There is always a great debate as to which place has the best deep dish in the city. In my opinion, Lou's classic deep dish is just the perfect melange of cheese, sauce, sausage, and a delicious buttery crust. The buttery crust seems to be a point of contention but I would say that it is what makes Lou's better than the rest.

Beyond the delicious pizza, the three cheese bread here is a great appetizer to munch on while you wait for your pizza. The service here is just great. Our server was friendly and very accommodating. The most annoying thing that you might run into here is the wait to get a table. Basically, when we left, there was a line around the street corner, which is pretty crazy. If this is your only time visiting Chicago, it probably is worth the wait. Otherwise, I would highly suggest coming at an off-time before the dinner rush or just take out.

Excellent Chicago Deep Dish pizza. Awesome first Chicago deep dish pizza. If you are in town I would say this is the place to go. The sausage and pepperoni combo on "The Lou" is the way to go. Just delish

We ordered a small sausage deep dish, small thin crust, and house salad. The crust was delicious on the deep dish and I liked the ratio of crust, cheese, and sauce. Although I liked Malnati's pizza more overall, I do prefer Giordano's sauce.

Pizza was so good! The butter crust was amazing! Just got classic deep dish. Normally I don't like sausage either but man I couldn't get enough of the flavor! I didn't have any more room, but I wish I could have taken a pizza home with me. Will be returning any time I'm in Chicago! I didn't give 5 stars only because the service wasn't great- we waited a good 10 minutes before even getting a hello, and another 5 for our waters... but she was at least nice!

My first time here, amazing Deep Dish as promised.  I want to say our server Angie is a 5 star server. She was attentive,   knowledgeable and on point. When you come to this establishment ask for her; guarantee you will not be disappointed.

Let me start off by saying I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza; however, Lou Malanti's completely changed my perspective.

I'm used to eating very heavy deep dish pizza, but the pizza here was not heavy at all.

Food:
I ordered the personal classic, which came with lean sausage, cheese, and tomato sauce on a "Buttercrust."

Best deep dish I ever had!  The crust is very tasty and not heavy!

Sides Notes

Ambiance:
This place is on the noisy side.

Service:
The person who took my order over the phone was so friendly and offered really good customer service; however, when I went in to pay for my food, the cashier (a different person than the one taking orders over the phone) was not polite and friendly.

Overall:
Definitely try the deep dish!

YUM ALWAYS. The Lou is the best - vegetarian with large tomato slices, spinach, cheeses, and a few more toppings. I'm a meat lover but I always opt for The Lou because it's so good. The brownies that come as a dessert with catered food are AMAZING. I have legit called and asked if I could just order brownies. Fun fact: you can.... if you're looking to feed 12 people.  Exceptional Chicago-style deep dish.

What a horrible way to start my Chicago pizza journey.
They say Lou Malanati's is the best pizza in Chicago but I beg to differ.
We got the large pizza with the buttery crust which is extra and I can only say that I was disappointed.
The pizza has no flavor to it. It literally just cheese, sauce, and bread. The pizza came out cold and our waiter was inattentive. I won't be coming back

I am not a big deep-dish pizza person but when in Chicago....

I have been to a few of the different pizza spots in Chicago and Lou Malnati's is definitely my favorite when it comes to deep-dish. The atmosphere is casual with tvs and sports memorabilia on the walls. They have lunch specials on the weekdays where you can get a personal pizza or half sandwich with a salad or soup. This location in particular gets really crowded so try to come for an early lunch or dinner to avoid waiting.

For the deep dish pizzas, there are different sizes as well as different types that you can order or even build your own pizza. It takes about 40-45 minutes for it to cook so make sure you aware if you are on a time crunch and order some appetizer if you are hungry. My favorites are the Stuffed Spinach Bread and the Combination Platter, especially the cheddar cubes on the platter. As for pizza, my favorites are the "Lou" and the "Classic" with adding pepperoni.

So if you are in Chicago, make sure you stop by here to get your deep-dish fix!

Best deep-dish, hands down.  I'm a Chicago native and Lou's gets it right.  Not too much cheese.  Not too much sauce (and no heartburn).  Not too much crust.

Nothing beats the spinach + butter crust + extra garlic.  Nothing.

My sister & I went there on a Sunday night at 9 PM. There was a wait, but luckily we found two seats at the bar. Service was a bit slow and he wasn't as attentive since our drinks were empty most of the time. Wait time for pizza is around 40-45 mins. We ordered the Manalti Chicago Classic.

I wasn't thoroughly impressed. Maybe because I am more of a NY pizza kind of girl? The flavor was alright, but nothing to write home about.

This location could stand to make several improvements and can't say I would recommend it to my worst enemy. When I arrived I was told it would be a 40 minute wait by the hostess outside. I asked her if the bar was first available and she said that it was. As I started to walk in I decided to put my name on the list just in case searing opened up. We'll within 10 minutes I got a text that my table was ready so not quite sure what the 40 minutes was about. When I reported back to the hostess outside she told me I needed to go inside. The server inside told me I needed to go upstairs. It seems like there should be a better process for this. Upstairs I was seated and couldn't help but notice there were at least 6 or 7 tables available. Jacob came and took my order. He told me it would be almost an hour for the pizza. I ordered a personal pepperoni deep dish with the signature buttercrust. The wait was about 50 minutes as he said. While waiting I wanted to charge my phone. I couldn't help but notice there were electrical sockets in the ceiling but none were at the tables that customers could access while they waited for their hour. Also the restaurant was uncomfortably cold in temperature. When Jacob brought the pizza out it was not what I had ordered. It was a cheese and not a pepperoni. I had to get up from the table to find Jacob to tell him. He did offer to make the correct one but I was done at this point and just wanted to leave. I would recommend skipping this location and trying one of the other Lous. I hear the one on State street is good but this one is for the birds!

We ordered the Lou, a vegetarian pizza.  It was Cheesy with a capital C.  The sauce was delicious.  The pizza was tasty and soft.  It was more filling than it looked.  We could barely finish a small pizza (9 inches) between the two of us.  Boy, we were glad that we only ordered a personal sized green salad as app.

A star is deducted because a server led the couple before us to their table, then left us waiting for a good 15 to 20 minutes.  I inquired with the greeter about our table.  A small table magically became available instantaneously.  It seemed to me that the vacant table had been available, yet the servers were too busy to let the greeter know, so we waited longer at the front unnecessarily.

pics.caption: The Lou (small size $16.95) - picture shows a quarter of a small Lou pizza
House salad. $5.75.  Personal size is perfect as a shared appetizer for 2 people

review.des: In my experience at this restaurant all of these previous reviews become invalidated. Dreadfully, the Lou Malnati's Pizzeria experience was terrible. The tomato sauce overpowered everything, I didn't order a tomato soup. My last two comments are; this pizza joint is at par to Walmart pizza, secondly, Giordano's is recommended if you are thinking of trying a new spot.

The Chicago deep dish pizza here was the best pizza I have ever had so far in the United States. As for the first time we came, and never had a chance to try a deep dish style, the restaurant seemed to offer so many options. Fortunately, our waitress told us it was possible to order half-half. Thus, we came out with Deep Dish Malnati Chicago Classic on one half, and Deep Dish The Lou on the other half. It took 45 minutes to for the pizza to be done, but it was entirely worth the wait. The buttery crust, the topping, the marinara sauce, and a generous amount of quality Mozzarella cheese, all combined deliciously in an excellent pizza. The crust, the edge was scrumptious as it was crunchy and was took out of the oven just at the right time. I definitely will go to this restaurant for pizza craving and bring my friends here. Plus, the parking spot here is private and free.

Ordered online pickup through yelp. Didn't get any notifications for 2 hours. Had to call the restaurant to see if my order was ready. Either make sure your online ordering system works properly or don't have one at all

This was a great find.  My friend told me about this place.  It fills up in the afternoon, the staff is friendly.  We sat at the bar, there are plugs to charge phones and what not, and hooks to hang bags and purses.  The prices are not bad, but the food is yummy

This was one of our stops on a food tour. Had the pepperoni pizza, really enjoyed it a lot. The crust was excellent and the sauce was not sour or acidic. Lots and lots of mozzarella cheese. Very flavorful. Menu is varied and they have salads, pastas, and thin crust pizza. Next time I am in Chicago we are returning for sure.
100% pizza. You could taste real tomatoes, fresh cheese with supreme meat on a deliciously seasoned crust. Purely amazing period.
It's pretty overrated. The pizza was flavorless and service wasn't great. Not a great first experience of Chicago deep dish pizza.

My FAVORITE deep dish pizza in Chicagoland! I brought my mom when she was visiting from out of town (a New York who was totally against deep dish at first), she liked it so much she asked to go back 2 days later and now we visit every time she's in town.

It's also awesome that they let you order pizza before you sit... Make sure to try the Lou Maknati's salad as well!!

You can't visit Chicago and not get a deep dish. We got the classic with sausage, tomatoes, pepperoni, and the world famous buttery crust. Now I don't usually like deep dish, but I knew it'd be sacrilegious to get the thin crust, and I'm glad I went with my got! The pizza was delicious, the sausage was seasoned perfectly, and the buttery crust was heaven. They also have a waiting system that notifies you on your phone when it's time to be seated and you can order your pizza ahead of time to optimize pizza eating time. Next time I come I'll definitely have to try their chocolate chip pizza for dessert
A good pizza but location could use some cleaning.  Server was good.  Be prepared to wait at least 30 minutes for your pie.  That is just the way it is in Chicago.  It is deep dish after all!

The classic Chicago pizza and Italian food that delivers some of the best deep dish.  The cheese, crust and sauage are delicious and rich.  Extra cheese is a must! The tomato sauce can be a bit sugary, and I wish it was more robust with tomato flavor instead of the sweetness.  Good deep-dish all around but with a varying amount of quality throughout the Chicagoland area (I think the best one is in Evanton, actually).  Remember to order ahead if possible, takes about one hour to bake a deep dish pizza.
Amazing Amazing Amazing. Food is awesome. Servers were great. Got free dessert as it was my sis' bday. There was a line. They texted us when our table was ready and let us order food while we wait.
I loved it delish! We are from out of town. Our pizza took 1/2 hour. We loved it. Great service too.

Lou maltini's is a great place worth stopping by if you are around the area.  The pizza crust is unbelievably amazing. Everything you heard about the food is true and even more. However, the dessert is not quite good as I expected. The tiramisu is a little bit too moist to me. In my opinion, you should definitely save some room to try different kinds of flavors. Besides, the Italian vegetable soup is great with a lot of veggies and macaroni in it.
We always love the pizza and Strawberry Spinach Salad at Lou's- flavorful, fresh, delicious and a fun experience!!

Had a great time stopping by this amazing pizza stop. There is a decent wait but we received excellent full service sitting at the bar!

Great bartenders and amazing pizza! My partner and I split two personal deep dishes and had more than enough food!

Thanks to this amazing restaurant!!
Solid pizza but the wait times are pretty long- 45-60mins. If you aren't hungry you may as well get seated because the food will come out just as you are starting to get hungry

Delicious pizza! We were told to go there by a local so that's always a good sign. Call ahead or be prepared to wait as there is a line. Pick up was 35 minutes and to eat in an hour and a half. They do have a few tables outside so we were lucky enough to get one. So we stood there and waited for pizza and drink a beer. When our food is ready we just eat it there. We ordered the Lou pizza and it was fantastic. First time trying Chicago style pizza.

This is my go-to place before and after Blackhawks games. Food is always good. Service is a hit or miss though, but I've never had a bad experience. Just some waiters are attentive and some take forever to get back to you.
We took our family there visiting and everyone fell in love with Lou's.  Great pizza (One of the best in the city)  If you have family in town Lou's is a must!

Chicago folks are known to fight to the death for the honor of Chicago Pizza, and they are also known to fight for the death about who makes the best deep dish pie in the city.
If someone tells you anything other than Lou Malnati's (unless they say Pequods, then you may let them live), they are wrong.
I am in general a plain pizza kind of girl, and could die happy shoving a cheese pizza from Lou's down my gullet. But probably the most famous preparation is the Chicago Classic. The sausage is not thrown on in paltry nuggets. No, this is a sausage disc that coves the pie from crust to crust. And speaking of crust, this pizza crust is buttery, caramelized, crispy, and all in all the perfect delivery system for all that luscious cheese.
Living now on the other side of Michigan, I can't drive to the city anymore when I crave Lou's. Literally the best pizza I have ever eaten. DO. NOT. MISS. IT.

I can tell it's a very popular spot. I saw a lot of people coming to pickup their pizza during my 1-hour stay. I had a salad and the classic Lou pizza. The salad is fresh but there's some crispy stuff in it that I don't like. The pizza is slightly too salty for me.

Best deep dish in Chicago.

We tried Giordano's, we tried Uno. But then we spoke to the people of Chicago and unanimously they told us to "stay away from the tourist trash and just head straight to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria.

So we did, on our last night in the city. And we were not disappointed! The line was out the door, but somehow we got a table at 5:30. It takes about 30-45 minutes for the pizzas to cook, so many times they let you order ahead of being seated, that way your pizza will be on its way to you before you know it.

We had the Chicago Classic pizza but added basil. The buttercrust is the best part. It's crisp all the way through and melts in your mouth. Just the right amount of cheese and the best tomato sauce there is. It's made of actual tomatoes.

Great atmosphere, greater pizza, great prices. Check it out for the best Chicago Deep Dish!

Lou's is the best Chicago Pizza. Everybody knows that.

Unfortunately, they seem to know that too. The servers can be quite slow - even when the restaurant is quiet. It's usually pretty busy, but the servers seem to really be stuck in one gear no matter how the night is going. Lou's has also decided to up the prices of their pizza from what I can gather, which is a shame. It's starting to become more of a special occasion restaurant than my usual pizza joint.

All these complains are pretty minor, so they really only retract one star. I still love going here and I love the pizza, but it definitely takes a big bite out of your night if you come for dinner, so just be ready for that.

Im from SF. My hubby and i love pizza.  I was so excited to try this place.    We came in 10:45 am.   theres hardly anyone there.  We waited 50mins to get our pizzas and our pizzas  came  out warm .  Im pretty sure our pizzas sitting out for a while.  We ordered Italian combo and classic.  Flavors was ok and service sucks.  Im so disappointed regarding the pizzas.  I would gave 1 star, but my hubby told me to be nice.  Would not go back.

My favorite style pizza is really the Brick Oven Style Pizza. Having lived in New York City, I've had the best of all pizza. Though the closest I've ever had to a deep dish was Pizzeria Uno. So of Course being in Chicago, my dining partner and I had to try the Deep Dish Chicago Pizza which Chicago is famous for. We arrived for lunch on a Thursday at 11:00 a.m. as not having to wait as I've read that wait time can be long. Believe it or not at 11:00 a.m. we got the last available table. Our server Sam introduced herself, took our drink orders while we looked over the menu.

We ordered the Medium Malnati Salad and the Personal Pan Cheese Buttercrust Pizza. The salad was excellent. The Pizza was good, very thick and cheesy. I just have a personal preference for Pizza styles, but I'm so glad I've had a taste of the best Deep Dish pizza Chicago has to offer.

Atmosphere is a touristy Pizza Restaurant. Service very good. Food very good, a MUST TRY in Chicago!

Their pizza is amazing. 'nuff said. The deep dish cheese and spinach is what I live for. The best feeling ever is when the waiter takes a slice of pizza from the whole pie and he has to cut the cheese because it is literally stuck to the entire pizza because there is so much cheese. Yes. just yes.

Loved the sausage deep dish pizza!!  The line was long, the staff was friendly.  Service was great!  Food came out when promised and steaming hot!  If you go there knowing there will be a wait to sit and a wait for the food, you are set up to succeed!!  That's the downside of going to a very popular, amazing spot!

There "Chicago Pizza is the best, I prefer going to Lincolnwood, The Evanston store works for pick up and delivery on the far north side. I remember when Lou greeted people and stopped by the tables as well. If you are a fan of deep dish, this is the place!
Wells Street is my downtown spot!!

This place is the best pizza in Chicago. Period.

Gotta understand that I am a pizza fanatic, love em all, but Lou's is KING!

We ordered the Malnati Chicago Classic. It was thick, and not just the crust. Every bite had a solid layer of cheese, sauce, and most importantly sausage. What was most impressive was the price. My wife and I ordered a large and had enough for a filling lunch there and leftovers a couple days later which ended up being $6-7 a serving for really quality food.
This is the best deep dish pizza I have tried in Chicago. It is deep dish style without being too heavy or having too much tomato sauce and very few ingredients like most of them do.

Deep dish pizza is great (as far as deep dish is concerned), however the amount of sauce on the pizza was ridiculously heavy. Maybe that's the way they do it in Chicago? Also I along with two of the other folks in my party couldn't taste the pepperoni in our personal pizzas because they were extremely thin cut. However, my father in laws pizza was great - lots of sausage on his pizza.

The best part of the meal was the dressings for the salad - they were Devine! I had some sweet vinaigrette dressing and it was awesome!!!

Now while I would never consider this "pizza," (in NY they serve actual pizza) the quiche I had was wonderful. The crust was crisp, sauce and toppings (?) sandwiched in between were delectable as well. Also had their signature salad, which was fantastic. I'm not sure why people from Chicago have this inferiority complex when it comes to the quiches they serve, but trying to compare it to NY pizza is just plain wrong. That said, it was delicious!

I wanted to like this place and maybe it was because I got a personal sized pizza, but honestly, my pizza tasted like a microwaveable pizza. I got pepperoni and green peppers and they served it to me on a plate, I wanted it in a traditional deep dish pan. First strike. Second, the crust was crispy, but there was barely any cheese! Quality control check number one, failed. The green peppers were huge chunks and uneven pieces, quality control check number two, failed. The one positive: the mozzarella sticks with marinara sauce were delicious, hence the two stars. Service was okay, but never had my drink refilled the entire time I was there. Overall, never coming back here. Super bummed. :(
My first time in Chicago & Lou's delivered. Rich in mozzarella cheese, layered in tomato sauce & sausage, with a soft buttery crust. Perfect

pics.caption: My first time in Chicago & Lou's delivered. Rich in mozzarella cheese, layered in tomato sauce & sausage, with a soft buttery crust. Perfect

review.des:
This is by far the best pizza joint in Chicago. Yes it takes some time to make a deep dish style pizza so make sure to order as quick as you can. I also want to point out that the chicken wings are amazing, so you may want to try if you're diggin in this direction.

The Malnati Chicago Classic was by far the best decision, this pizza was delicious. My friend and I could not stop talking about this pizza the entire trip. We wanted to go back for seconds but didn't have time. That cheese and crust!!! To die for! I highly recommend this, it's called the Malnati Chicago Classic for a reason!

Also, there most likely will be a wait so plan accordingly. I ended up eating here later on a Thursday evening and avoided most of the crowd.
Only because i believe pizza is all about the sauce. Lou's Pizza doesn't have to much sauce on their pizzas. "You have to ask for a lot of sauce on your pizza"

A lot of people prefer Lou's when it comes to Chicago style deep dish because of the crust, and I'll admit it's good crust, nice and flaky. But, for me, that's where the advantages of Lou's cease.

Lou's deep dish certainly lacks the cheesy goodness and volume of toppings that Giordano's or Art of Pizza boast and it also doesn't have that light fluffy crust that Pequod's can boast. Plus I find the wait, especially at this location, to be much lengthier - Giordano's especially just seems to turn tables a little more quickly.

Lou's thin crust is kinda the same story. I just find that the other pizza places offer better options when it comes to thin crust and there are plenty of local mom & pop pizza places with good thin crust.

My two cents: opt for other pizza than Lou's.

The epitome of Chicago deep dish.  You gotta go with the Chicago classic if you've never been here before.  It's always crowded during the dinner rush so I'd recommend getting a table early.  Service can summer if your waiter gets stuck with a huge party.  Lou's and Giordanos are 1a and 1b for me and I can't visit the Windy City without paying either a visit.  I really like the flavor and buttery crust of the Lou's pie.  Can't go wrong here.

First time having deep dish pizza from Chicago-and did NOT disappoint!!!! Have nothing to compare it to, but thoroughly enjoyed the cheese pizza with buttercrust!! Expect a longgggg line (minimum of an hour)-so consider calling in your order ahead of time. Took our pizza to go and pizza remained hot entire way home because they wrap to-go orders of pizza in plastic!! Would definitely return to Lou Malnati's for more pizza!!

Holy deep dish pizza batman! This place is phenomenal and totally worth every minute of the wait! This was one of the must do's on our annual girls trip to Chicago and boy am I glad we didn't miss out on this spot!!

We arrived around 5 or 6 in the evening on Sunday (8/6/17) and this place was packed. We reserved our table then put our order in and I proceeded to the bar. I ordered the local IPA they had on tap and it was crisp and refreshing. I put my phone to charge as they have outlets under the bar area only. They told us the wait for a table would be about 25 minutes and I only had time to order a beer and plug my phone in and they had already called us, yay for good service and timeliness! We were told to go upstairs and then the waitress escorted us to our table. Our waitress was really good!
