I liked watching the bartender serve the pizzas in worn, hot skillets with tongs and a serving spatula. The bartender was very friendly and charming.

I ordered the 9" pizza because I'm a hungry girl. The single probably would have been sufficient. They pride themselves on Wisconsin mozzarella and California tomatoes for the sauce. There was a nice sweetness to both, and the crust was crisp on the bottom yet doughy. I thought the crust could have been more buttery and lacked salt. They put the cheese on top of the crust, what we call an "upside down slice" in New York. That is followed by lean sausage, and then tomato sauce on top. It was tasty.

I tried two craft beers: a bitter, yet sweet Anti-Hero Revolution IPA and the easily drinkable Goose Island Greenline Pale Ale.

Lou's contacted me several times to speak about my experience and they have went above and beyond to listen to my concerns and rectify whatever happened during my visit. I am sooo extremely impressed by their sincere effort to listen to customers and improve their business. I have not come across many organizations as nice and as attentive as Lou's.

I have had a few organizations message me to change their reviews. At first they offer a deal or an inventive to go back and retry, but normally I politely decline since I already had a bad experience the first time and don't see how going again when they are on their best behavior would solve anything. The companies then have proceeded to flat out ask me to change the review with various excuses or even angry threats. Lou's did not even mention anything at all about changing the review. It appears they just were genuinely trying to make sure I ended up being happy with the service!

I cannot wait to try their spinach pizza.

i guess i forgot to write a review
when i visited a few years ago
a photo popped up on my instagram
and i was reminded of how i fell in love with the pizza here

thick sausage patty with stretchy, gooey cheese
all smothered in that tangy sauce
held up by that buttery, thick crust

i hate LA!
just kidding

Everyone has their favorites, but for us Lou's is the best deep dish pizza in Chicago! A definite must have if you're passing through. We love the butter crust option. They also a great Lou's salad and sometimes I even buy the dressing in a bottle.

I took a poll among my friends to help me decide where to get deep dish pizza while I was visiting Chicago in October. I heard the same answer repeatedly - Lou's!

We were seated quickly and our waiter was very friendly. We ordered our pizza and beers, and our waiter warned us that the pizzas are made to order and do take some time. I think our wait was close to an hour, but I amused myself with editing photos from our Chicago exploring that morning. However, I would consider the fact that Lou's would not be a good lunch option for those working close by as it can take some time.

I selected the "Lou" personal, and my husband ordered The Malnati Chicago Classic™. Though hard to believe, I think this may have been my first true deep dish experience. It was definitely soupier than I had expected (is that normal?), but I thought the pizza was really tasty.
I'm it's malnatis, hello?? Welcome to Chicago.we get the deep dish they deliver to the door we have parties and love life. Can it get better than this? Maybe but this is pretty darn great too.
Not my favorite pizza in the city but it's still good. The pizza dough tasted stale but the toppings were good and the salad starter was great.

I've been looking forward to this visit for weeks. My pizza came in the time it was promised and it wasn't cold nor was it hot. it was somewhere in the middle and made me feel pressured to eat it quickly before the cheese became rubber. How long do these things stay in the oven? I'll try out Pepuod's next time to see how they do.

1. Verdict/Value: Decent food, decent prices, and a solid choice for deep-dish pizza in a town full of deep dish choices!  Folks looking for personal sizes of pizzas will appreciate this place.

2. Food: The Bar-B-Lou Wings ($8.75) featured just 8 drumsticks and wings, but they were big, meaty, juicy, and flavorful.  Order it with the honey BBQ sauce on the side, since they normally come over-smothered in sauce.

The Malnati Chicago Classic personal sized pizza ($8.95) comes with tomatoes, sausage, and plenty of cheese.  For $0.90, you can get extra toppings; pineapple worked well for this Hawaiian diner.  Unlike some of my fellow Yelpers I had a reasonably soft crust - likely because the Classic comes with a special buttery crust.

For dessert, I couldn't resist the Chocolate Chip Pizza ($3.50 personal size) - who can resist a soft, thick/deep-dish cookie served with vanilla ice cream and a cherry on top?!

3. Service: It's a hopping place, so given that, the service was good.  My waitress came often and various wait staff passing by constantly were willing to help.

4. Atmosphere: Old-school brickhouse where sports memorabilia adorn the walls.  It's clean, comfortable, and classic-looking, like the pizza they serve!  Rooms allow for private functions and they can host small and large groups easily.

pics.caption: The Chocolate Chip Pizza ($3.50 personal size): heavenly soft thick chocolate chip cookie, vanilla ice cream and whipped cream!
The Malnati Chicago Classic ($8.95 personal size): tomatoes, sausage, lots of cheese with pineapple (extra $0.90) - fantastic!
Bar-B-Lou Wings ($8.95): eight big juicy drumsticks and wings with honey BBQ sauce on the side.  YUM!

review.des: Finally!  Deep dish pizza, I loved! Being a tourist and trying to find that pizza w legit reviews got me on a deep dish pizza hunt. I tried Giordano's first,  wasn't so impressed. Came here hoping this place wouldn't let me down... it sure did not! Enjoyed a glass of red to accompany my delicious pizza. The sausage spread at the bottom,  the flavors n sauce was in sync on  combination and the crust tied it perfectly together.  Shall be dreaming of this forever,  until next time Chicago!!!
Wow best deep dish pizza in Chicago. Can't wait to go back to Chicago and taste it again. The ingredients so fresh, the salsa oh wowww so good

I'm not gonna lie, even though I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza, when in Chicago one must try. It was actually pretty good. We shared a small Chicago classic pizza because we didn't want to get too full. We also ordered beers and a salad to share. Wait takes a while and they ask you to order first because the pizza takes time to make.

We culminated our exploration of the Magnificent Mile with a trip to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria...unfortunately we got caught in crazy unexpected Chicago rainstorm so instead of arriving for an early dinner, we arrived right at the peak of dinner time. That. Kinda. Stunk. We were hit with a wait over an hour, but luckily Lou Malnati's is fairly aware of its ability to accommodate guests - definitely put your order in beforehand. They time it to come out shortly after you sit - genius!

We ordered the Chicago classic deep dish and also tried a thin crust variety. And to give some semblance of healthiness, we added a family sized spinach salad. The salad was delicious, it was light but the creaminess of the goat cheese definitely paired well with the more sweet strawberries they used as their fruit. The onions also added that sweet crunch.

The Chicago classic deep dish was to die for. It had the perfect ratio of ultra gooey cheese to meat ratio. And I love that the sausage wasn't little pieces strewn randomly about...it was a 1/4" sausage patty enveloping the entire pie. That's LOVE. And all of this is housed within a thick (but not too thick) butter crust. I could eat this for days on end probably...ugh, so good. The thin crust pizza was kind of joke though...didn't expect too much from it, but also didn't expect what seemed to be a cheese cracker, lol.

pics.caption: Close up of the Classic Deep Dish
Spinach Salad with Strawberries, Onions, and Goat Cheese

review.des: Our fave Chicago style pizza place! The three cheese bread was good, too. You are able to order your pizza when you put your name in for a table so it makes the wait not so bad. Roberto was our server and he was great. Love the atmosphere of this location.

This was highly recommended to me as a first time visitor to Chicago. Wait here is not absurd, about 1 hr for me coming in as a solo diner on Friday evening. They're nice enough to take your order ahead of time and also take your number to text you when your table becomes available. They provide you with a link to a website that tells your position, which i thought was very useful. I started at position like 50 something? Not sure how accurate it is as I got seated when my position on the website was at about 10. Anyway, good marker that would allow you to walk around and come back in time. Make sure you do come back in time, they allow you 5 min to show up when your table is called otherwise you forfeit it.

I got the classic pizza or something that has sausage and their "famous" butter crust in a personal size. It's a pretty reasonable prize at about $12. One of the best pizzas I've tasted flavor wise, not sure how they did it, but I was quite impressed. This place easily would have earned 5-stars but I felt they messed up either accidentally or intentionally. The pizza I received was warm, not hot. And by warm, I mean the cheese didn't have the melted or gooey effect I usually expect from a pizza place. Rather the cheese stretched a tiny bit before tearing. Unsure if this was how pizza was normally served in this style, I ate at Giordano's and they served the pizza much hotter than Lou's. Overall impressed with the flavor enough that I'll be back again, but hopefully the pizza will be much hotter and "fresher" tasting next time around.

There's a reason Lou Mal's is synonymous with Chicago pizza. Yes, you'll wait forty five minutes to an hour, but then you will receive a pizza the likes of which you will eat nowhere else in the world (except another Lou Mal's, obvs.) Crunchy butter crust, squeaky fresh mozzarella, and perfectly seasoned tomatoes plus your topping of choice. The sausage and pepperoni and spinach and mushroom are family favorites, but honestly you could put anything on these pies and they'd be delicious.

Now stop reading this and go to Lou Mal's. Yes, now. Right now.
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place dinner for 4 with drinks, appetizer, and a pizza for under 50 dollars.  The best pizza hands down (and I am not a fan of Pizza)

This definitely made up for going to Pizza Uno's previously. What a difference!

We started with the stuffed spinach bread which led to a very good indication that the pizza was going to live up to expectations. This bread was delicious and the loaf had a similar crust to that of the pizza crust.

Went with The Malnati Chicago Classic and was absolutely wowed by the flavour of the sausage, the flaky buttery crust, and the gooeyness of the cheese. Every single bite was delicious and it tasted just as good reheated the next day.

We visited on a Saturday around lunch time and I am glad that we did because the place kept getting busier and busier. Our original plan was to go for dinner so this worked out much better since we didn't have to wait for a table. Service was excellent, we actually had two because one was in training and both were fantastic.

I really wish they could deliver to Canada. Needless to say I am glad I have a great reason to keep visiting Chicago so I can also keep coming here for their deep dish pizza.

Out of Towner here. Obvious tourist. Came in here at 9pm after a long flight and long train ride on the "L". They promised a 15-25 minute wait and they delivered. They take down your cell # and give you a call AND a text which I appreciate.

You can always get drinks at the bar while you wait which makes the wait much shorter!

You can order right after you let the hostess know how many people you need for your table and they'll get your pizza started for you right then and there.

Super highly recommend the Malnati Chicago Classic --- best deep dish pizza I have ever had. It was just my husband and myself so we could barely finish a personal size.

We also had the "Lou" but if you can only eat one -- get the classic.

Make sure to get the spinach stuffed bread --- it's really mozzarella with a tinge of spinach but I ain't complaining. Sooooo delicious.

Grab some Goose Islands, sit down, and have some really good pizza!!

I always expect the same thing I go here, each time.  Oooooey, gooooey, delicious pizza.  Deep dish, winderful goodness.  I give 4-stars, why?  Sometimes its perfect, sometimes its 95% what I expect.  

If you want deep dish, butter crust, and a sauce that is a balance of salty sweet, get involved.
Pizza is great. Always have to get the buttercrust.  Just remember that the pizza does take about 45min - 1hr to prepare so be patient
Best pizza I've ever had! I bring anyone new to Chicago here. You will have to wait about 20-40 minutes but it is well worth it. The service has been great every time I've been!

Very generic, it is the same as all deep dish pizza, which means you enjoy it, but only eat it when friends or family are in town. It was the best of times, it was the worst of times. Many sides, many sides.

Be prepared to wait! I don't think it matters what day you go, there will be a wait. A touristy spot? Well, yea but so what! You go to the hostess put your name in and you order while you wait. It doesn't really matter that you put your order in way in advance because when you get seated, you'll still have to wait.

The deep dish: This was my first time having real "deep dish" pizza and I loved it! I was expecting it to be loaded with bread, but it was the total opposite. The crust is thin, crisp and loaded with toppings (a little too much toppings for me) but it's delicious! I was with a party of 5 and we split 2 mediums with about 3 slices left over.

The thin pizza: let me just say, if they had this pizza where I'm from, I'd definitely eat it once a week! I absolutely loved the thin crust way more than the deep. The topping is layered between the crust and cheese and it's different from what I've had before.

If you're not from here you should check this place out. Really enjoyed the food!

There was a long-ish wait for this restaurant on a Friday night. We ordered the pizza while we were waiting, and it still took some time to get the pizza once we were seated. Disclaimer: we were hungry, so the wait might have seemed longer than it really was. But when the pizza arrived it was delicious and quite filling! The wait staff was pleasant, but a little slow, and the restaurant was clean, but a little chilly.

Well worth the trip ... all the way from Utah.  The first time I had a Lou Malnati's pie was a couple years ago when a Chicagoan co-worker had a few shipped to Utah and shared them as Christmas gifts.  The frozen version was pretty darn tasty, but when I got to Chicago today that memory led me straight to Lou's for the real deal ... and the real deal did not disappoint!  The pies take about 40 minutes to cook, so if you are in a hurry, this probably is not the place. But 40 minutes is the perfect amount of time to enjoy an order of Lou's traditional buffalo wings, a cold drink and some sports on the bar TV.  I ordered the classic Chicago deep dish pepperoni pizza, though made a mistake and went with the "personal" ("feeds one") variety.  Being a hearty eater, I certainly could have slammed down a small, "feeds two" pie, but that doesn't mean I was disappointed in the food--only my apparent lack of ordering skills.  My pizza was terrific!  Seriously, I am going to insist that my work meeting crew order some Lou Malnati's pies for lunch tomorrow, and you can rest assured that I will be devouring more than a personal pie then.  Bring it on!!!

pics.caption: Personal sized classic Chicago deep dish pepperoni pizza.

review.des: This is the best deep dish pizza in Chicago! I always always always get the pepperoni deep dish when visiting with my boyfriend. It's our favorite!

Just realized I didn't take a picture of the actual pie maybe that's because it was just so good and we basically ate it all up.  While baking the house took on the smell of a  delicious Sicilian pizzeria.  

Every aspect of online ordering the pie through to its rapid consumption was easy and painless.  There were no hang ups or snafus with delivery.

The shipping costs are kinda hefty but worth it for real authentic Chicago deep dish pie.

The instructions for baking were easy to follow. The pie dripped with cheesy goodness and the veggie pie was loaded in every bite.  Even the crust was buttery and flaky and delicious.

It took lots of restraint to not cook the sausage pie. That would have been a binge for sure.  

Thankfully, the freezer will keep it just fine for our next craving!

I would order pie again and again from this restaurant.

pics.caption: Packing nix with styrofoam and dry ice
Veggie deep dish pie delivered to our door

review.des: Hands down the best deep dish pizza I have ever had! We had the small Lou pizza between 2 which was more than enough food as the portions are huge! Service was great too!

Coming from California and the land of horrible pizza.... this place was awesome. . Great crust, perfectly cooked and very tasty.

Sat at the bar. My bartender David was spot on. Friendly, fast [well not the pizza, takes 40 minutes to make... well worth the wait] and informative. Thanks for the great experience

Will definitely be back .
Really good pizza. Maybe, just a hair below giordano's.  Crust is very good. Great service!

Best Chicago pizza I've had.  Sauce was spot on with lots of cheese.  We also enjoyed the spinach bread for app.  Only gripe was tap water......wish there was some better filtered water.  But small gripe.

The deep dish cheese pizza is simply to die for. The cornmeal crust is the best I have ever eaten. The salad with creamy garlic-lime dressing is also fantastic! Not a place, however, to eat at often unless you are intent on clogging your arteries. But for an occasional treat, Lou's is hard to beat.

I think it's a little overrated (opinion of a foodie from out of town). I was debating between Giordano's or Lou Malnati to try my first deep dish in Chicago and I gave in to Lou Malnati (this location) because of the reviews and ratings. It's overrated for it wasn't as good as I expected and it was certainly worse than the Giodarno's Takeout order I had in Orlando,Florida. I might be wrong about how deep dish should be like but I expected it to have light crispy crust , heavy sauce with toppings and moderate cheese. In Lou Malnati, the ratios are 1:1:1 which made me feel that it was a little too dry for a deep dish. However , their crust was on point (texture was good but a little too thick for the pizza I had). All in all , my experience in Lou Malnati would've bee better if my personal pizza had more sauce (and cheese). Oh and also, shorter wait time because I waited for 1.5hours in total.
Best pan pizza in the Chicagoland area!  Pizza is great - salads are huge and delicious. Great service. Highly recommend!
Absolutely the first place to try if you have never done the Chicago pizza thing. Great food, nice staff, worth the wait on the table and order that can accompany a visit.

I started with the Giant calamari served with lemon and marinara with the cake. Marinara so good you could drink it. Then I had the Lou special which I added onions to. This is the best pizza I've ever put in my mouth. It's like making love to your taste buds. Because it was my birthday, they gave me a complementary deep dish chocolate chip cookie with vanilla bean ice cream whipped cream and a cherry on top. I will definitely be back.

pics.caption: Giant calamari served with lemon and marinara with the cake. Marinara so good you could drink it.
This is the Lou special with onions added
Deep dish chocolate chip cookie pizza with vanilla bean ice cream whipped cream and a cherry on top

review.des: I used to be a Giordano's fan, but I came back and everyone said I needed to try Lou Malnati's.   They couldn't be more right because I was in heaven!! The flavors are just perfect and it was even better the next day for brunch
Whatever you do do not order their Gluten free pizza, it's the worst GF pizza I have tasted.
Best Pizza in Chicago!! Gotta get the butter crust and the full slab of sausage!! My favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago! Hands down!! Screw all the other deep dish places! Giordanos sucks!!
Eh.  Lou's, while a Chicago favorite, is too greasy and doesn't have enough sauce.  Giordano's is much better!

Final verdict: Lou Malnati's  is so much better than Giordano's. The Malnati Chicago Classic pizza blew the deep dish pizza served at Giordano's. It wasn't only the golden brown buttered crust, but also the fresh ingredients (particularity the sauce) which made my experience worth the 5 stars of this review.

Tip: the bruschetta is a great appetizer to start off with.

I guess if you come to Chicago deep dish pizza would be something on your list to try. I am a big fan of pizza in general. Being an East Coaster, I have to say that deep dish pizza is not for me. Not really a great beer selection here- pizza and beer go hand in hand.Pizza choices are ok. What I did like was it wasn't too much bread compared to some other deep dish pizza options. This is just a basic pub place.

We went here on a holiday weekend and waited an hour and five minutes for our table.  It was worth it.   Totally worth it!  When you arrive and give them your name they will ask for your phone number.  Give it to them.  They will text you and you get to see where your place in line is, while you wait.  Then you go to the counter and order your pizza.  Just your pizza and then when your seated you'll order any appetizers or salads.  This is suppose to get your pizza to the table quicker.   Ours came out a little too quick when we got seated. It beat our garlic bread and mozzarella sticks.  I was peeved at first but it was so amazing I didn't care!!  We took home the leftovers and had them the next night for dinner.

pics.caption: Pepperoni deep dish, butter crust, well done

review.des: I had the personal sized classic deep dish with sausage on it. It was bland and the crust was soggy. I don't want a salt mine on my pizza but this pie needed a serious pinch of salt on it. The actual pizza versus crust ratio was terrible, almost half of what you get is soggy crust. I personally far prefer giordano's for their deep dish. Will definitely not come here again.

I think they have really good pizza. I got a simple vegetarian pizza and it was delicious, and I really love thin crust. The place was nice, with friendly customer service, however the washrooms were not that clean. I would come back here again.

I took a day trip to Chicago and wanted to maximize my experience of Chicago and what better way to do that than with some deep dish pizza? I decided on Lou Malnati's due to suggestions from friends as well as raving reviews on yelp and I was not disappointed!

Ended up ordering the spinach bread and the Malnati Chicago Classic and both were amazing! The spinach bread is a smaller sized loaf of bread filled with cheesy goodness and a little bit of spinach as well. The pizza with the butter crust is amazing as well! Took about 30 min for them to make the pizza but it was definitely worth the wait. The crust has a really nice crunch to it all around and every bite was filled with ooey gooey mozzarella goodness and Oh my, they definitely do not skimp on the sausage! Instead of bits of sausage, it seemed like they had sausage on every inch of the pie! A small pizza and the spinach bread were more than enough for our party and I would highly recommend the deep dish pizza here to anyone!

Sorry folks.. I've had all the pizza's here in Chicago..(at least in the downtown area) and Lou's is the best...BY FAR.   But.. I hope you'll also try them all out, as I did, in order to reach your own conclusion.   Next on the list to try... Pequod's in Lincoln Park!

If you are visiting Chicago for the first time, you MUST go here. We are staying at the Beat Western in River Front and the parking employee recommended this place for a good classic Chicago Deep Dish pizza. I went here last night. The wait was supposed to be 25 minutes but we found two seats at the bar and skipped the wait! The bartenders were very nice and accommodating hence the busy night they had. We ordered a mule (custom with triple sec) and Goose IPA for drinks and got the classic deep dish pizza from the restaurant and really enjoyed it! I thought it was nice how they warned us that the deep dish would take 40 minutes and we in return ordered some more beers to enjoy the wait. The pizza was amazing. I would recommend getting a smaller size than you are used to for regular pizza because this deep dish stuff is very filling. I usually eat a good amount of food and could finish a regular medium size pizza without lifting a muscle but with this medium the two of us still had two pieces left over!

Anytime I'm in a new city I like to try it's pizza, and this did not disappoint. Great deep dish pizza, with gluten free options if necessary. The only downside is the long wait, but because the pizza is made to order, it is to be expected with deep dish pizza. I would recommend leaving at least an hour and a half if ordering deep dish.

Pretty disappointed, this was my first time in Chicago, and I was told to come here by multiple people. You enter this place, while you wait for a seat, you order your pizza (since it takes about 45 min to make) great idea! So we get in around 1pm..

We were seated probably about 30 minutes later and we order some apps. Apps come out at room temperature. Probably been sitting on the expo window or wherever for a while. We were starving so we just ate them and didn't say anything.

It's about 2:15 now - still no pizza. People all around are all getting theirs before us, so I ask them to check on it for us. They bring out this pizza. It's 2:30 now, so an hour and 30 min after we had put the order in to begin with. It takes an hour and 30 minutes to make pizza. No joke there's like a watery
substance sloshing on the pizza, probably from the veggies, the pizza looks like it had been sitting out for ages. I already in my head told myself there's no way this pizza is cooked. I have a tiny bite and it's cold. Not sure why you'd even bring this pizza to someone by the way it looked. They clearly rushed this pizza, probably forgot to bring it out, I don't even know, nobody could explain to us why this took so long or why our pizza was so bad. They offered us another pizza which we accepted but at this point we are just over being there for so long. Waited another 30 minutes, finally got another pizza. Was alright. I guess the whole experience overall made me lose my appetite. We watched 3 sets of people sit and leave by the time we finally got to eat. Not how I wanted to spend my day.

They did comp our food, which we appreciate, but a little more communication would've been nice. Not just keep us waiting forever in the dark wondering where our food is.

This deep dish pizza was well worth the 30 minute wait! A perfect buttery crust and an enormous portion of toppings. When we visit Chicago again, we would choose this place over uno's pizzeria hands down.
YUM! We had a great dinner here. Thanks for letting us reserve a table in advance by pre-ordering our pizzas. Great service and happy bellies! A Chicago MUST!
My favorite pizza, deep dish, butter crust and any topping. I'm a native New Yorker and even ship pizza to my dad in Florida a few times a year. Check it out.

I obvii had to get some deep dish on a recent trip to Chicago and I heard that was the real thanggg. I also heard Uno is good but I used to get that all the time in California as a kid..so idk how real it is.

Anyways, so it's really nice that they warn you that deep dish is made to order so takes 45min so obviously allocate time! I got myself the house salad ($6) and a beer ($5-7) so I wouldn't eat my friends hand off during those 45min hehe. Salad was good but if you aren't hungry, just wait to eat your pizza cause you don't need any sides!!

So I got the Lou which was the veggie one with spinach, mushrooms, and tomatoes. INCREDIBLE. YUmmmmm. Recommend if you are vegetarian and don't want the reg cheese.

5 stars mostly because our server (Tina!) realized I was kinda in a rush to get the airport, told me how to get there the fastest way possible, got the check to the table when the food came, and immediately ran it and brought it back, and with boxes. So nice when you're not like hELLOO im gonna miss mah flight cause you cant run a credit card!

Deep dish is not my favorite kind of pizza, but if I'm going to eat it... I'm eating it at Lou's. This place does deep dish, best.
There isn't too much crust, too much cheese or too much of anything. It has just the right amount of each ingredient to make sure you can taste and enjoy each and every one.
Since we were starving, and a pizza takes 40+ minutes, we ordered some hot wings to hold us over while we waited. Great decision! These are some of the best wings anywhere. Yum!

So good!!!!! We tried both Lou's and Giordano's while we were in town. Both were great, but I prefer Lou's for the amazing sauce and buttery crust. We also tried their cheese sticks which were also very good. We went right when they opened on a Saturday so didn't have to fight any crowds.

Good pizza. Their spinach salad was really the star Not sure if this is the best deep-dish in Chicago...or if I'm not just a fan of deep-dish. Either way you have to the pizza when in the Windy city and this is a solid place.
Love this pizza. Deep dish is not over doing it and I do feel guilty after having a few slices but it's worth it every time.

The reason why I posted as a three start not for the food but for the service, our server was confused about what beers they had when we asked if they have any dark beer. Then our chicken wings appetizer took for ever to come out and they slightly cold but we were so hungry we didn't feel like sending it back, they say that it takes them about 30 minutes to cook the pizza so we ordered it after the wings and got another drink after about 40 minutes the manager comes to us and tells us they burned our only one small pizza, and they were rushing to make another one then when they brought it out we go ahead and eat it and the one we ordered is there most popular deep dish pizza with lean sausage cheese and Roma tomatoe sauce and we also asked to add chicken sausage which we didn't see. So we asked for our waiter he came by and left and when he came back he says that they might have mixed chicken sausage with the lean sausage meat which still wasn't plausible but what ever. They took care of the pizza for us since they burned in the first place. Not saying if you go there it will be like that but for us it wasn't great. Food was good not going to lie though.
In Chicago and need deep dish pizza? Here's the place to go. Expect a long wait, but it's worth it.

What can I say? Pizza the best ever! It was Chicago!! Have always wanted to try it! Everyone there told us we couldn't leave without trying this pizza! It was incredible!! Tasted even better leftovers for breakfast!! AND IT WAS VEGETARIAN!! I was in love!

Good food for a great price!

I wanted to know what all the hype over deep dish pizza was about and this place proved it. Sure, it took longer than an average pizza but well worth the wait! We got 2 personal sized pizzas (one Lou, which is the vegetable one, and the Malnatis Chicago Classic, which featured sausage) and both were perfect. Very simple stuff, but simply delicious and filling.
Beer was good too! They have local craft beer specials!

pics.caption: Sorry it's dark! Malnati Chicago Classic an the Lou (both personal size)

review.des: We ordered pepperoni with bunch of veggies as toppings, but when our pizza came to our table, it only had pepperoni and olives as toppings. We informed the waiter and he first asked if we wanted to wait for our correct order, which will take another 30min. We already had waited over 30min to be seated, so we said we would rather not and we just ate the pizza with just pepperoni and olives. We usually like our pizzas with lots of toppings, so we didn't enjoy it as much, but it was good! Later on, the manager came to our table and apologized for the mistake. He gave us a 50% discount. Although we were a bit disappointed about the wrong order, we were satisfied by the service.

Prior to visiting Chicago, I had some friends tell me, "YOU MUST GET SOME DEEP DISH PIZZA THERE." Now, I had never been to Chicago. Therefore, I did not know which pizza place was the best. Since I was in Chicago, I figured that my attempt to get a decent deep dish pizza would be akin to "shooting fish in a barrel." While walking and taking in the sights of downtown Chicago, my friend and I decided to check out Lou Malnati's Pizzeria.

We walked into the restaurant and were greeted by staff. The staff was all smiles and made us feel like stars. The restaurant was packed, but we were seated very quickly. Our server/waitress was a young girl and she was great. She seemed like the happiest person in the world when taking our orders and serving us.

I ordered a pepperoni deep dish pan pizza with sausage and mushrooms. Once I finally tasted the pizza, I instantly thought of all the "Chicago-styled" pizza places that I have visited over the years and how their pizza DOES NOT measure up to this authentic Chicago deep dish pizza from Chicago. I definitely see what the hype is all about. If I were not a fan of Chicago deep dish pizza, I was after eating at Lou Malnati's Pizzeria. OUTSTANDING PIZZA!

I know that I will be returning to Chicago one day. I will make a beeline to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria without even thinking about it.

Being from California I'll say Zachary's (Oakland/Berkeley) deep dish is much better and more flavorful, and Patxi's is average.  Use that as your gauge of this review.

Maybe I don't know what to expect from Deep dish Chicago pizza or maybe it's what we ordered.  The food was average bordering on somewhat bland, and price was ok.  

We didn't have a reservation but it didn't take too long to get seated for party of 2.  They have a good system for putting in your pizza order while you're waiting for your table so that the long wait for deep dish isn't too long once you're sitting.

Nothing to rave about for the food or the restaurant.  Next time I'm in Chicago I'll try another deep dish and let you know if it's just me and my sketchy relationship with deep dish pizza.

The deep dish pizza was very very good.  Service was good too.

The deep dish pizza is huge! Even a small was huge.  Definitely worth trying.

Disclaimer: This was my first experience with Chicago pizza.

My group of 3 arrived just before 5 on a Saturday and was seated right away. The lobby was sardine level packed when we left, so I feel we got lucky. Our waiter kindly reviewed the menu with us newbs and recommended a salad as an appetizer to start since the pizza would take about 45 minutes. We mistook that to mean all appetizers were quick and ordered the wings, which took about 25 minutes. It was okay in the end though, because the wings were incredible! I highly recommend them. We got the Malnati classic, and it was a really, really good pie from the crust to the cheese. It wasn't as thick as I imagined, but I don't think I could have finished my two slices otherwise.

Overall, Lou's was a fine experience from service to food and I would happily return.
One of the best places in Chicago for typical deep dish pizza. Love it! Be prepared to wait. You can also take out if it is too busy. Always on my list of places to eat while in the Windy City.

This was my first deep dish pizza experience and I'm so glad I had it here! Our waiter was really nice and attentive, but the pizza. The pizza! We ordered their house classic and I wish I could have brought a dozen home with me.

I went here over thanksgiving vacation.

This pizza is the most amazing deep dish I have ever had.

I can't wait for the next family visit !

we waited 1.5 hours to eat here but it was worth it! the pizza was amazing. service was eh, though it was extremely busy and probably couldn't be avoided. they allow you to preorder if you wait a long time, which is good because the food gets thrown in the oven as soon as you sit
it is not that hard to MIX the tomatoes in your sauce. no one likes PEELING tomato skins from their pizza.

I came here because one of my friend talked to me about this place. When we arrived, waiters were waiting and talking and looked bored. They didn't pay attention to us and there was a horrible odor in the restaurant. They put dirty socker shoes on the wall (you can see the dirty grass and mud on it!). At this time I wanted to leave but we stay because we thought that maybe the food worths it. The waitress was very unhappy and fed up. After 40 min our pizzas arrived. The vegetables inside the pizza were very good and pretty healthy and tasty, but the dought was too crispy and very hard to eat. I won't come back and I don't recommend to go to this place as there are so much places better than this one.
Pizza is overrated. Let's talk about the real reason to come here... cookie skillet. Heaven sent. Get extra ice cream.

Got the thin crust sausage with fresh sliced tomatoes, garlic, onions and jalapeños. So so delicious and very fair price! Great value. My husband and I couldn't finish a medium! We ordered through grub hub as the place was literally lined around the block waiting, I can see why!

Love me some Lou's!!   If you haven't been here, I feel sorry for you and your taste buds.
Go hungry, you will come away stuffed.I do not visit Chicago without making this tops on my list for dining.
Nuff said.

I'm basically plagiarizing if I attempt to write an original review among 2100+ reviews, but here are my highlights from my siblings weekend getaway to Chitown.

The 45 minute wait on a beautiful Saturday evening in Chicago was expected, but definitely worth it. The staff was super friendly upon arrival, and they even let you place an order when you put your name in. That way the wait time once you're seated is cut in half.

The pizza was a monstrosity, and every bit as delicious as it looked. We also had a side of ravioli with meat sauce. That was also great, as it kept all but a few happy giggles from my 10-month old nephew. We stuck with the ravioli for him, because we decided the pizza should be reserved for people who are actually making memories.

I also recently found out that "Buttercrust" is apparently trademarked. And for good reason. I'm a snobby mcsnobster from the East Coast, so I'm all about the quality of pizza crust, and Lou's nails it. If the east coast falls into the ocean, Chicago is looking like a decent alternative...

Great spot for visitors, locals and anyone looking for some good food. I have bought this food for work catering and have brought friends and family here. The thin crust is my favorite, the crust is so buttery and delicious! I also appreciate that the chain puts their calorie counts on their menu.
Not a big fan of deep dish but had to try it . Much much better than Giordanos for sure

Outstanding pizza. Different than the other major Chicago pizza chains and that's a good thing. Each major pizza chain in Chicago has a slightly different way of making their pizzas. Lou's is just delicious. Very saucy. And the crust is just amazing.
I love Malnati's. You cant beat the Lou's pizza with sausage. The service is good and their drinks are reasonably priced. Their salads are great.
Very good pizza!! We love the deepdish pizza because of the perfect ratio of cheese to tomato paste. We go almost once a week ; my whole family loves it.

This place was at the top of our list while visiting Chicago and it definitely didn't disappoint! We came in around 12:30PM on Sunday and we put our name down and were seated after 5 minutes. Good thing we came when we did because people started piling in soon after us. There's tons of memorabilia around the restaurant which gives it an authentic feel.

There are different sizes for the pizza. You can get your own personal one or get a small for 2, medium for 3, large for 4, etc. We decided to share the Malnati Chicago Classic which comes with lots of cheese, tomato sauce, and sausage and of course that famous deep dish style. They do have a large selection of beer so we ordered one each. The pizza took about 30 minutes to arrive, but we didn't mind.

Once it arrived, our waiter cut it in 4 slices and we dug in. IT WAS SO DELICIOUS! I added some red pepper on it and it was literally perfection. Having two slices each was more than enough and it was a struggle near the end to finish it. I understand why this place is so popular! They also let you buy frozen pizzas to take home o_O

Two buddies and I were in Chicago for the weekend and we tried to get into Malnati's on a Friday night, ummm..that will be an hour wait. So we tried again on Saturday and put our name in four the hour wait and headed next door to grab a beer.  Perfect plan. Plus you can order your pizza while you are waiting, because those deep dish pizzas take about  1/2 hour to cook. Those are some dense pizzas.

We got texted and the place was packed. We were seated at a booth in the back, pretty small place, but everyone had a smile on their face.

I got a Diet Coke and my buddies ordered a glass of cabernet. I tried a sip and it was good cabby.  We ordered a Malnati classic with the sausage and cheese.  We also ordered an appetizer, but it didn't come out until we were done with the pizza, so they took it back at no charge. We were so full after the 2 slices of 'za, I couldn't have another bite.

Our waitress was super nice and refilled my Diet Coke a few times. Then the medium pizza came out. The crust was perfect looking, heck, the whole pie looked AMAZING.

The first bit was full of sauce and cheese and a buttery, crispy crust. Then I started to notice that the sausage was actually a slab of perfectly spiced sausage covering the whole pizza.  Genius!

After one piece, I was almost full. As I finished the second piece of heaven, I was uncomfortable full. These babies must have 600 calories a slice. But I figured since I was in Chicago, I had to try a slice of deep dish pizza.

My buddy said that he and a friend ordered this pizza in Minneapolis and they will send it to you freeze dried. He said it was awesome as well.

The price was pretty reasonable. For 4 drinks and Diet Coke and a medium pizza plus tax, it was $55. Not terrible for a night in Chicago in downtown.

ordered a small deep dish pepperoni = received a sausage deep dish.
i ordered the spinach bread with no onions. it was LOADED with onions.
my service was marginal at best;

i would suggest Giordano's;
i rarely have a bad experience there.

Im glad I read previous reviews about the long wait time I ordered a house salad to start to hold me over. Let me tell you, it is definitely worth the wait! So freaking good. They are very busy here so everything takes a while to get but try the local beer selection! You won't be disappointed:)

This was my first experience with deep dish pizza and it instantly has me addicted. My group of 5 shared a large deep dish, family salad and order of garlic bread.
Salad- This was your average salad and they were so kind to allow us to pick multiple dressings for the group.
Garlic Bread- This garlic bread had the best mozzarella cheese on it. It was cheesy heaven.
Deep Dish-  We ordered the sausage option and it was amazing. I love that the sauce is on top to prevent the buttery crust from getting limp under all those toppings. The menu said a large would feed 4 people but it easily fed all 5 of us and we were stuffed.

Lastly I want to mention how attentive our server was. This place was packed and he was attentive and quickly replaced a dirty plate for us. I would recommend this place if you want to try some deep dish pizza!

Yum! My favorite pizza ever ever ever in my entire life is The Lou deep dish!
So much so that my entire family knows that The Lou is officially part of my hospice plan for whenever that is needed.  The house salad with the creamy lemony garlic dressing is also great for a family style meal. But back to the pizza--get the butter crust.  

Love it, love to take guests to this location when showing them Chicago--but also order delivery up in Mt Prospect or take them to the Buffalo Grove location.

5 stars deep dish pizza. Not recommended to try their thin pizza. The thin pizza is signature of NYC and should only be eaten in the city (smile). Also try their signature malnati salad (non veg). It was the greatest salad I ever tried, even my mom who doesn't like salad, loved it

If you're into crispy deep dish then this place is for you! I got the Chicago deep dish style and tbh, I enjoyed the crust because I like the crisp  definitely fulfilling. You get to place your name first and then place your order as well so when you get seated, you won't have to wait for the pizza as long. However, I went during 9 pm and no wait; I suggest for those impatient people to do that and just eat later to avoid the hangry-ness.

Side note: the minestrone soup was actually pretty bomb!

Simply amazing pizza. We got it with the butter crust. YOU MUST DO BUTTER crust. It does not make the pizza overly greasy, rather it makes the culinary experience complete.

I love pepperoni, but I was with a friend who keeps kosher. We got mushrooms. I was already skeptical it was going to be boring, but heavens no. It was cheesy goodness. In correct proportions of sauce cheese crust. I can't wait to drag my husband to chicago to get this again, but with pepperoni. My husband and I went last year on Chicago pizza tour (see my precious yelp review). We got to try amazing places, such as pizanos and pequod. I've been to giordano's too. All good but the malnati's take the cake!

pics.caption: Deep dish, butter crust. Definitely recommend the butter!

review.des: I love this pizza! The deep dish with pepperoni  is awesome. But honestly, it cant compare to Beggars Pizza....Its a close second though.

Visiting our favorite pizza joint on a long weekend get away to Chicago! Beat the lunch crowd and arrived early. Sat upstairs and took in the beautiful nostalgic loft-type building and cool sports memorabilia lining the walls.

Started with the Lou Malnati's salad and a pitcher of Goose Island 312.   Delish!

10YO had the kids chicken nuggets and fries, rating them MMM MMM! Hubs and I split the Chicago Deep Dish and it was worth the wait.  Excellent!!!

Super busy on a Saturday evening but it was well worth the 45 minute wait! Restaurant allows you to place your order upon arrival so that it's basically ready when you're seated. Out server, Tina, was FANTASTIC!! We got the classic pizza and it was AMAZING! All in all it was a wonderful experience! Only wish I had More time to retune and request Tina... Even if I have to wait an hour!

It was a very good place to eat. The sausage is the best. They put a whole layer of it under the sauce. The only reason I gave it 4 stars because I didn't like the sauce as much as else where. I would say my 2nd favorite pizza place in Chicago behind giordanos

I don't generally like deep dish pizza but I'd go back here. Good serving staff, decent food. They were 5 minutes late with an order of wings so comped it. Very busy but we got a good table quickly and our waitress was attentive.

Got off the Plane checked into the hotel and went straight to Lou Malnati's Pizzeria Oh My what a treat. We started off with the brochette it was Amazing a must try. Then we had the Chicago classic I would eat here at least once a week if I lived here. We came to town to watch the San Francisco Giants play the Cubs we were overly impressed with the City of Chicago and the people.

Pretty good buttery crust deep dish pizza

Order the food ahead of time before you sit down since the pizzas take a long time to cook

Had the best wings calamari!! There cocktail sauce had a marinara flavor to it can't wait to have that again when I'm in town!  Had deep dish sausage pizza excellent!! Will be coming back and taking some to go also!

Rewind to a few years back...my first time in Chicago, a group of us wanted taste the Rivalry between Lou Malnatis and Giordanos first hand. We've heard that each establishment claims to be the "best." We had come to the conclusion that Giordano's was the better Pizza once and for all.
Fast forward to a few days ago when a new group of friends came to Chicago with me and we decided to leave it up to them to decide for themselves. However, it was a little tougher this time for me and my other friend that was with me the first time around. While the sauce is robust, spicy and more flavorful than Lou's, Giordanos delievered an abundance of cheese (layered to perfection) with thinly sliced pepperoni... but the crust was a little bit more dry and mealy than I remember.  On the other hand, Lou's had the most incredible buttery, flaky crust. It was absolutely delicious. I do NOT remember the pizza being so good last time. It could have been that we ordered in last time and maybe this type of pizza is better served hot, and fresh. While Lou's doesn't serve up a crazy amount of cheese like Giordano's, nor is the sauce as robust,  it's still superb! The sausage was also fantastic here (I normally don't order sausage on pizza but we ordered "the classic")  it was thinly sliced and layered so precisely with every other layer including cheese, and pepperoni. Omg it was delicious!
So I've come to stand still, to which family owned Pizzeria serves up the best deep dish. Both are fantastic and both are affordable as a family of 4 can fill up on a medium pie. While the prices may seem steep ($20-$30) you can, and probably will be, stuffed with 1 slice. I thought I was going to be pizza-d out for awhile and as I type this, I'm already craving a slice...Lou Malnatis for the Tie!

Love the crust of the deep dish Pizza here, crispy and not oily. Cheese and tomato were also very tasty. On the down side, 1h wait for a table at 8:30pm, 30+min wait for pre-ordered pizza and the starter we ordered while waiting for pizza came like 30s before the pizza itself.

By far the best pizza I've ever had. Covered in toppings, thick flaky crust, flavorful sauce. It has everything you could ever want in a pizza. A slice or two goes a long way, three of us couldn't finish a large. Only downside is the wait is painfully long for dining and take-out. Its a busy place though and I'm sure it takes a while to cook the pizza through so I won't hold it against them. You can always grab a drink at the bar while your waiting too.

very disappointed... ordered the chicken masala rigatoni... received bow tie pasta instead when I called to find out why I did not receive rigatoni and why I was not given the option of deciding whether or not I wanted bow tie pasta...I was told it tastes the same... in any case I should have been given the option to decide whether or not I wanted to change my order. The food was not good and the manager dismissive... will NEVER  order from Lou Malnati's again and will not recommend it.
Best Gluten Free Pizza!  Very nice atmosphere and staff.

Despite being a local Chicagoan, I do not frequent deep dish eateries. It would only come up on my radar when a friend is visiting from out of town or a non-local friend has the crave.

The usual order consists of: Malnati Chicago classic, Malnati's salad, and calamari. What makes Lou's deep dish better than others is it's not overly stuffed. The sausage is lean and not overly salty as it carelessly rests on a bed of vine-ripened tomatoes. One can easily down two slices without feeling too guilty unless you also ordered appetizers. The calamari was standard, lightly breaded, and seasoned. It delight to have but I would not say it's a must-order. As for the salad, I could care less. Honestly, when I go for deep dish, I'm not looking for a healthy meal. I mainly ordered it so as to not further provoke my out-of-country friends into thinking what unhealthy and detrimental eating habits Americans have.

In conclusion, I would say Lou Malnati's is my favorite deep dish eatery thus far. The ingredients are quality and the prices are fair. Do beware of the long waits though. We waited over an hour on a Saturday at 7pm.

pics.caption: Malnati's classic, Malnati's salad, and calamari

review.des:
I'm honored to have eaten Lou Malnatis pizza as my first deep dish pizza.  

I ordered Lou Malnatis classic chicago deep dish and it definitely surpassed my expectations. Because deep dish is known for their layer of cheese, meat, and tomato sauce, I thought it would taste extremely similar to a lasagna but it was far from it.  

Crust was crunchy on top yet very fluffy on the inside but not enough to be mushy on the bottom.  

Cheese was savory and wonderful.  Although there was a decent layer of cheese, it never felt greasy at all.

Amount of meat toppings was more than enough and tomato sauce was light and sweet.

I would definitely visit Lou Malnatis again when I am in town.

After a few weeks of research we decided to give Lou our first try, disappointed, we had calamari, bruschetta, and the classic Lou Deep Dish , food across the board was cold, pizza was lacking flavor, service was good

I would give a zero if I could. Down the street from my building. They deliver rotten, I mean spoiled, food. What idiot place does this and thinks there won't be bad reviews? Thanks to Yelp now people will know. Tourist trap with rotten food. I wouldn't go to this place if I were you, especially considering all the other really great pizza places in town. Even Bottled Blond across the street has exponentially better food-which is not rotten.
Love this place,,,, great food,,,very friendly servers and nice ambience so what more could you ask for?
Great calamari. House dressing has a sweeter taste to it, I'm not really into it, but the pizza is PHENOMENAL....

Although this place has really great reviews I have to say, I think it's mediocre. And it's not just because I'm from New York and love NY style pizza. I tried Gino's deep dish and thought it was a lot more impressive. This pizza was not bad but it didn't blow me away either- I probably wouldn't return given the many options of pizza in the area.

Not for me. I love the crust but I prefer a sweeter sauce and more cheese. It was my first ever experience with Chicago Pizza. It was delicious and I ate every ounce of it bc it was a treat for me to have PIZZA. I am Sicilian so my favorite is fluffy pizza, with sweet sauce, and a lot of cheese!

Over the last six months, I've ordered delivery of a small, Buttercrust, Cheese & Sausage Pizza, and an order of Buffalo Chicken Wings, to an Elmhurst address. The pizza always arrived in a perfect state, but the Buffalo Wings were always a toss up. Were they cooked correctly? Were they overdone or underdone? Were they dry from to little Buffalo sauce, or would they have the proper amount of sauce?

When I first started ordering wings, they came out perfect. But now six months in, I never know what I'm going to get. On my last order, I ordered two orders. When they were Delivered, the packages were cold, and it wasn't because the delivery took to long. It was because the wings weren't cooked long enough. After delivery, I bit into the wings, which were pink and raw. I contacted the Elmhurst Manager, and didn't ask for a replacement. I just wanted Rosie to know that the cooks aren't consistent. I have a credit for two orders of wings, but I won't use it, because I no longer trust that location. I'm not sure, but either they changed suppliers or cooks, and both are not doing a good job. I'll go to BWW for wings in the future.

I'll trust Lou's for pizza, but not anything
else. In six months, I can't get a decent order of wings. That's my opinion, and only mine. But I've been a Kitchen Manager in the past and have dealt with this type of problem.

I'd like to contact the owners, but don't have their contact info.

I'm no longer going to use Lou's as a supplier. I simply cave trust them, and those two orders of underdone wings cost over $20.

I can no longer spend that money on inferior food. It just costs to much not to be done right.

I only wish that upper management would drop in on this stores and review the cooking practice, so that the practice was uniform from store to store, because  sure it isn't, at least from my multiple experiences.

The Manager, Rosie, knows who I am. But even after this, even though I have credit, I won't be contacted.

I'm one person. I'm not important.

Just order pizza.

The other items are hit or miss.

If I were management, I'd be looking at staffing, because I don't believe they share the vision of the company.

I know I'd be very engaged in it as a former Kitchen Manager for the Howard Johnson's chain, The Ground Round.

We always listened to our clients. Always.

True Deep Dish Pizza!

When you think of Chicago, you think of the home of the deep dish and Lou Malnati's Pizzeria delivers just that! The lines are long for a reason and you'll need to place your name in line 40 minutes before your stomach gets hungry but it's all worth it.

I had the butter crust pizza with the huge slab of sausage right on top- just great! Hot, crispy and filled with the flavors you love- cheese, meat and the herbs and spices that pull it all together nicely.

Staff are friendly and very attentive.

An additional bonus is that their bathrooms are very clean.

Bottom line- Unos has nothing on this place, for the real flavor of the deep dish- this is the spot!

One of the best places to get Chicago Deep Dish Pizza. Gets crowded every night of the week. Very small bar area, so even though I was by myself, I needed to wait for a table. They have a lot of seating upstairs. Nice place, good friendly service and the best pizza around. If you don't preorder your pizza you will have a 40 min wait after ordering. Decent beer and drink selection as well.

Carb loaded before the Chicago marathon- great pizza, bruschetta and salad! Service was fantastic. We put our pizza order in with our name for a table. 40 minutes on Saturday night was well worth the wait. Family friendly and great food.

Excellent pizza! I got seated right away and the service was quick.

They found the secret with deep pan pizza. Instead of just making a Italian style pizza an loading it with extra filling they went another route. The crust is perfect and the combination of filling is just bang on.

It is the first time in my life that I waited 35 minutes for a pizza, but it was all worth it.

Having only tried Giordano's and Gino's East from our previous trip to Chicago several years ago, I can't really comment on how the deep dish pizza at Lou Malnati's compares to the other two.  I thought the pizza was decent and definitely filling.  I do remember the buttery crust being extra special compared to the other two popular joints.  I'm am only giving the place three stars partly because of the service.  I felt that it was a little disorganized since we were asked to switch tables initially.  Also, we felt that the server could've been more attentive and followed up on how our pizza was or if we needed anything else.  Perhaps I was expecting too much going in that the experience was a little underwhelming.

Last night while in Chicago on business I decided to go on an excursion (all by my lonesome - after hiding from the typical colleague steakhouse dinner) into the inner city in search of authentic Chicago style deep dish pizza. Initially I thought I might head out to the place that was featured on Anthony Bordain's "No Reservations", but once I realized it was about 40 minutes outside of the city I quickly changed my mind. I settled on the Lou Malnati's pizzeria. They have several locations, however this location seemed to be the most popular and it also happened to be in a part of town with interesting bars and lounges within a few blocks (check my other reviews for some good recommendations).

I arrived around 8 PM on a Saturday night and the place was packed. I gave them my name and was told it would be in approximately 30 minute wait for a table or I could just sit at the bar. They also recommended placing the order for my pizza ahead of time since the pies generally take around 30 minutes to prepare. They have a chart on the wall near where you check in illustrating the sizes of the different size options  ranging from personal to extra-large. I was famished and was concerned the "small" size (one step up from personal) would not be sufficient to satisfy my appetite. The lady at the check in desk was correct, the "small" sized "Malnati Chicago Classic" (  Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust) pie shut me down like a pile of bricks.  

As you can see in the photograph I made it about halfway through slice 4/4 and that was it for me. Perhaps I should not have ordered minestrone soup, without it I may have made it through my iPod. They also have a full bar on-site, a nice touch; I had a few glasses of red wine to go with my pie.

Being from the Northeast I had reservations about the Chicago style deep dish pizza, but my meal here made me a believer. The ingredients were all of high quality In the crust itself was delicious.  I still prefer New York style pizza, however if I had a place like this near my home I am sure I would eat their from time to time.

Five stars for a nothing-but-positive Chicago deep-dish pizza experience.  After I finished my pie, I jumped in an Uber and headed to my next destination, but that is another story!

pics.caption: My size small Deep dish pie  in all of its glory. That's what I'm talkin about!
Minestrone soup as an appetizer - tasty, but a fatal mistake in the big picture.

review.des: the pizza is good but they put so so so so much cheese! i told them to put very little cheese but there was a ton so i can only imagine how much they put if you dont them ask to put less cheese!

Penne ala Malnati can you say YUM!!! Also their Tiramisu  is one of the better ones i have EVER had! The The Malnati Chicago Classic was good, but unfortunately I am more of a thin crust pizza person.

Still dreaming about that pasta though!

This is some of the best pizza in Chicago.  Delivery takes a while during busy hours, but that's understandable.

We got the deep dish Malnati Chicago Classic with Spinach mix added, and it was excellent.  My wife and I enjoyed it very much, and would gladly order from them again.

My first experience trying a deep dish Chicago pizza and I was not disappointed! We went back for seconds before flying home.

They delivered it to our hotel room so we never got the dine in experience. We ordered the traditional deep dish Chicago pizza both times. The cheese was amazing! The butter crust... drooling!!! We also ordered calamari and that wasn't as good but I blame it on delivery. The sauce it came with was yummy. Next time we are in town we will be dinning in.
By far and away the best! The sausage on the classic Lou and the butter crust are a great combination!

Look. I'm giving this 4 stars but not because it was really good pizza.  It was good...something...but we really need to come up with a different word for what this is.  It might be in the pizza order, but it is not the same species as pizza.  That said, because we don't have a word for it yet, I will call it pizza.  But it isn't pizza.

I don't get it Chicago, I really don't.  There isn't a comparison to be made between NY pizza (or, just pizza, for short) and Chicago deep dish.  How do you compare the two?  How can you possibly say one is better than the other?  It's like saying chocolate is better than football or unicorns are better than rainbows.  It's not comparable.

Let me get on to the "pizza" for a moment - it is 4 star worthy food.  I would probably go 3.5 if I could, but I can't, and its definitely better than a 3.  Heck, it better be since this is the go-to for Chicago pizza...depending on who you ask.  Apparently, you can ask 20 people in Chicago for the best pizza and get 20 different answers, but that's not much different from NY.  Anyway, I got the Lou, or something like that.  It's their signature deep dish pizza with butter crust and a flavorful tomato sauce and cheese.  It's basically what you would expect a deep dish pizza to be, though I am not sure I would go with the butter crust again.  It was good, but a bit too heavy on the buttery goodness.

My girlfriend and I sat on the patio and the service was good out there, though we failed to read anything that would have warned us the food takes 35-40 minutes or else we would have planned our day better and not gotten so annoyed by the wait.  Once the food came, I will admit I devoured it.  Again, it's not that it wasn't good, it's just that you walk in expecting to be floored and really struggle with the idea of NY v. Chicago pizza.  There is no struggle, there is no contest.

So, again, its good, but its not pizza.  This is what you get if your pizza was bloated, or perhaps if your pizza was allergic to bees and got stung, or nuts and was served with sausage cooked in peanut oil.  It deserves its own name and its own category.  But please, for the love of all that is good and holy in the world, stop calling it pizza and stop comparing it to NY.
Delicious pizza!! Calamari was so fresh and salad was great. Just gotta wait because everyone wants to eat Lou's! I don't blame them!
Ate dinner here after strolling the beautiful downtown Chicago. The food was delicious and very filling.
Ordered a small deep dish pizza with a side of pizza sauce. Pizza sauce is literally a can of super chunky tomatoes   Onions on pizza were tough and raw.  So disappointed.

After tasting Gino's East and Giordano's, I knew the best big thing to round out the trio was a pie at Lou Malnati's. And man I do have some mixed opinions on this. Again, in accordance with my deep dish factorial analysis, I gotta judge it based on the crust, sauce, cheese + toppings, and ratios. How do we break this down?

Crust: Lou Malnati's takes on a close second to Giordano's for sure, but barring anything else they are both essentially equal. Flaky and crispy butter crust, never burnt. I will knock on the fact that typically because Lou's and Gino's has smaller pizzas than Giordano's, the ratio of dough to ingredients seems to be greater. Still crispy and delicious though.

Sauce: I actually prefer the flavor of the sauce at Lou's compared to Giordano's, but much prefer the consistency of Giordano's(which just seems fresher with larger chunks of tomato). The sauce at Lou's is a bit sweeter while still being spiced similarly(I'm a fan), but for the most part seemed like a paste rather than a more natural and made-to-order tomato sauce.

We ordered two large pizzas, the Lou(Spinach mix, fresh tomatoes, 3 cheeses), and the Chicago classic(Sausage, extra cheese). Here is where I have mixed opinions. Despite the lack of meat, the Lou is probably one of my favorite deep dish pizzas in Chicago. The extra tomatoes and the fresh spinach mix really just makes it all taste vibrant, and the cheese with the sauce really just brings it all together in an oozing fatty mess of deliciousness. The Chicago Classic on the other hand....the plate of sausage was nice but I think I prefer the sausage at Giordano's(Lou's was about equal to Gino's in that respect). However the ratios of the Chicago classic were a bit off for my tastes: far too much cheese and crust and not enough sauce. In the end I sort of just wanted an extra side of sauce just so I could dip the extra cheesy bread.

Overall verdict: Lou's can make some good pizza, and the namesake is there for a reason. As for the Chicago classic, if you want a meat based pizza I'd stick with just a regular pepperoni or sausage deep dish because the ratios will be a bit more favorable. Unless you're willing to say cheese.

My friend and I were visiting Indy for a few days so we decided to make a one day trip to Chicago! This was our first stop!

What We Ordered:
- Trio of Dips and Pizza Chips
- Small Malnati Chicago Classic Deep Dish

Out of the three housemade dips, roasted garlic and giardiniera-topped hummus were my favorite. The artichoke dip was just okay. The deep dish pizza was AMAZING!!!! The crust was nice and crispy and the cheese was oozing out. Yummm.... I wished it didn't take so long to make because I was already kind of full after the dips and pizza chips by the time it arrived. :(
A+ chicago style pizza.  Love this! would highly recommend to anyone wanting a chicago - style pizza in chicago!

Everyone always asks what is the best Chicago Style Pizza.  Lou Malnati's is always my recommendation.  They don't always have the crazy crowds you get at Giordano's or Gino's and Lou's is way better!  They have multiple locations around the city but I went tot his one and got a table right away, service was good and the pizza was excellent.

People always ask me where to go for Chicago deep dish pizza, and I always recommend Lou Malnatis.  If you're vegetarian, go for The Lou, otherwise, definitely try the pepperoni (which can be on the spicy side) or order sausage.  There is 2 ways to order sausage at Lou Malnatis, so make sure you know what you are getting into.  If you order sausage, it will come as a giant sheet of sausage as an entire layer of the pizza.  If you tell them easy sausage, it will come in the more traditional way of having pieces of sausage sprinkled on top of the pie.  You can't go wrong with either, just a matter of personal preference.  Either way, this is my hands down favorite place to go for authentic Chicago Deep Dish pizza.

First time visiting Chicago. The concierge at the hotel recommended this place and said it was the best for pizza. I'm not a big fan of deep dish pizza in the first place. I tried the "Lou" and it was just alright. It didn't have a lot of flavor to me. It was kind of bland. I also got the Malnati Salad which was amazing. That was the best part. Salad was on point. I would go back for the salad but not the pizza.

We visited Chicago last week and we excited to try Chicago deep dish pizza! We chose this location and didn't get disappointed. We were aware of  waiting time since the spot is extremely popular. We ordered some calamari as an appetizer and were amazed by the freshness of the food! We also went for Lou's special deep dish pizza with mushrooms, spinach and three cheeses. Pizza was just yum and our waiter was extremely helpful. Definitely worth of waiting.

What exactly can you not brag about in this place??  The only other thing I wanted to do when I came to Chicago, other than go to my concert, was eat Chicago style deep dish and this place seriously delivered.  It really was a no-brainer since it's advertised so many times on Food Network shows, etc. on where to eat in Chicago so I was a bit worried about the touristy feel of the place.  No problem.  It may be where the tourists go, but it was also quite obvious that it's also where the locals go.

I knew the pizza would impress but the service was bar none.  Our server was HIGHLY knowledgeable about what we should order as newbies and suggested their house salad along side our pizza and I'm so glad he did.  That is seriously one of the best salads I've had and went with the pizza so so well!  As for the pizza, duh, it was fantastic.  We went 1/2 and 1/2 and both sides were mouth watering. No words other than, GO.  You won't regret it!  Great food. Great staff!!  We will be back Lou!!! No worries!!

It's all about that BUTTER CRUST! While it's a little on the heavy side for me, it's still one of those deep dish pizzas you have to try in Chicago. I like their tomato sauce, it's quite flavorful. I feel like it's chunkier than Gio's? I can only eat one slice, so I try to make sure to enjoy each bite. Good thing it's not as cheesy as Gio's, because then I would probably be way too full and bloated.

I know it sounds weird, but their salads are pretty freaking legit. Especially since the pizza is so heavy, it's nice to balance it out with some fresh, yummy salad! Not too much dressing, and not too heavy on the little bits of salami meat. Definitely try the salad!
Great classic staple of Chicago. Takes a while to get food, but well worth the wait!!

Came in today Tuesday am right at 11 before we left for the airport.

Pizza: the sauce was very flavorful and had just enough cheese on it. The dough was perfect. Not too crunchy and not to soft.
5/5

Service: we sat at the bar with mark, amazing guy! Has such a Nice personality, thanks for the enjoyable conversation!

If we ever come back to town we are coming in to have pizza and sit with mark!

I had my first Chicago style deep dish pizza here last night. For appetizer we got the Three Cheese Bread. It's garlic French bread with three cheese and came with three dipping sauces (artichoke dip, hummus, and garlic sauce). The bread was very crunchy and had dices of tomato. My favorite dip was the garlic sauce for sure.

For the main course, we went with the house specialty, Chicago Deep Dish Pizza. The Malnati Chicago Classic was made with Lou's lean sausage, tasty tomato sauce, and some serious load of cheese. They did not mess around with their cheese, it was awesome! We ordered small but it came in 4 good size slices. We also ordered a small Pepperoni deep dish pizza and between the three of us we couldn't even finish. One of my friends had food coma after we were done.

For dessert we got the Tre Dolci. It came with three individual portioned desserts. We had the Tiramisu, chocolate chip pizza, and the peach cobbler. Chocolate chip pizza was by far the best, hands down! Definitely give it a try when you are there.

Overall the atmosphere was nice, service was great, and the food was awesome.  It is a little on the pricy side for pizza, we spent about a hundred between the three of us (we did get 5 drinks). Nevertheless, I would still recommend it if you want to try the Chicago style deep dish pizza.

The place was good for pizza, definitely something different. The pizza was really big and thick. My group of 6 adults actually had trouble finishing it. But there was a taste on the pizza was odd. The juice of the pizza tasted kinda like an alcohol. But other than that, it was actually good.

The cheese was extremely good. I could definitely tell it was high quality cheese. When I picked up the pizza, it was a never ending strand.

But other than the sauce on the pizza, the place was actually ok. Loved the inside of the place. Also provided free valet parking. And all the staff were really friendly.

High praise for "The Lou".
I have never been to the restaurant but I attend an event which orders Lou Malnati's every week.  Now, I have had a couple decades of pizza, more than enough to last a lifetime, and I am Never happy to see pizza served at an event even if it is free. However, I was introduced to The "Lou" which is a vegetarian deep dish pizza, and I am sold.  I am not even a vegetarian and I actual Look Forward to having a slice every week, even after many many weeks I have not grown tired of it.  The "Lou" has converted me back into being a pizza eater after many years of being a pizza avoider.  What more can I say.

Wait was long but it takes 30 mins to cook a deep dish ... tte wait was worth it like u can go do whatever they send uva text when it's time...... and plus the pizza was amazing like a half a slice filled me up

We were in town and had to get our Chicago deep dish fix.  After asking around town, we decided on Lou Malnati's.  I really don't get what all the hype is about.  The ingredients were not quality, the cheese was mushy and not stretchy, the crust was flaky like pie crust, the whole thing was unimpressive and not good at all. I had one slice and didn't finish it.  We ordered mozzerella sticks and those were frozen, not even homemade.  Not sure what the fuss is all about but the best thing I had was my drink.

If you love cheese and crust, this pizza is life lol. The only thing I didn't love was the amount of chunks of tomato on top of the pizza. WARNING atleast 45 minute wait just for your pizza, another 45 to be seated.

This place is viewed as one of the best pizza places in Chicago and certainly has the wait times to back it up. We went on a Sunday afternoon for a late lunch and had a 45 min-hour wait. We decided to get drinks elsewhere to kill time. You can pre-order your pizzas, which helps with table time. We ordered the calamari appetizer, Malnati salad, Malnati pizza and pepperoni pizza. The calamari was crispy and tasty and gas a flavorful dipping sauce. The Malnati salad was full of great ingredients, packed a punch of flavor and was dressing heavy (which I like). The pizzas were also good and way different from east coast pizza style. The Malnati pizza was good, but I wasn't a fan of the thick cut sausage. The pepperoni pizza, which I got with extra sauce, was great! The cheese was a little heavy on both pizzas, but I am told that is the Chicago way. I think the food is decent and that coming here is a must for a tourist, but there is too much hype.

Admittedly this is just a review of the food as I've always only got take out.  This location is close to where I live, so its a somewhat regular occurrence in my household.

Their pizza (both thin and deep dish) is one of the best in the city- and the crust on their pizza may be one of the best I've had in the world.  I start to drool just thinking about it.  The pizza always the right ratio of sauce to cheese to toppings creating pure bliss with every bite.

A few years ago a friend turned me on to the Malnati salad and so glad she did.  When not in the mood for pure gluttony, I'll do the salad (still far from healthy with the salami bits and cheese) which is one of the few salads to show up in my dreams.

I have to say, for my first time eating at Lou Malnati's, I most definately enjoyed my experience. My server Colin was prompt and accurate with our order, and the busboy Scott was very helpful in suggesting what to eat. If I was ever to eat here again (which will be highly likely) I would very much like to have them cater to our hunger needs again. 5 out of 5 for a very enjoyable meal.

I'm a Giordanos fan and pretty much always go there when in Chicago. However I tried Lou's and it did not disappoint.
I went in on a busy afternoon for lunch but quickly pounced on a seat at the bar.
As usual lunchtime hours at deep dish joints offer a good deal on personal size pizzas, which is what I ordered.
For $10 you get a soup or salad, a personal pizza, and unlimited refills of soda. So how can you beat that? It made for the perfect lunch and I really liked their pizza.

I kept reading that this place is a must visit. We were seated right away but things got busy quick. Pizza takes 45 minutes which feels like forever so get an appetizer. The personal size pizza is perfect to fill you up. I have to be honest the pizza was nothing special. Maybe I just don't like deep dish? The deep dish cookie was REALLY good.
